content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
												What is good about this game:- Character development is complex- Good setting- Varied enemies- Variety of situations you find yourself into- Nice graphicsSo why downvote?Because my friends, of two reasons.The GAME BALANCE. It is so broken i cannot even believe it. Some fights are so unbalanced i had to actually lower the difficultry to Normal to beat them, which i never ever did for any game in my life. This because you are put in situations where you just need luck to make it out alive.And Luck is the real master of this game, not skill nor strategy. Just pure luck. RNG (Random Numerical Generation) (What determines % of success or failure of things) is so determining in the combat that it just rules over everything. In other turn based games there is RNG of course, but also other factors like strategy, formations, class builds, level are critical to win a fight, but not here in blackguards, not at the same level.A single random critical, or spell failure (spells can FAIL casting, yes you got it right), or a random miss with 99% chance, or again some trap which activates randomly decides to turn just towards your party and wipe it out with a blast of fire.All these things can make a fight fail. Random chance upon chance upon chance upon chance. Not even in Vegas there is so much gambling.This more than a game of skill is a game of luck. I have many many years of experience in all kinds of RPGs but i just cannot take it anymore. I find myself by now to repeat fight over and over and over again just to get a fight where the RNG favors me, where traps do not activate on my team, or on the target i have to protect, etc, and make me fail after a well planned strategy.Do yourself a favor, go and buy Divinity Original Sin, that's a turn based game made right, not this disguised slot machine of a game we have here.

number of helpful: 32 of 45 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
Blackguards is a medieval fantasy turn-based tactical RPG based on the Dark Eye tabletop RPG. Framed and tortured by the one you called your friend, you make your escape with a few other prisoners, trying to find out the truth behind the accusations against you. This review takes into account the Untold Legends DLC.Pros: Nice game with enough mechanical depth to offer a variety of gameplay styles: rather than level-based progression, you spend adventure points on anything from attributes, weapon skills, spells and perks and determine exactly how specialized you become with your various talents. The story isn't of a great hero, but of someone who won't leave a mark on history, making your way in shady towns and accepting questionable quests, especially in the multiple side quests added by the Untold Legend DLC where you must take stances on subjects such as slavery. Graphics are good enough for the genre, tactical maps are clean, most of which have interactive environment elements you might use against your foes if they don't use them against you. The game is sufficiently balanced, and even with the occasional difficulty spikes, you can jump right back in the last encounter to try things differently.Cons: Many will find the depth to be a bit too much, scrolling through 5 pages of skills and perks will make it hard to figure the best way to optimize your character. There is a limited variety of equipment, especially armor. The story is pretty linear and not all that complex. The odds of success aren't mushed, so 95% chance of success might still miss, multiple times, in a row, which will frustrate anyone who isn't used to rolling dices. The music is somber, and sucks life and excitement out of the game whenever you're not in a combat situation.Verdict: ★★★☆☆ - It's up to youThis is an ok RPG. It is definitively ported directly from its tabletop RPG roots, which might feel very "meh" to the average gamer. I still recommend it, just make sure you also get the Untold Legend DLC, or you'll feel the game is short on side-quests.—————————————————————————This was just my opinion.If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

number of helpful: 26 of 35 people (74%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
												The game starts off well enough but I eventually had to quit.  I was getting so frustrated I nearly threw my mouse through my monitor.  Blackguards is presented as a game returning to the core roots of RPG strategy goodness.  Just check out the multiple videos from Daedalic above for all the stuff that sounds so great about this game.  What is presented sounded awesome to me but in reality my two attempts through the game turned into a frustrating slog from one scenario to the next.  I got hooked on the story from the start which turned out to be a prison break.  Nothing ground-shakingly new here but it worked for bringing three main characters together and launching them off on what was to be a quest to save the world.  The cut-scene interactions just propel the story forward, but did contain some humorous dialogue.  City/settlement locations are really just screens you click on to visit the tavern/shop/quest giver, etc.  Again, nothing earth-shattering for the genre but where this game was supposed to shine was in the combat.And the combat on many of the levels was excellent.  Some of the scenarios were very challenging and I truly felt good when I had achieved victory conditions.  You certainly cannot simply build up your characters and then rush through everything.  Planning was necessary.   All that was great.Specific building of your characters is crucial to the point that if you build them wrong, you will find that the difficulty spikes.  Character building is handled through allocating skill points.  There are a lot of options (FIVE screens worth) and very little in-game guidance on what to build up first.  I am sure most players will do what I did and end up resorting to the forums and walkthroughs to know how best to maximize their points.  It should not be this difficult or nebulous on building up your characters - especially with this many options.  The game reminds you to save often so you can go back to an earlier time and rebuild if needed.  But that still stings a little knowing that you lost that progress and will need to make it up.But then the game started throwing out some curve balls on the scenarios and I found myself needing to restart certain ones again and again.  These levels were often fronted by a cut-scene dialogue that had to be clicked through again and again.  I just do not understand why they couldn't simply start the level with your characters on the field.  Many of these levels had special rules or situations that were not made apparent until you played them.  So you learned the "special" rules through failing at the level and had to try again.  And again.  And again.  It does not help when the game chains scenarios together without a way to rest in-between.  You may find that by the end of the 2nd or 3rd scenario you are completely out of potions/health/magic/whatever.  And you may need to not only restart that level, but perhaps go back to a prior level so that you end with enough health/magic to be successful in the next one.  I could see the game doing this on hardcore difficulty for those who really enjoy upping the difficulty, but I just wanted to veg out after a hard day at work.  By the time I was into the gladiator fights in chapter 2 I realized something.  The. Game. Was. No. Fun. I am recommending a pass on this one.  If you do buy it, wait for a nice Steam or bundle sale.

number of helpful: 14 of 15 people (93%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												I honestly took a long time to play this game (I knew I eventually would as I love turn based tactical RPG), because of all the mixed reviews.  Regardless, I can't believe how much fun the combat in this game is.  I'll break down some key game concepts that might persuade you to buy or push you away.Good:-Amazing character development using a deep system of random dice rolls and old-school board game elements-Hard battles (some are pushovers) that make you think or have to re-do because of a single screw up-Deep turn based hexagonal board-like combat involving traps and the environment-A Baldur's Gate style of map minus the exploration-The game really focuses on the battles without the fuss of wandering and exploring (ie. not an exploration game)Bad:-The story is not bad, but one shouldn't be getting this game for that reason-The itemization and game mechanics are a bit complicated to understand and required a lot of Google searching-Linear story and no explorationIf you are looking for a game that focuses purely on the tactical turn based combat, then this is truly it.  There is no wandering and exploring with your party and discovering secrets.  The world map is like Baldur's Gate, however, when you visit cities and places, you are either transported into a combat situation with some cutscenes or visit a town where NPC's are static screens filled with innkeepers, healers, merchants, etc.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												I'm really surprised at some of the negative reviews that this game has received. I personally found the story to be interesting and engaging, it's dark in places and you need to get your hands dirty, but that's how Dark Eye fantasy generally is. One moment in particular seems to have turned some players off, I thought it was a brave decision by the developers, and I thought it worked well, a story should generate emotion, and this one did. It's not all grim and dark however, and the humour is very finely tuned in places. Turn based tactical games are a genre that I'm very much into, I play a lot of Chaos Reborn on a daily basis for the PvP side of it. Consequentially I often find that with story driven turn based tactical games that the PvE battles are a let-down, I don't think an AI can generally replicate the engagement that comes from playing against a human opponent. But I tell you what, Blackguards comes as close to it as I've ever found. There's a real wealth of variation in the battles that occur from; small skirmishes, arena fights, fighting withdraws, chase downs, there's all sorts. The developers of Blackguards have really gone out of their way to keep the fighting fresh. As a result this is one story driven turn based tactical game that I can see myself replaying. Just taken on their own the fights are a lot of fun.I think the one caveat that I'd give is that this is a game where it's worth checking out what happens to certain characters in advance. I’m not going to give anyway any spoilers here, but making your party build based on that knowledge does make a difference to the overall effectiveness of your party by the end of the game.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												"Back in the day" this would have been called "a thinking man's game." If you are looking for "fast paced" look elsewhere. EVERY thing that you do NEEDS to be carefully considered and thought out. The Manual says to "save often." And it is spot on because you WILL have to go back and retry battles.The biggest problem that I have (had) with it is that while it is billed as non-linear, in the begining it IS. And some of the begining quests are out of balance with the character's abilities. Now, I will readily admit that I am not an especially intelligent person. I'm not stupid, but i feel like it when i play this game. Sometimes I can figure out what i need to do... but i can't figure out HOW to get it done. (Like i KNOW i need to lure the Wood Troll into the swamp gas areas and then blow them up, but it moves too far for me to get him where i want him.)Some games do a very good job of designing a variety of difficulty levels so that anyone can play them at whatever level of difficulty they want to. (ex: The King's Bounty Games, the Witcher games, and the Elder Scrolls series.) some - like this one - do not.If you LOVE a real challenge and don't mind the frustration of failing and having to re-start a game... buy this. If you want a game that you can just play even if you aren't a chess Grand Master... don't.

If you start with that understanding, you'll avoid the disappointment that many players have encountered.The game is about figuring out how to beat a series of scenarios.  Sometimes it's about how you use abilities and items, sometimes it's about using the environment.It's not a perfect game, but it's fun.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												This game was part of a bundle I bought 1 year ago - together with Memoria and Dark eye: Chains of Satinav. I did not install it at the time because the looks of the game did not appeal to me at first. I even thought back then that this was a strategy game (its actually a turn based RPG :P) One month ago, I decided to install the game in order to get the steam cards. Based on the reviews I was expecting a pretty aweful game. Nevertheless, I decided to play for an hour instead of idling.The first screen I encountered was the character creation. I was pleasantly suprised by the depth and variety of choices and I found myself tinkering at the various options and builds for an hour!Well, after an hour, I thought that the options did not really matter because I wasnt going to play the game given how bad it must be according to the reviews I had read. However, I was still waiting for those cards so I decided to have a look at the actual game. Again, to my suprise, although it started slowly, the game captured my interest. Slowly, but steadily, I started enjoying the story and the battles gameplay. That was it, after some time I was hooked!Here is what I think of the game:+Give the game some time at the beginning. It starts slowly but it steadily builds a strong story! Same goes for the gameplay. It looks a bit strange at first but I grew to like it very much! +The Graphs are really good. +Full sound + Voice + Subtitles +Dialogue options+Decisions matter+Challenging game+Character creation system. There is no level up system - Using adventure points to create unique ways of fighting. +Story twists. +I havent encountered any in game bugs. -Some may find the game TOO challenging. Its not a forgiving game. You have to think the consequences of your gameplay. -Linear. Most of the times there is only one battle available. -THE MOST IMPORTANT PROBLEM AT THE MOMENT IS THAT THE GAME SEEMS TO HAVE SOME PROBLEM RUNNING IN WINDOWS 10. However, this issue can be solved with a little bit of tinkering. There are numerous solutions out there. To sum up, I fully recommend this game at a discount and even at full price if you enjoy turn based RPGS. I dont understand whats going on with other reviews. Perhaps people were expecting a different kind of game? However, keep in mind that the game has some compatibility issues with Win 10. I've already bought Blackguards 2.

number of helpful: 26 of 39 people (67%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												A solid strategy RPG that focuses on the combat and doesn't weigh you down with walking back and forth through the same areas. Cities, dungeons, and world are travelled by point and click and I enjoyed the simplicity of it. Combat is done with an isometric view on hexes. Each combat area is unique. Melee combat is fairly straight forward. The magic combat really shines with up to 4 levels of each spell, each level unique, allowing you to pick any level you have unlocked. So later in the game, a mage can have quite the variation of spells to choose from. I felt the game started a little slow, took off and didn't slow down until the anticlimactic ending. I was able to beat the game with over 30 hours which included the DLC. The DLC was integrated into the main campaign, which was nice. I like a game that doesn't overstay it's welcome.Regarding difficulty, I felt many previous The Dark Eye games were much more difficult and appreciated the fact that I was able to get through this game with minimal issues. It is a strategy game, so if you pick poor weapon and spell combinations,you will hit a brick wall you can't pass. If you are having difficulty with the game, lower the difficulty. I like that difficulty can be changed. Another bonus is the game starts up quick and you can skip the intro and get right to the menu. It is worth mentioning with so many games forcing you to wait through minutes of unskippable logos.

												I got this game in a bundle and was just curious to try it, so I first cheked the store page to see if there were good reviews. There weren\'t, and people was talking about it as too hard.I agree, the character sheet is very complex and you end up wasting a lot of experience points, but it\'s not too bad.I really enjoyed the story and I find that the voice acting is superb, there\'s a point in the game where you have more than 10 side quests and you really want to go on, but then there\'s a slow down and it gets quite heavy in the end. I don\'t think it\'s too hard, but I don\'t recommend playing this game at max difficulty, it\'s balanced enough at normal.Overall it was a fun game, far from perfection but still enjoyable, I definitely won\'t play it a second time, but I will play Blackguards 2, which is said to be even better polished. Hope you found my review useful!

Posted: March 26, 2015
												I wanted to like this game. I really did. But the extremely clunky UI, the complete lack of explanation of gameplay, and the lackluster story made it very hard to do so. Not a complete waste, but there are much better games out there. Played a few more hours, and it wasn't any better. The game is still wildly uneven in difficulty and very obtuse on how certain mechanics actually work. Everything out of combat is a complete joke; the "dialouge" which consists of clicking your way down the dialouge box until you're done, the fact that you'll most likely still be using starting equipment 5 hours in, the fact that all spells (no matter how trivial) have a failure chance, to the final point that Final Fantasy 1 had more freedom than this game does. Seriously, every single thing out of combat is a single screenshot where floating chat boxes tell you what's going on.  Save your money, buy a better game.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												First, let me just say that (spoiler alert!) despite the title and hype, the game still ends up with a cliched save-the-world scenario.  Which was a bit of a disappointment.All right, so there's some good points to this game: The combats are each well-designed (often frustrating, but that's part of the fun), and almost every combat has some interactive environment object you can use to either help or hurt you.  This part of the game works great.  I wish the rest of the game was better so I could take more advantage of it.Further good news: The game isn't ridiculous easy, even on the easiest difficulty level.  I had to switch down from Normal in order to make any progress past the first chapter.Now for the bad news.First, the combat system is incredibly complicated.  The rules for combat are mostly invisible, but reading through them (on the help screen) made my eyes cross.  This coming from a guy who plays tabletop D&D, HERO System, Shadowrun, Traveller, and Legend of the Five Rings.  This might explain why the chance to hit an opponent is vastly different from the chance marked on your screen.  Anything under an 80% chance to hit will miss at least 2/3 of the time.  And there's one enemy in particular that you won't hit more than about 1/20 of the time, despite the fact that your hit % is shown as 60.  Always.  I'm not sure if the hit chance is failing to take into account about half the combat rules, or if (as some others have suggested) the random number generator is just broken.  Either way, this drops my enjoyment of the game by quite a bit.The other problem is that there's really no actual "role-playing" involved in the game.  There's little to nothing you can do to direct the game, except in some of the sidequests.  And most of that involves giving up a sidequest instead of finishing it.  Sure, you have dialogue options, but they don't really *DO* anything.  Overall, I'd probably rate this something like 3/10.  The combat scenes are great, but the combat itself fails, and everything else is boring as hell.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												Blackguards is not a very good game. It's a great example of turn-based strategy gone horribly wrong and just because something uses hexagons doesn't make it inherently worthwhile.Blackguards is cheaply made. That much becomes apparent as soon as the voice acting starts torturing your speakers. The voice actor for the male main character is weirdly familiar from other budget titles. He's not trying very hard and neither is anyone else. The graphics are also fairly poor. I didn't expect much but it looks incredibly cheap and one has to suspect it was meant to be a tablet title originally. The art direction is also incredibly generic. This game makes Dragon Age look like Zeno Clash.Most of the game is really just battles. Towns, numerous as they are, serve to buy gear and heal up and not much more. There are side quests but they almost always result in even more combat. You would think a game that contains this much fighting would have deep mechanics but no. There is not even flanking or backstabbing. Most of the weapon abilities make you hit harder or pierce armor in exchange for accuracy and that's basically it for physical attackers. Abilities that can hit multiple enemies are only available very late and they are not great. There is a knockdown but it virtually never works and most elite enemies are outright immune to it. The game is terrible with double standards like this.Mages have a bit more to do but the spells are horribly imbalanced, ranging from absolutely useless to pretty much necessary to beat the game. You can't even make a proper offensive mage because spells do poor damage and are not very mana-efficient. There's virtually no way to restore mana outside of the very poor regeneration between turns. Potions do exist but they are insanely expensive. They're something you use in a boss fight and not something you can waste in a regular encounter. To make things worse, spells are also line of sight dependent. That means if you surround an enemy with your melee fighters, you can't hit them and if one of your characters gets surrounded you can't heal them. Want to throw a fireball into a cluster of enemies? You can't because you have no line of sight to the center so you can never really hit the whole group. It's as annoying as it sounds. Level 4 spells on the other are insane. They can hit every single enemy or ally on the entire map, no matter how far away they are. Sadly, later on enemies use the same spells against you and it's awful because you can't do anything about it.The game's biggest downfall are the gimmick maps. This is hard to explain. Basically, half the encounters are built some sort of gimmick except... the game doesn't explain these gimmicks to you or warns you that there even might be a gimmick instead of a regular skirmish. The most blatant example is when you plunder a crypt and you get attacked by a gang of skeletons (you never hear about skeleton gang violence in the media, typical) and every time you destroy one, it gets resurrected by some crystal. Fair enough, you have the skeletons distracted by some of your fighters and have another one sneak around and attack the crystal. You attack it with your spear and...it does no damage. The crystal is immune to thrust damage. There is no feedback to it, you can't figure it out on your own through the environment. Well, that would have been nice to know, I thought to myself. Most of the time the best way to beat is a map is to figure out the gimmick and immediately reload the fight in order to actually use it to its full effect. Everything else is an uphill battle.So yeah, it's not a very good game. It's full of baffling design decisions and even the things outside of combat are not good. I could write for hours about the awful, incoherent story but it's not worth the effort.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2016
												BlackGuards is a turn based RPG with party combat and grid battlegrounds . It is not open world game but rather simplified system where you move around towns and map by clicking on images .There are some sidequests and text based choices that can effect quest outcome and impact later in game . At the start you will be able to customize your character in depth with skills but cosmetic options are lacking .This game has a lot of issues but I was able to overlook those because the core gameplay is fun and challenging . I will go over some negative points that people mentioned in reviews to give some feedback .-Beginner's trap?- There are several events in this game that can force you to start over if you did not manage your resources properly . You can end up in a position where you can't win a fight and can't go to previous areas to level up on side quests .  Auto Save will not help so you should keep 2 more save points .I don't think that it adds any fair difficulty but I like games that do not hold my hand .This game is extremely hard because you can't always anticipate what happens . Like you may need a speed buff for a mission but you never got it . There are many fights where I had to go back to get the right skills and come back (which is not always an option) . If you are a casual gamer there is a chance you might get stack because you did not build characters correctly .I am seasond RPG player and this was the most unforgiving game I ever played . -Permadeath on Party Characters-?One of the characters in your party will die ( forever ) This is a scripted event so you won't actually loose party members by diying in combat  . It is kinda cool to see a game have the balls to do that but for obvious reasons not everybody likes that . You can potentially waste some gold by buying equipment for that character ( I think you get it back but sellback value is not the same ) The real problem is that you may waste some of your Skill points thinking that you can rely on this character for a specific role .- Too much Luck -?-In this game Ranged,Melee and Spell attacks have % to hit . Luck is a big factor early on  . Eventually you can upgrade skills high enough to where you will hit 90-100% so it has to do a lot with how you level your characters .Dodging is frustraing early in game but not a fair criticism for RPG because it adds depth to character builds . However there is a luck element to using items from iventory which can be avoided by save/load ( so that mechanic just wastes your time )-Very basic loot System -Loot in this game is not exciting to say the least . You get a 3-7 damage weapon and 10 hours later you get 4-8 weapon .It keeps number values low which is good because it makes fights less gear dependent but I would prefer something better than just common white trash as you would call it in other games .Rewards for Side quests are very unbalanced . Some quest chains can take 2-3 hours and you might get the same reward as the 20 minute quest . There are some specific quests that give uniqe weapons but there is no consistency with legth or difficulty of the mission .I also should address god awful inventory weight system . This game kinda requires you to carry a lot of gear especially toward late game but you never have enough inventory space . Like entire game I was between 90 and 100% full . You constantly have to find items to remove even though you do not have that much junk . -Pros ?- Challenging tactical gameplay Good variety of different stages and objectives Text choices that impact later in game Spells that gain new effect at maximum levelDecent voice acting and some good jokes .Score: 7/10 . I am really enjoying the unpredictable and unforgiving nature of this game . Perhaps it is a bit unfair  to new and casual players but it is fantastic for someone who does not want the game to hold your hand . At full price I would not recommend it to everyone but on sale you should consider picking it up if you like turn based party RPGs .

content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												Known for old-school point & click adventure games such as Deponia and Edna & Harvey, German developer Daedalic took gamers by surprise when releasing Blackguards – a tactical turn-based RPG based on The Dark Eye tabletop ruleset.While the story sells itself as a dark narrative where you play as outlaws, it’s rather cliche and heroic. The Dark Eye ruleset is the true drawing point. While some rules where cut, such as most non-combat talents, it remains a solid and complex (if rather intimidating) classless system, offering ample freedom when creating your character. It’s a joy for hardcore players, but very poorly explained for newcomers. Sadly, the forced party members end up limiting some of your party building possibilities – sometimes even forcing a restart.Blackguards knows its limitations and uses some unconventional design choices to compensate them, betting everything on its battles – cities are presented as simple animated backgrounds with stores and NPCs to talk with, exploration is limited to a 2D world map full of icons, dungeons are but a semi-linear sequence of battles without rest and the story is told via simple cutscenes, with an occasional decision to be made. This leads to an unique “Western Final Fantasy Tactics” feel, and while the game first hours are very linear, it later opens up to a wide range of interesting side-quests.Daedalic’s background as an adventure game developer is felt here in an unusual way. There are no random battles in Blackguards, meaning that every encounter happens in an unique arena specifically designed for it, often with unique challenges or tactical puzzles. There are traps, time limits, holes that spawn enemies, movable and destructible objects, healing orbs, falling chandeliers, mechanical blades, flying dragons, swamp gas, giant tentacles, mind-controlling plants, draw bridges, collapsing passageways, a giant cage on a crane, etc. There’s not a single RPG out there that offers so many interesting combat scenarios. This alone makes Blackguards a must-play for any tactical fan – or RPG designer. Unfortunately, the game stretches out for far too long (40 to 60 hours), and the limited variety of enemies and equipment result in a rather stale second half of the game. Still, fans of Tactical RPGs will have a blast.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												SUMMARY: 8 stars out of 10.  A solid and highly enjoyable RPG!PROLOGUE: I show as having 88 hours playing this game, as of this review.  I probably actually was playing for 80 hours of that, for ONE playthrough. I am methodical and slow, so most of you whippersnappers who like to cut to the chase will likely finish in 40 hours or less.  I saw a lot of complaints about this game having spikes of frustratingly high difficulty, so I played the EASY/NOVICE setting, which I believe gives more Adventure Points (AP) than the other settings.  In retrospect, I can understand the complaints; but I never had that problem, maybe because of the easy setting, maybe for the most part because I pushed off what I suspected would be the tougher fights until I had more skills under my party's belts.  I ended the game with 1300 ducats (enough to ditch EVERYTHING the party needed and buy it all back again), lots of poisons, potions, provisions, projectiles, traps, and other stuff I never seemed to have the need to use.  I used one potion, and that in the second to last battle.  Perhaps on NORMAL difficulty I would have needed more...REVIEW:  This game has a main storyline which is fairly linear, but the available sidequests (and locations they open) make it feel less so.  The RPG character development system is versatile and refreshing: You can mold your characters by earning and using AP to buy levels in any of a myriad of basic traits, talents, weapon talents, special abilities, and (for magic users) spells.  You get AP by fighting battles and completing quests.  You do not get enough AP to turn your characters into super heros; but, if you do most of the sidequests, you will get enough to make them excellent in their chosen specialty (magic, melee, ranged) and solid in a second specialty and/or support.  One word of caution: this is not the game for those who want to destroy waves of hapless foes with giant fire or frost balls.  Using magic to buff teammates (and/or debuff enemies) will carry the day. There are approximately 180 fights available in the game, for those who wish to seek them all out, with plenty of tactical variety and some light "in-fight" puzzle solving.  In all but a few cases, the game clues you in to what is needed to make a fight easier.  For those few where they fall short, there is the internet: I used it about six times.  There were about three fights I elected to replay because I failed or did not like the outcome.  All in all, I found the combat to be satisfying.Some have complained of running out of ammo (the shops do not re-stock arrows and bolts); but I ran two archers and one crossbow, and did not come close to running out.  I think someone relied too heavily on "triple shot" and "rain of arrows," which skills none of my characters learned.The storyline is nothing to write home about; and the ending cutscenes/wrap-up is lackluster.  But the character voice acting, approriate interjection of humor, and plot intrigue that is played out was, in my opinion, quite well done.Replay value is modest.  The plot twists and intrigue are a lot of what pulled me along the first time.  Your party characters are a mandatory set of (up to) five characters, only one of which you get to roll from scratch, and even HIM not entirely (name, gender and appearance are all set for you).  After almost 90 hours on record for my first run, another one (this time on NORMAL) will have to wait until I am up for it.  But, for the pittance I paid for the game (got it on a deep, DEEP discount), one run was overwhemingly worth the price!EPILOGUE / HINTS (which some might consider slightly spoilerish, but I will not give away plot.)-- Screw the game's advice:  Roll your own character from scratch the first time.  It is almost impossible to fail if you buy in as a magic user and start him out good at SOMETHING.-- Take magic, unless you are dead set on a heavy melee fighter.  the 500 AP cost might seem like a lot, but it is a pittance over the course of the game, compared to the advantages it gives.-- Continuing this line of thought, a dedicated heavy melee fighter is probably not the best choice, as you will eventually end up having two excellent ones foisted upon you.  You will be much better served with a magic buffer/healer who is good at bows.-- All your magic users should be good with staffs, or possibly daggers.-- Study spells carefully before trying to achieve high ranks in them.  For most spells, level 4 is not worth the cost.-- Hammer Blow (HB), coupled with level 3 "Standfast Catlike" buff is OP.-- The level 3 buff "Move like Lightning" (or some name llike that) is OP.-- A fighter simultaneously buffed with level 3 Lightning and Standfast, and also using HB, is beyond OP for most fights.

Posted: June 23, 2014
												The map and so-called adventure choices are little beyond token, though correctly executed. The story is very classic but does have a couple of courageous twists that deserve credit.Beyond the game system that you of course have to like or not (I do), the main highlights are:1) map design, creative and varied with many fun environment elements;2) difficulty: the game is very challenging at the highest difficulty level and keeps getting harder as you progress toward the last act (die you ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ plant, die). Some maps or quests are quite tough and you'll need to use all you can to deal with the sheer brutality of special enemies. That's very refreshing from the usual strategy game curve (mildly difficult beginning to mid-game then disappointingly easy as your characters get IMBA).The interface is neat and even rather classy.All in all, quite a nice game if you're into the system.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 10
												Blackguards is a turn based RPG game. A very difficult, very unforgiving one. The backbone of the game is made up by the Dark Eye system, a system similar to DnD and (from what I understand) very popular in Germany. I've played  alot of DnD, and read a lot about the game's system and guides before playing Blackguards, but didn't really feel like it made much of a difference. The RNG is very unforgiving, in that if your characters' builds are not razor optimized, you will have an incredibly difficult time with the game, more than it already is. I STRONGLY suggest looking at character guides and just following one to the T in terms of what are good skills, what are must haves, where to put your points, and the like, as it is very easy to render a character effectively useless in a battle as you continue to invest points in skills.Damage and  status efects stay with characters after fights, and consumables are in relatively short supply, meaning strings of fights become very dicey. Magic casting runs off of the same RNG as the melee attacks do, so it's possible to cast spells, have them fizzle entirely, but still lose mana - very frustrating since you then need to use one of your limited resources in money or mana potions to get them back to the point to where they can even begin to be useful again - or so you hope.These difficulties in learning the games system will unfortunately turn people away from what is a very enjoyable and very think-y turn based combat game. Almost every single individual map is handcrafted and presents new challenges to the party, and the game often forces you to use various party members in different compositions: Aggravating if you chose to focus on one in particular, but from a game design standpoint, if executed well lets you offer all sorts of new challenges. The problem lies in the game's very punishing permanent levellnig system. With no way to undo bad choices and mistakes (and don't be fooled: there ARE mistakes and just bad choices you can make in character builds), you might be stuck at a fight you now have no way of winning, fifteen hours into the campaign.The story is not particularly interesting, in my opinion, but I have played  alot of very intensely narrative focused games so I admit my bar may be set a little bit high. The characters are interesting, and it's fun to see a story told from the perspective of sly ne'er-do-wells rather than heroic caricatures. Unfortunately, I never really felt like anything groundbreaking or innovative was really done with the characters or situations they could have used, and instead it just sort of became background set up fora relatively generic story that could have been done with the more "Usual Suspects" of heroic characters.Ironically, I garnered the most fun from the game when my frustration was at its peak and I simply used Cheat Engine to level my characters to the max immediately, giving myself essentially unlimited skill points and ability points to make the characters I actually wanted to make. Due to the punishing RNG and the thoughtful, puzzle-y situations the game likes to put you in, in every single combat, this takes less of the challenge out of the game than you might immediately think (it DOES make it much easier, of course.). Your mileage may vary, but for someone that wants to experience the combat system and the story, i would actually recommend just cheat engining your characters to max level and giving them all the skills you want them to have, and then enjoy using them in the varied combat situations the games put you in.In the end, I give the game a thumbs down - but only because I think the game's opaqueness and difficulty in learning the system is such a a negative that many people will feel immediately turned off by a combinatioin of that and the game's innate difficulty that they'll be unable to enjoy the game for its positive sides.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												I bought the game on sale last week because I never really played a turn-based RPG before and wanted to give this genre a try. As it wasn't too expensive it seemed like a choice without too many risks. I never heard of the game before and didn't read up on any tips to be able to start with a clear and unbiased spirit.So far I have to admit I am really enjoying it. The story, characters and global setting don't appeal that much too me, although everything is more than correct. The story isn't that special, but forms the perfect background for the many fights I encountered so far.And it's in this domain that the game really shines for me. Every fight (or almost every) I had so far really left some room for your own tactic. At the very start of the game I was a bit overwhelmed by the turn-based approach (as I  never played it before), but after a while you really get the hang of it. I like the fact that you have to think about the placement of every character aswell as which attack to use. The fact that it's turn-based also allows you to really plan your next move. Some fights were challenging, but I never got the feeling that it isn't fair so far.I also really appreciate the fact that you can upgrade and shape your characters as you like it. The game allows you to create your party like YOU want to play it.I only spent about 6 hours in the game so far, but I am sure many more will follow.

												Some decent ideas let down by painfully bad design. The writing and voice acting are decent, and there are some interesting RPG concepts, but the game is centred around an unbalanced combat system. It is so heavily dependant on RNG, and yet many battles are determined by a few key actions - fail the RNG on those, and you may as well re-start the battle. As such, it simply becomes a frustrating exercise in repetition and luck.There may be some good content here, but it's trapped behind some ill-considered mechanics.

												When I started to play the game I was surprised that it have so many negative reviews, it looked like a very good game at the beginning, but then its flaws bacame evident.pros: -good storyline-interesting side quests-huge freedom on character development-decent graphic-interesting combat system-interesting magic/abilitiescons:-freedom on character development can turn against you later in the game. there's no clue on which way you should get skills and abilities and you can come across certains fights where you absolutely need a certain skill to win or it will take a lot of luck. this is quite frustrating. expecially if you don't have a savegame old enought to learn the ability you need.-inventory items are uninteresting: you only get good stuff from a few side quest in the entire game, merchants around the world only sell cheap/bad stuff. also I think the weight of the stuff (especially supplies) is unbalanced.-major and minor bugs could prevent you from completing some side-quests-unnecessary loading timesin the end I can recomend this game only if you are a turn based rpg enthusiast.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												This is great fun, and particularly recommended if you're looking for a less daunting, more linear story-driven turn-based RPG. It's perfect for busy people who perhaps have less time for too-open and deep an experience: - Fairly linear, especially for the first half of the game (it opens out a little in Chapter 3, but even here it is still really just about having some choice about what order you do the quests and fights).- Great story, with a central mystery, and lots of believable twists and turns; it takes you to lots of interesting locations and has you meet a range of engaging characters.  - Good voice acting nearly throughout - only a few weaker performances. The main heroes and villains are all voiced very well. - Some great characters, such as Zuraban, the womanising socialite, Niam, the drug-addicted lost soul or the gold-loving dwarf. These may be fantasy archetypes, but the interaction between them often takes you to new territory, and is often funny. - Fairly deep (but not TOO complicated!) skill tree and leveling up system.  - Good turn-based combat, and challenging if played on Hard. The only criticism I have so far is that there seem to be just a few areas that are a little unpolished - for example, you can skill up you 'traps' detection and disarming ability, only to discover that there is no actual mechanic to allow you to disarm traps. And yes, I've searched the forums! In the end, there are other ways around it, so it's no biggie!

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												TL/DR at the bottom.Save Your Games Often. SYGO.Lore: This games has a great story, or maybe just a good one, but with great soundtrack. Every time the action stops to give me some of the story, be it only with voice over or with a cinematic, it makes me feel like sitting back, dimming the light, lighting up a cigar (I don't smoke cigars, wtf) and just getting immersed in that world. It works. Oh and SYGO.Graphics: Every graphics outside of the spells and backdrops are ok for a turn-based strategy game, cinematics or gameplay. The backdrops are nice. But the spells are one notch above that. They are cool. Let just say that after 80 hours, I'd gladly skip the crossbow animation in order to save 4 seconds every time, but I'd keep the spells any day of the week. Gameplay: I recommend you name your character SYGO. I didn't. I should have. Now I need to restart from scratch. Don't just SYGO. Keep them. You'll need them. This game is unforgiving as it leads you to think that you'll need this skill and that skill in order to make it, yet it surprises you (too) many times with different tactics and resistance to particular damage. If you can finish this game without a single hint from the internet, a walkthrough or without ever needing to backtrack yourself once to change some skill points (let alone back track yourself 40 hours to change almost everything...) you are a God amongst humans. TL/DR: One of the best turn-based game I've played, as enjoyable as your favorite HOMM or Civ. Poor DLC value, very good base value. If you don't want a good challenge (60 hours) that kinda forces you into restarting at least once the game from scratch (do I hear 120 hours?), then this might not be for you. Only negative thing is that I'm really dissapointed that the dev made a Blackguards 2 instead of adding more than one DLC to this game. Did I mentioned SYGO? Yeah, SYGO. Or cry. Like the people that wrote bad reviews for this game. They didn't SYGO. Clearly. But you will, right?

content:
Posted: December 9, 2016
												So having finally finished the game, time for a quick review. Is it worth buying?Eh, just about. It's regularly on sale for £2 or £3, and I got 70hrs out of it, so on that basis you'd be a whiny little ♥♥♥♥♥ to complain. Is it any good?Eh, just about. It's a classic TBS affair. The storyline's OK, but gets kinda convoluted throughout the game so by the end, you've pretty much lost the plot and stopped caring. Something to do with a Whisper...? Anyway. One big plus is the characters and writing. They're generally a likeable bunch and have good banter between them, and often their conversations raise a chuckle.Progress is extremely limited - you won't be working your way up through half a dozen better and better sets of gear as you progress: in fact, once you've got a complete set by around chapter 2, you can pretty much forget about upgrading any more. So if you're a loot junky and love waiting for the loot windows at the end of every fight to see what shiny new gear your heroes are getting, you'll be disappointed.Having said that, if you simply enjoy the basics of TBS combat and love moving your guys around a hexboard and using your new skills/spells to smash zombies in the face, you'll enjoy yourself.OverallIt's not the best TBS out there, but it's not awful. The thrill fades throughout the game so towards the end finishing it off becomes as much a chore as a pleasure, but at 90% off there's no reason TBS fans shouldn't have it in their library.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												Much like Baldur’s Gate II, Oblivion, Dishonored, The Witcher II, and countless other fantasy and action games before it, Blackguards begins with the player character sobering up in a dingy dungeon. Said dungeon is especially mildew-y and uninspired, packed with boring old barred cells and dirt floors.Then the player meets a wizard with a voice so melodramatic and overacted that some will likely be put off the game almost immediately.But to strike off the game due to its weak opening alone would be shame, as Blackguards grows gradually into its own strategic combat system, and presents colourful and fantastical confrontations that escalate nicely as the game progresses.Blackguards is a turn-based RPG at heart, based within the universe and roleplaying system of enduring German Dungeons & Dragons-alike The Dark Eye. The story is simple and functional: the player character has been convicted of the murder of a noble’s daughter, with whom he or she was a close friend.Towns consist of little more than painted landscapes populated with stationary NPCs that can be clicked to begin a sparse dialogue tree.There’s no overworld to navigate, merely a series of interconnected nodes on a map. Building a game on the back of a pre-existing RPG has pros and cons, and perhaps because of its hardcore tabletop roots, the levelling and character progression system in Blackguards is immediately intimidating.The combat is easy to understand on a basic level. A player can move and use an action, or cover a greater distance by sacrificing an action. The number of actions that can be performed, including spells and attacks, quickly broaden the combat system into a rich tapestry of decisions.That combat is absolutely the core of Blackguards, both in a gameplay and aesthetic sense.An early assault of brown and grey doesn’t do it any favours, but the presence of large numbers of well-animated on-screen characters later on certainly do. The spell effects are similarly excellent, and there are some creative and terrifying monster designs.There may not be an overworld, and the friendly towns found in most RPGs are absent, but Blackguards does possess an extremely well-developed core combat system, and for that it deserves to be commended.Overall 7/10.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												I enjoyed this game (hence the recommendation) but I really must caveat this, because this game is a cruel mistress.Pros and cons as follows, because how much each point sways you will govern how much you get out of this game. On the whole I enjoyed it.Pros:- Funny dialogue and interesting characters. Naurim might be the greatest character in Western RPG history- Deep strategy. There are lots of environment effects, ways to optimise and spells to learn.- Good voice acting. Genuinely good and a nice array of accents. Apart from the main characters female voice- Dark, gritty artistic direction. Few games capture being and anti-hero so well, with murky non-binary decision making- Challenge. Good god the challenge.Cons-  It's a bit... broken. Little things that seem to have been left incomplete, or lack polish. This includes a few bugs with quests and achievements. A good example is that the combat controls list auto-save, but if you try to use it, the game says you can't.- Not explaining things. Sometimes you will see environmental effects or objects, but have no idea what they are or do until they kill you. Sometimes it will drop you in a level with a special win condition, but it won't be clear what it is. This is fine once you work it out, but causes a bit of trial-and-error frustration- The ending is, well, balls. Quite simply. There are apparently multiple endings, but to me the last chapter and ending felt a bit rushed.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												   Let me preface this by saying this game is definitely not for everyone. The story is terrible imo, and there is lack of documentation about the ruleset within the game. So good luck if you mess up your build early in the game (some talents and spells are useless). But, if you can get around those two factors, there is a nice TBRPG here.  Blackguards strength is easily its combat. Difficulty of encounters is not determined by the number of enemies nor the amount of hp they have but by the types of enemies and the environmental hazards on the map. Hell, even increasing the difficulty actually makes the AI smarter instead of having cheap mechanics like OHKOs.  For a first time RPG developer, Daedalic did a suprisingly good job. Unfortunately, Daedelic didn't just decide to make a better Blackguards 1 when making the sequel.

Posted: February 24, 2016
												A frustrating, boring mess. This is very hard on new players hoping to learn the genre, and will sit you through painfully tedious repeats of battle scenarios and loading earlier saves if you're not experienced or running through without a guide. It actively discourages tactical creativity at times, and I've found through research that some spells and approaches to the game are just blatantly optimal and better than others. Play the "meta" way, or good luck.Beyong that, the plot, characters and voice acting are all sub-par and uninspired. All I can give praise to are the environments and animations, which look great but don't exactly generate fun on their own. I really tried to like this game with 20+ hours of playthrough. I'd hoped I would find the fun in all that time, but sadly I didn't.

content:
Posted: February 4
												OK; I've just spent a couple of days playing this game, and I think I'm about ready to turn in my verdict.Pros: - Interesting storyline; - Decent(ish) combat engine; - Some downright funny moments.Cons: - Opaque combat mechanics (i.e., lack of walkthrough, ingame pedia or other assistance to help understand these numbers getting crunched); - Zurbaran is USELESS *sadface*; - The. Baroness. OMG, the Baroness....where to start. The bonus objective is only achieveable if you've looked up where the traps are placed - and that's just to start! - Siege of Morbal. Nothing ticks one off quite like pushing ahead, winning a tough battle....then, as you're winning, having a rock fall on two characters' heads at once, taking them entirely out of the fight arbitrarily! - No "RP" in "RPG" - it's a combat grinder, little more. There are hints of an interesting story, but no background, no dialogue, no choices....Overall, Blackguards feels very, very old-school (think JRPG from the mid-90s, but darker and edgier) - 2014 was better than this! Would not recommend unless on significant discount...

content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
Blackguards Review Overall Score: 6/10  Storyline: (1/2) + Fun dialogues to read between characters.- Bad storyline (I don't see it going anywhere besides a basic story of the advanture itself). Graphics: (2/2) + Well designed character models and gears.+ Good looking battle maps and towns. Sounds: (2/2) + Voices matching the characters.+ Good sounds in battlemaps and overall. Gameplay: (3/4) + Easy and basic training progress to let you understand the game rules and mechanics.+ Main and Side Quests (Each quest is intresting because it gives rewards and you never know who the enemy is and how many there are).+ Visit each town and meet Blacksmiths/Healers/Merchants etc.. (Inventory/cash is usefull)- Difficulties: It's good to have 3 level of difficulties but we need to understand the difference between each one because it feels hard even on Easy for a new player in Blackguards. RolePlay Elements: (4/7) + Different Classes (Hunter/Mage/Fighter)+ Rich variety of equippment (Weapons/Armor Sets/Items to use on A.I/self/enemy)+ Happy Mage (A full page of spells only for the mage)- Special Moves for other characters (You're able to unlock them with a trainer.. But I'm reaching 15 hours and I still haven't found this 'trainer' yet.+ Talents : A sweet bonus in this game which let you upgrade each talent form level 1 to 5 and give you it's special effect [see below]*Knockdown resistance *Animals/Humans stats detector *Healing Effect * Traps detector and more...+- Stats : There are good sides and bad sides about the stats because in one hand you can match the stats to your likingif you want a spellcaster archer or a dual wielding warrior but if you don't know what you upgrade to your character you might have a weaker character than you've expected.- Equippment stats are a bit clumsy.- Upgrade Points: It takes more time than it should be for a player to think about where to invest his upgrade points. Combat: (4/5) + Each combat is exciting and makes you eager for the next one.+ Basic turn-based combat rules/moves but more challenging then other TB games.+ Usefull Objects : You can throw weapons on the enemy, use/disable traps , use battle objects to move them around or use them against the enemy. You can even hide in the bush from the enemy.+ Satisfaction : For those 100% players, you will re-do the battle until you get it done the best way you want it to be.- Frustration : In some battles I felt like my characters are over powered by the enemy. Had to re-try multiply times in different tactics.To sum it up, I'm enjoying my new Turn Based experience with Blackguards.It offers an addictive experience throughout the game so I recommend on trying this game if you're an experienced TB gamer.Don't bother playing this if you're more of a classic TB gamer who doesn't want to focus much on character's stats and RPG elements that might confuse you along the way.You're more than welcome to also check my screenshots for this game [link below] to see what this game has to offer.http://steamcommunity.com/id/xDMikeW2k14/screenshots/?appid=249650&sort=newestfirst&browsefilter=myfiles&view=imagewallEnjoyment: (6/10)Repetetive: (2/10)Replayability (8/10)Frustraiton (5/10)Boredom (5/10)Overall Score: 6/10* Skip it.** Not Recommended.*** Give It A Try.**** Recommended On Sale.****** Recommended On Full Price.Thanks for reading.

												Ok I'm done. Got in to a decent start and I thought the game is alright. But then came the baroness rescue. Tried to bang my head against the impossible for several hours. Gave up. In terms of making a game challenging, it has to be executed in some different way than throwing you into an impossible situation which requires basically every dice roll to go on your favor in a maximum way. Otherwise, reload and against the same situation again, and again, and again, and again, and again, and again, and again, and again. Nuff said? Yeah. Killed all the fun for me. Luckily I got this game with a 90% discount and got a few hours of pretty decent fun. It's a terrible shame really, it would've been interesting to dwell deeper into the storyline. The characters seemed pretty interesting with their personalities. Oh well, now I'm off to uninstall this piece of garbage.

Yea the unbeliever might do the math and sayeth he that 75% chance to hit means there is only a 1 in 4 chance to miss, but blaspheme not so! For the lord will punish ye all the way through to 95% chance to hit. Ye shall miss as certain as ye have bound the quick load/save to ye mouse buttons." -Numbers 1:20.

Posted: January 27, 2014
												This is the worst game i have played in  long time.  Story is linear and boring.  it's cut scene after cut scene forcing you thr4ough the story interupted but completely unbalanced fights.  i have a dwarf in the game who wields a two handed hammer, and i cant hit an unarmoured wizard, on top of that when i do land a blow, the wizard deals more damage to me with his melee attack.  so the mechanics are sort of broken and frustrating.  It is ultimately a bad story mixed with crappy game mechanics (BTW i am playing on normal).  There is no exploration into the game.  i have played 10+ hours worth so far.  just go hear kill this go hear kill that, save this maiden, do this task.  etc...  If you decide you want to gain some xp before you move forward so the game doesnt kill you very easily you do not have an option.  you have to crank the diff down to easy and then it becomes boring and dull with no real challenge.So the two options i found where ridiculously hard and non sensical (wizard does more melee damage than a two handed melee weilding dwarf)or easy and equivelant to pressing play on a bad fantasy movie every now and again to get the story going.  i would not recomend this game to anyone, especially not for $40.  I love turn based fantasy games.  grew up on the dark sun TSR games, baldurs gate, and way back to hero quest in the late 80's.  so it's definetely up my alley.

Posted: December 21, 2015
												Dungeons and Dragons meets Xcom. Instead of running from cover to cover, you use your environment to set traps, set oil puddles on fire, or gain health at a fountain. It's the best way to mix the two ideas.Gameplay-wise, it's too slow in my taste, and it shouldn't cost my character's turn to change weapons or activate a switch; it's tedious. The leveling-up system is overwhelming, and it is too easy to make mistakes while managing your XP spendings. Be warned: XP is a limited ressource and there is no possible grinding. Also, There are some ridiculously difficult fights spiking about. If the game design wasn't all over the place, it wouldn't be an option to change the difficulty whenever I want.It's not bad, but there's better out there. It's a really hardcore experience and I'm not a big fan of D&D. I had crashes and had to reload some games. The achievements are stupid : waste your XP everywhere, use an inn 50 times, run in a circle (not a joke)

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												TL;DR: If you like a game of chance, play roulette. If you like RPGs, buy a real RPG, if you like tactical combat, buy XCOM. But dont buy Blackguards.After 10 hours of playing the game, the game is simply over for me. I am stuck at an impossible fight, the autosave is at a point were I cannot make any meaningful alterations to who fights anymore. And the fight is unwinable with the character I build.Now, dont get me wrong. Its not a badly build character. Its a very straightforward mage. Its not underleveled either for I did every single quest so far. But if your character is a mage, and you dont build it in one very specific way, you will be stuck at the beginning of chapter 2. It is impossible to progress, since there are no potions or pieces of mage armor available so you usually just get one-shot.Unfortunately, this happens quite often in Blackguards. The game is not balanced - at all. You can in theory build a character, but if you build anything other than a fighter or a very specific mage, you just get stuck in impossible fights - like the one that ended my game.I had fights like this before, and I got through them by just reloading for two hours until the RNG finally turned into my favor.  Here is an example:In one fight, turn one, my main character would get shot and fall on his♥♥♥♥♥about 90% of the time. That means the fight is over - I lacked the DPS to win and he would just continually be shot down. There is nothing you can do against this either. You cannot prepare for fights - all spells etc. can only cast once you are IN the fight. So right away 9/10 cases, I had to reload. If my character managed to dodge, I now had to get a very specific spell of to make sure he wont get shot down every single time. However, the spell barely ever got used so it failed in 3/10 cases. If it failed, reload.So right away I could only progress in 3% of the cases. Of course the rest of the fight also included a lot of luck.Sure with a different character build that wouldnt have happened - but if the game is only beatable with some very specific builds than either dont give the players the option to build their characters, or rebalance the fights.This is the main problem of Blackguards - the game is not skillbased, its largely RNG. That means that dicerolls decide outcomes of fights, not your skill or ingenuity. This makes the whole experience hugely frustrating. And its not frustrating in a good way. In Dark Souls, it is extremely frustrating but you know its your fault, and if you get good enough, if you finally figure all the patterns out, you beat it, and its awesome. In Blackguards, you beat a frustrating fight and the only thing you feel is 'finally its over'. Because its not skill that won the fight, its just that for pure random chance the dice have fallen in your favor. Almost every fight in the game is like this. The few fights that arent usually have a very simple to figure out environmental danger that you have to activate in order to basically get a free win.Until this game actually gets balanced, dont buy it.

number of helpful: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												While Blackguards has interesting characters, visually appealing backdrop and a good amount of character customisation. It is linear in nature like most tactical RPGs, it is still engaging enough to keep you playing.What could of been an exceptional tactical RPG, is heavilly mared by the skewerd RNG.  Enemies with ludecrously low hit chances will regularly hit, while your group with ludecriously high chances to hit will miss quite often.  This simply plays out this way the entire game.Many of the enemy hits will impose effects but you wont resist them because of penalites of unknown oragin making the skills you developed to resist them, meaningless.  Likewise Enemies will constantly resist your statuses because aparently you dont apply the same penalities to them.This would be fine for the most part if enemies did similare damage to your group, sadly they typically will almost always do about 50% more, leaving you to scratch your head wondering why.  In general enemies will always be better than or equal to your group in combat, even if they happen to be some merchant or alchemist they will be exceptional warriors none the less.  They also wont give you the gear they are using (aparently that vanishes in a puff of smoke when they die)Again this woud be fine through the use of tactics.  However the RNG issues will often destroy the best tactics you can bring to the table.Plenty of places have traps everywhere and the non-enviromental ones will let the enemies happilly walk over with without triggering them.At the end of the day unless you are happy to ignore the RNG issues and vague information on many of the combat aspects, I cant really recomened Blackguards (hopefully the second one has improved those issues).   Even then best to get it on a 75% off sale.

number of helpful: 14 of 23 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												Hello!  This is a game that seems to have nearly a 50/50 split on good and bad comments/reviews.  I've been working through a fairly long LP of this game and I figure that I probably should weigh-in as well.  I am 100% for this game and I'll list the reasons why down below.  I'll give a short version and a long version for those that want it.  If anyone is interested in seeing a bit more of how the game plays out before picking it up, or just wants to enjoy my struggles and successes, feel free to check it out.


YouTube™ Video: Let's Play Blackguards - Ep. 1 - Hungry Like The Wolf! 

			Views: 1,249		

			If you are a fan of tactical turn-based RPG's and an amazing story, look no further than Blackguards. The game starts off quite terrifying and more or less sets the mood for the rest of the game.		

or for any of my other games:https://www.youtube.com/bumpymcsquigumsShort version:Blackguards is a tactical, squad-based, turn-based rpg.  The story is very funny at times and quite dark throughout.  You have quite a bit of freedom in regards to how to train your party, what equipment, skills and abilities each person should have.  You are on a linear path, but there is freedom in that as well.  There is, of course, the main quest line to advance the story, (which I find rather entertaining, it's funny, but also dark) and there are several side quests that you CAN do, or miss.  (I missed a few)  There are some things I don't like, (RNG makes things rough and a few multiple battles means one bad decision early can be terrible for you) but overall those can be overcome and dealt with.  I recommend saving often, as I SHOULD have been doing all along.  Still, I think this is by far one of the best games in the tactical, squad-based, turn-based rpg games I've played in a long time.  I really don't understand all the negativity towards the game.  :(The Long Version:Blackguards is a tactical, squad-based, turn-based rpg.  The story is very funny at times and quite dark throughout. :)The Good:The pacing of the game is fun and very enjoyable and this IS one of the longer games of it's type that I've played in recent memory.  The fact that there's more to the battles than just your attacks/skills/spells abilities is a very refreshing change. Now, I love X-COM and I know this game catches some comparison to it, but even in the different missions in X-COM you pretty much just killed all the aliens.  There's different objectives in battle as well as usable/destroyable terrain.  Sometimes you might have to rush across a bridge to save someone within "x" number of turns.  Maybe you are escaping from prison and you can fight the guards, or free other prisoners to fight them off for you.  There's usually several ways to achieve the goal and they add enough different things to keep you guessing AND make it entertaining.    You are part of a story. so the linear gameplay makes sense.  There are flashbacks and you learn pretty quickly what all is going on, well for the most part.  There's still a lot you need to discover, but the story is well written even if it's a bit cheesey at times and overly dark at others.  The voice acting is quite a bit better than I would have expected.  I personally think they did an exceptional job in this department.  The music and graphics are also very well done.The different characters you can pick up for your party all play pretty differently.  The nice thing is you DO have a say in all of their training/gear/abilities after what they have initially.  A mage plays very different from a warrior, who plays very different from an archer.  One of the things I did was had a third mage like character and transitioned her into an archer as I lost my archer a bit earlier on.  So she can use a bow decently well and has spells to fall back on.  I think 90% of the battles are pretty balanced, but every so often you get a battle that just makes you think and rethink your strategy 100 times over before you get it.  The game is unique, I haven't seen anything quite like this before.  The concept isn't so different from a lot of other games, but the setting, the story, even just the idea of having a group of misfits, criminals, drug-addicts as the "heroes"is fairly different from the norm.I could go on and on about the "good" of the game, but I want to address the few issues that I have come across that you may want to know about.  It's a very good game, but nothing is perfect.  :)The Bad : (or Frustrating if you will)The RNG can be exceptionally frustrating at times and bad decisions can bring you to a screeching halt.  I don't recommend "save scumming" but I DO recommend saving often, as there are many multiple battles with no way to back out.  There were a few times that I ran into a battle that I made a bad decision in the fight before it and it cost me quite a few stressful attempts to survive.  I have also fought a few battles without really changing my tactics and only managed to win because RNG (Randon Number Generations, i.e. Luck) was in my favor.  One fight in particular that I fought 4 times or more, I did MINOR changes but it really came down to my person not missing as much.  In all  honesty, this is really the only BAD thing.  Now, if I had chosen a different team setup in the previous fight, it probably would have been easier. Some of the other "Bad" things in the game would be more about personal preferences.  I personally play both open world games as well as linear.  Some people hate linear games.  I don't mind it as I find the story is usually tighter, better told and more memorable in the linear games.  You have less "distractions".  You have a main quest line you have to follow and it advances the story.  You can't do stuff from chapter 5 in chapter 1.  There are several side quests however and you can do those whenever you feel like each chapter.  I skipped a few or missed a few in chapter 1 as I wasn't 100% sure which was which.  There's no free-roaming, it's towns, points of interests, people of interests that you click on a map and throughout the cities.    So it's the world map, town maps, area maps, or the battle map you deal with.  Again, I don't mind it, but some people will.You have only 3 choices for your main character.  Archer, Warrior, Mage (not sure what "specific" names they give those classes).  However, you have a lot of freedom on how you want to train your character and the members of your party.  The game slowly teaches you how to play, so it may start a bit slow with all the tutorial messages popping up, but the tutorial DOES do a good job at teaching you what you need to know.  Occasionally the camera angles can be a bit annoying or cumbersome, but it's not much of an issue overall.It might seem like there's a lot bad here, but in reality it's just a lot of detail.  Most of which is personal preference or it limits you....only a little, but again, some people hate any limitations.  Bottom Line:The game is very fun, and makes you think.  You will breeze through some fights and then just hang your head in shame in others.  You have a set path to follow, but you can take several side streets along the way and the ride is very enjoyable.  I really really like Blackguards and I recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of Tactical, squad-based, turn-based strategy rpg games.  It has a few problems, but the good outweighs the bad by a landslide.  This is a shining gem from Daedalic Entertainment, well....a Darkly Shining Gem!  Check it out!

content:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												I understand the negative reviews. The ruleset is complicated, and even more jarring perhaps to those used to D&D attributes and rules. That is why you should do as the game suggests and play on Normal difficulty and use the Basic (pre-made) character if it is your first time and unfamiliar to The Dark Eye. That's exactly what I did, and by the time I play a second time, I'll know enough of this convoluted system to choose a different class and choose my own stats.It's a really fun strategy RPG, with an emphasis placed on usable objects on the battlefield, and unique battle maps. Every fight seems to have a "hook" to it. You will, however, spend hours looking at the manual, in-game tutorial and rules menu, and ultimately guides to explain what the hell is REALLY going on.Talent modifiers to aid failed skill checks; Damage types as diverse and odd as Infantry, Piercing, Fire, Bashing and Magic (No, there is fire magic, it's just, well, the system is weird, OK); 3 separate attribute checks just to cast one spell; finally figuring out what the ♥♥♥♥ Armor Rating and Encumbrance really mean. This is for all the true OGs of CRPGs.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2016
												This is a pretty fun game.  There are a lot of looading pages, and even though the game auto saves before and after a battle, it is best to make your own save file. If you loose a battle, and the game reloads, it will autosave again, and unless you have your own save file, you'll be stuck in an endless loop until you succeed, and sometimes those battles weren't ment to be entered yet. The voiceacting is actually pretty welldone. I was suprised. The art is decent, the story thus far is very predictable, but still enjoyable. There's lots of side quests you can complete. It seems to be a good idea to do them, just to get the experience and the points to spend on spells, and abilities. Makes the game a little easier, and allows for more battle options. I'm not a fan of the buying system. There's seems to be a limited number of arrows. After buying all of them in a shop, it seems they don't restock. I've come back to shops after many battles to see if they resupply, but it doesn't seem they do. The potion prices are rediculous. Though you shouldn't need them very often. There is a little bit of a freedom  aspect. At a certain point you can choose where you want to go, and dialog options give you different results. You can choose which side to be on in some battles. I give the game a 6/10. It's nothing special, but I do enjoy playing the game.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												Have you ever played Dungeons and Dragons with a Dungeon Master that absolutely hates you? Do you like campaigns in which dialogue options are almost meaningless and the plot is confusing? Well if you haven't, Blackguards can fill that void for you. The plot isn't bad. It captured my attention fairly early and has some nice twists in it. The main focus of this game, however, is the combat system. I love the combat in this game. Blackguards uses a version of tabletop rules to fuel its combat. There are even simulated dice rolls for damage and hit chance. Unfortunately, (or fortunately depending) pretty much every dialogue option leads to some sort of cliche combat. Very rarely is there a non-combat solution to anything. The character creation is pretty cool also. There are two modes; basic and advanced. The creation is very open and is manipulated by AP (adventure points (I think)). Using these points (earned from combat and completion of quests), you can add talents, special abilities, spells, and basic attributes to your character, none being restricted to your character (except spells in some cases). Unfortunately, this game does have some downsides. Some of the encounters are downright frustrating and (at least for me), very difficult. A number of times I've had to walk away from the game or take a break. These particular encounters seem to me generated specifically to be hard and not at all story oriented. I won't go into much detail about them so I don't spoil the "fun" for you. On the plus side however, there is no penalty for losing as the game forces you to keep trying unless you load a previous save before the encounter.The graphics are actually quite nice and are better than I expected. The layout for combat is excellent, using hex-tiles and a partially destructible environment. The cities however seem more like pretty backdrops for my character sheets and are fairly dull. I would recommend this game if you are an avid tabletop gamer looking for your D&D fix, or someone who appreciates tabletop games.7.5/10
