number of helpful: 10 of 16 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												Blackguards is a turn-based strategy game with deep RPG elements based on the popular German pen and paper RPG The Dark Eye. You assume the role of your own custom character who is accused of killing the princess in the opening cinematic. Your only choice is to run away, assemble a cast of shady characters such as the suave mage Zurbaran, the feisty dwarf Naurim and the tribal warrior Takate. The storytelling and the characters are solid, but they really don’t stand out in any significant way, for the most part it really feels like a poor man’s BioWare story.What makes Blackguards truly shine are its great combat system and wonderful game world. The combat system is hex based and may at first remind you of fantasy turn-based strategy games such as Heroes of Might and Magic or King’s Bounty. In reality, it’s more like a combination of Disciples III and Neverwinter Nights, a heavy mixture of classic turn-based strategy and role-playing philosophy. The fantastic thing about the combat system is that every single battlefield is completely unique. Not only are they all different from a visual standpoint, but they are all set up differently as well. Sometimes you’re surrounded, sometimes you have multiple goals, sometimes you have to defend something. You can also use the environment to your advantage. Cut the rope to make the heavy wooden chandelier fall on your foes or burn down the walkway spiderwebs causing deadly poisonous spiders fall to their doom.Another big thing different from usual turn-based strategy games is that you’re not building an army, you have a party of up to five characters. As you progress through the game, you acquire adventure points which you can use to upgrade your characters in a wide variety of attributes, abilities, spells, talents and weapon talents. It’s a really robust system that allows for truly deep customization and experimentation. The only negative thing is that the game assumes that you’re familiar with The Dark Eye ruleset when in reality you will need some time to really figure it out.The other problem stemming from the use of The Dark Eye ruleset is that almost any attack can be a hit or miss. Because the game is really tough and the opening battles are rather grueling, it can be really frustrating missing a 95% attack. There are ways to upgrade your characters to offset this, but again, this will take some time to figure out as the game doesn’t really explain much of anything. This can cause some really ugly bouts of frustration and anger, but it’s not a deal breaker.The vast majority of the gameplay is in the battles. Apart from that, you’ll be using a lovely 2D map to travel from location to location. Towns are represented with a single screen depicting various points of interest such as shops, healers, blacksmiths and quests. The graphics are absolutely beautiful, the wonderful art style is sort of a mixture between fantasy, medieval Spain and 16th century Caribbean which is actually seldom seen in games. The accompanying soundtrack reflects that as well and fits the game very well. However, the animations aren’t that great and the voice work, while mostly solid, can be a bit cringe-worthy at times.Blackguards is a hardcore game for hardcore gamers and it is completely unapologetic about it. So be prepared for some truly grueling stuff and a steep learning curve. The great thing is, it’s absolutely worth playing thanks to the great combat system, deep RPG elements and a wonderful game world.8 OUT OF 10 (GREAT)

number of helpful: 11 of 18 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												I've played this game for nine hours and it has been punctuated by frustration, confusion, and boredom.Not let me be clear right off the top, I've played a lot of tabletop RPGs but never the system used in this game, and when I played I kicked it to "Easy" right off the top.I'm looking for an enjoyable experience with some good story but I don't have the time to waste with hardcore difficulty.So if you're looking for a hardcore review from a guy who loves hardcore tactical RPGs you'll be dissipointed.My first problem with the game is that even after nine hours in the game I don't know the characters. I have no idea who my character is, what he's done, or if there's any reasoning behind anything I've ran across thus far.The other heroes are so painfully one note it's not even funny. The dwarf is quite possibly insane and is hunting a dragon (which may or may not be real). The mage is a scholor but mostly a well spoken man♥♥♥♥♥. The elf is a drug addict who owes people money. Oh, and has an injured sister.Most of that stuff is what I learned about them in the first five minutes of their appearing and nothing has changed.The story isn't much better. After nine hours I've discovered that we're trying escape capture and figure out what's going on.Which is pretty much where I was ten minutes in. It's just going too slow to really get invested in anything.The second problem is the combat.I will conceed that they did a nice job of varying the maps and throwing in varying maps with different enviromental hazards.Unfortunatly that's about all of the nice things I can say. After nine hours I had access to nearly no abilities to play with, a limited number of spells worth using.Fights for me basically went "Warriors power attack, mage fire bolts"Most of the fights feel like I wont mostly because I had more HP than they did rather than any tactical considerations.And since most of the fights feel the same, the combat quickly feels very much like a grind.Which is ironic because grinding is something you can't do intentionally.Combat only happens during missions and subquests. So you can't build up money to buy stuff, and you can't grind to build up some extra XP. So if you're having difficulty there's no way to stack the odds in your favor.And if you want anything new you will need a LOT of gold. Sadly, though, you won't find much in the way of new equipment, or new weapons for quite some time.And you know how in D&D looting the bodies after a fight was the most exciting part, because maybe... just maybe you'd get an awesome magical sword, or some kind of unique armor? Well this isn't D&D, you'll get some generic weapons if you're lucky.You want something unique? Watch for sidequests. Nine hours in there are two. And those two weapons are only marginally better than the weapons you pick up after your first fight.*sigh*The final and biggest problem with combat is that it seems to linked to some kind of weird nonsense logic. You can have a 95% chance of hitting and you can (and will) miss three out of four time.I had a mage with an 85% chance of success cast one successful spell in five rounds. The good news is that failing to cast a spell doesn't cost you magic points, but it wastes your entire round.And I am aware that enemies have the ability to dodge or parry your attack, but doesn't that seem like something that should be listed in the to hit percental?If I see 95% to hit, I assume that means that out of a hundred attacks I'll miss five times. The battle Log, which shows the results of all your attacks, isn't any help in deciphering why you've missed. Which is frustrating after three rounds of both my fighters missing an enemy and that same enemy missing them.If I don't understand what I'm doing wrong, I can't fix it.And don't expect the game to explain it to you. It doesn't.Basically all of my complaints seems to come down to pacing. It's too slow. The story is too slow for me to get interested in it, the characters develope to slow (if at all) for me to bond with them, my combat options increase too slow so I'm bored with combat, my equipment changes so slowly I'm not really interested in even winning fights, and my abilities increase so slow I'm not even interested in trying to buy the very limited number of skills in the game.Hell, going into towns in this game is slow! There is a surprisingly long load time to pop into cities which are, for all extents and purposes, a static shot of a the town with three to five people standing around.Don't expect to explore the town, either, generally you get three icons to click on and then you're officially done with everything the town has to offer.But I figured, oh well. If playing it on Easy is still a painfully slow slog maybe I can just cheat to get a ton of gold, EXP and just power through the game.And, unfortunatly, the creators decided that there isn't even a cheating option. Sounds bad for me to complain about that, but after three fights which were basically attrition battles designed to wear down your team and waste your (EXPENSIVE) potions in long drawn out fights where enemies just continiously spawn...Yeah, I'm tired. I just want to speed things up so I can see if the story gets any better. But I can't. So, I'm done.I can't suggest it, which is sad because I wanted this game to be good. I wanted to play this and I wanted to enjoy it.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												First: Blackguards isn't bad or good.  It's just extremely mediocre.  If you're into D&D alternatives and dig X-Com, it probably won't waste your time.  But I can't recommend it for most people.The character customization is surprisingly lacking, despite the illusion of choice.  There are twice as many attributes as a D&D system, but they all just sum together to increase your attack, dodge chance, initiative, etc.  There are only a handful of combat abilities to use, so there's not a lot of choice as far stabbing/shooting.  The magic users are more nuanced; there are a ton of spells, each with 4 tiers, so you're constantly weighing the cost/benefit of those.Combat itself is very similar to X-Com or D&D 4.0: you get either a move and an action, or a double move.  This all occurs on a hex-grid, and most maps have some sort of interactable element to spice it up.  They do an admirable attempt to differentiate the levels, but you will take place in about a billion combat scenarios, so a lot of them inevitably feel repetitive.  You'll probably be skipping side quests by the end out of boredom.The plot is pretty linear.  There are batches of side quests that open up at various points, but none of them augment the main plot line at all.  It's your typical RPG "save my daughter" or "escort my caravan" kind of stuff.  You become enslaved and forced to fight in a gladiatorial arena at one point, so that's pretty neat.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												Let's start with character creation; You seem to have a lot of choices, but most of these are just number-crunching to get the few choices that matter. Although even those are just a numbers game, just bigger numbers. You can also choose your starting equipment, this is pretty neat, if it weren't for the fact that you lose all of your equipment after your first combat.Speaking of combat, every action you do has a high chance of failing, from casting a spell to setting a trap to swinging a club. The chance to hit or be succesful is made harder by your enemies' defenses. Wait, that's not all, the damage range of your weapons goes from 1-6, 5-10, or 4-12 for example, this damage is further reduced by your enemies' damage reduction %, and flat damage reduction. This means that on top of the abnormally high miss chance(plus dodge and parry chances!), actually dealing damage is stupendously hard. Now imagine most enemies have around the same health as you, 30ish. So what do you do? You wail on the enemies until they fall down, hoping you even hit them. This makes combat feel sluggish, your actions meaningless, and generally make you waste time.The story? You get to choose which lines are said first.. sometimes. It also appears you get some dialogue options at times. None of these worked, and didn't work the few times I did try them. Perhaps they work later in the game when you have a higher Charisma? Thing is, I maxed my charisma, it wouldn't go higher, so why have those options there at the start anyway? To waste my time? Make me feel like I have a choice? No, this is another kick to the nuts this game gives.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												I thoroughly enjoy Daedalic Entertainment's point-and-click adventure games so when I heard that they would be making a turn-based RPG I was super pumped.  I love the Dark Eye world and the gritty fantasy found therein and I feel that this game does not disappoint.  PROS1) THE CHARACTERS! I adored the main characters and genuinely felt that each line of dialogue between them was solid gold.  Every one of them had a great personality and contributed to the overall value of this game a great deal.2) The Dialogue and Story: You can take it or leave it but I what I came across I enjoyed.  While it is true that the story is linear and doing side-missions does nothing but help you grind this was never an issue for me.  I liked the story and the direction it was taken.  You're a bad guy doing bad things for the right reasons and it is not often to come across something that does this trope well.  The game does a great job of putting you into the "antihero" mentality.  3) Combat: This game does not hold your hand.  You WILL redo fights, you WILL get frustrated, and unless you know how to build your stats and abilities you WILL fall behind but as long as you play your hand correctly you will always be able to win the next fight.  Similar to older iterations of D&D (which Die Schwarze Auge/The Dark Eye is the German equivalent of more or less) there are weapon AND damage types to consider.  Knowing what kind of weapons and what kind of damage types to use are crucial against certain enemies.  For example, DON'T USE PIERCING AGAINST THE UNDEAD!  They are completely immune to anything that doesn't impart massive physical trauma to their skeleton like slashing or bashing weapons would.  Some enemies are immune to poison, some to magic, and some to physical damage.  It will be trial and error to figure this out but this is also why you can equip each character with three different weapon load-outs which you can cycle through in combat so as to avoid being harmless to a specific enemy.  Other things to note about combat include the diversity of places you will fight in (it makes you feel like you're actually traveling from place to place), the importance of positioning, the use of environmental effects to your advantage, and bottlenecking.  Combat is the meat and potatoes to this game and after 50+ hours of this game I, for one, can say that it does not get old.4) Stat Systems and Leveling: DO NOT RAISE BASE STATS! At least not at first.  This game offers a wide variety of upgrade paths with which you can take your party in a multitude of directions.  Wanna be a crazy hefty tank? Upgrade Warcraft, Body Control, Willpower, Strength, Vitality, and the proficiency of two weapons of your choice.  Wanna be everywhere and piercing armor? Upgrade Agility, Body Control, Spear proficiency, Dexterity, and Vitality for that damage you are most certainly going to take.  Wanna mage it up?  Take Bow proficiency, level your spells like crazy (a hefty investment), and make sure you have a tank or two between you and the enemy.  While some might bemoan the lack of class options with there only being three, Warrior, Ranger, and Mage, it isn't that large of an issue.  This is not a game about diplomacy or sneaking around (ignoring two or three AWFUL missions that can be solved with fighting), it's about slugging it out with the enemy.  To play something that doesn't contribute to the fight directly is to take a difficult game and make it impossible.5) Grittiness: I consider this a plus because I like games that force you to be aware of the number of arrows in your quiver, how absolutely vital healing can be, and how huge a difference is made when you finally buy that new axe that does ONE MORE DAMAGE.  This is a game where all the small things add up over time to take your party from bandit npcs to gods on the battlefield.  Throughout the game you can also learn special attacks which give you advantages in certain situations such as inflicting wounds (Wounds and HP Damage are totally separate things), knocking down enemies, or doing more damage from a distance with ranged weaponry.  The larger and more valuable the effect the more costly the attack will be in terms of accuracy so a very effective trade-off between damage/utility and accuracy is established.6) The World: Not much to say aside from how much I enjoyed it and all the people you come across.  It is VERY uncommon for you to run across nice individuals so when you do you instantly grow attached to them.  Even then most of the "nice" people you come across are still awful by today's standards due to their desires to brainwash, enslave, or kill off rivals for a plethora of reasons.  Aventuria (the world) isn't a great place and it's heroes reflect that, but maybe, with a great deal of effort, you can change that.CONS1) The Probability System: IT LIESSSSSSSSSSSSSSS! Never in a game have I missed five consecutive instances of hitting with a 95% chance of my attack succeeding each time.  It is without a doubt the single most irritating and detracting point to this whole game.  Until you play Blackguards you will not understand how infuriating it can be.  It doesn't just apply to physical attacks, though.  Your spells will fizzle out and do nothing, your arrows can randomly vanish, you will fail body tests where you have a 99% chance of passing and fall down.  This was a HUGE oversight on the part of the developers and if they would just release a patch that made these percentages more accurate I would have nothing against this RPG.2) POISONS and Enemy Buffs! In the latter half of the campaign in an attempt to balance the gameplay the developers just decided to either give the enemies a flat magic stat buff or give all of their attacks the poison quality which will do continuous damage or give you a stat debuff for the rest of the fight.  Not nearly as irritating as the percentage issue but it does somewhat cheapen the joy you get when your party goes into an encounter that you should faceroll only to discover that the enemy basically leveled up with you.3) Stat Building: While I did mention this as a plus earlier you can very easily destroy your game by building poorly.  Seeing as how there is no way to undo this it can prove to be game ruining.  Overall, I would give this experience a solid 8/10.  Fun from beginning to end and if you see it on sale for less than 10 you should instantly snatch it up.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
												I can't have more than an hour into this game, and it's already crashed twice on loading screens. I force-quit it on the third non-tutorial level.I'm a big fan of daedalic, and I champion myself as being well versed in every turn based RPG of this nature. But this feels like it was never play-tested. It genuinely feels like no one sat down and played it, as a game, and said "okay, these elements work mechanically, but from a game-perspective, they dont." Every single time you miss a hit, and your enemy never misses at all, and you sit there for a dozen turns soaking up damage for what feels like--no strategic reason, you realise, "Oh great, this is one of those games where I need to return to town every ♥♥♥♥ing time I finish a level, to heal up"Why? Why not just heal back to full between missions? What purpose does returning to the inn after every mission serve as an improvement to the pacing of the game? If you take a bow for your caster (I mean, that makes sense right, you've read the reviews, you know you're gonna run out of mana and you're a ranged character) and you switch to it, and "Oh, I'm pointblank range with this monster. Hit chance 25% 4dmg" monster has 20 hp. Wtf. So statistically it should take me 20 ♥♥♥♥ing turns to kill this? I'm not talking about this being late game and you made a series of bad choices. This is the first mission that doesn't hand-hold you through a required tutorial.Turns out, yes. It's going to take you twenty ♥♥♥♥ing turns to do anything, while trying to negotiate the ridiculous gimmick (plug those lice holes! Pull those levers!) no. I was done. The game is not balanced in any satisfying way. It's not "challenging". At best, it just challenges your patience to see how many times you can watch your ridiculously weak spell miss for the 20th time, before you realise there's absolutely no pay-off. I understand miss and dodge mechanics. But when your game is structured around you missing more than 50% of the time... there's no fun in that. No one is sitting at home playing this game thinking "Oh oh oh, I missed! What fun! That's 3 in the row!"

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												At a glance, Blackguards is a fun foray into the turn-based tactical genre. The system is both simple and overly complex at the same time, but it balances out nicely. The graphics and the storyline certainly aren't anything to write home about, but for a turn-based game they are more than acceptable - after all, the real focus of any turn-based strategy game is going to be the combat, not the sparkling wit or crisp graphics.Unfortunately, the combat is where things really fall apart.That's not to say that the combat system itself is at fault. It's passable, and roughly analogous to Dungeons & Dragons. The real problem is that many of the set-piece battles are designed to be inherently unfair. Even on the easiest difficulty, you'll often struggle with scenarios that are designed to be one step short of impossible. You'll often find your character(s) stripped of their equipment and forced to use random items that you don't have the skill to use. You'll often find yourself thrown into insane battlefields filled with literally dozens of hidden traps, endless hordes of respawning opponents, or obtuse victory conditions that require you to interact with five or more scattered pieces of scenery. Somewhere along the line, the designers seem to have gotten just a bit too clever about their level designs, inadvertantly making many encounters more frustrating than fun.Fortunately, the developers made several adjustments as the game went through early release - so if you can power through the first two chapters (Chapter Two is particularly frustrating), then you'll find that the game opens up a good deal. At that point it becomes a much more enjoyable experience, although still occasionally plagued with annoyingly obtuse map design (one optional "arena" map can easily take an hour or more to finish due to it's maze-like design and infinitely spawning enemies).If you're a hardcore strategy gamer, then Blackguards is certainly worth buying. For anyone even slightly more casual, though, you should probably give Blackguards a pass.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												I don't even know how to explain the lackluster gameplay. Simple put, if you enjoy games where you have to lose battles a dozen times to memorize trap locations, constantly fight unbalanced matches and only like to stick with non-intuitive,  cookie cutter builds, then this game is definitely for you. If you want to experiment with unique builds, play melee or just want some fun battles and original gameplay, look elsewhere, this really isnt for you.Not even a couple of hours into the game and I realised that the battle mechanics are absolutely one of the worst i've seen, in over a decade of playing turn based strategy games. It's another perfect example of developers compensating for horrible AI, by overpowering the player.A few other problems: This isnt tactical, it's nearly impossible to be tactical in this game because the maps are way too simple, if you're looking for XCOM style tactics, this is nowhere close. Most of the obstacles can be shot through and they provide no additional defense(unless of course the enemy is behind them, in which case they will shoot from behind their obstacle and also through yours and still knock you down with an arrow, from the other end of the map), even with 90% hit chance you will constantly miss.I've never once wanted to give up on a game so fast but I already see no incentive to continue with this game, it's just so boring and unrewarding for the difficulty. I regret buying it, even at the sale price of $15.Please, for your sake, ignore the steam reviews and do some proper online research before buying this game.

Posted: October 12, 2014
												For all the hype this game received it truly is infuriantingly awful!The story is trope-ridden and uncompelling, a flaw which is compounded by the lack of any sense of progression due to enemies quickly becoming ridiculously overpowered (don't even get me started on the Iribar lily).Combining an AP system with the need to locate a highly specific trainer to attain certain special abilities really damages the game, if you save up your AP hoping to find a trainer for a particular you find the enemies outclassing you due to the lack of uninvested points. When even a single missed hit can cost you the battle (which are frequently overly long) it seems counter-productive to have such low hit chances even when the relevant weapon skill is maxed out and complimentary stats are high.I'm sure if you are a veteran of The Dark Eye, the choice of character build could be optimised such that the battles are easier; on the other hand the highly repetitive battle sequences, lack of character placement pre-battle, dreadful story, and lacklustre town interface probably wouldn't make the game enjoyable.I was genuinely looking forward to this game heralding a new wave of turn-based/tactical rpgs (of which i am a great fan), but now I am left sincerely hoping the publisher never curses the world with a sequel.

Posted: September 30, 2016
												The visuals of this game are in real stark contrast with the game mechanics. Everything looks very nice, but when it comes to the combat, skill system, rest periods and so forth, the game begins to feel like it was drafted twenty years ago.It's just so inbalanced. The classes are not in balance. The attributes, skills, talents, weapon talents and special talents (I probably forgot something) are not in balance. The cost of items and services - compare for instance provisions, healing, bandages, potions and taverns - are not in balance.The game is haphazard inside and outside of combat. You may begin a series of events only to notice that there is no way to return anymore. There are unforeseeable series of battles, and failing one may set you back an HOUR of progress. Failing even one spell might flip the situation completely. Putting all points in a single weapon talent can screw you up, because, well... find it out yourself.But all this got me thinking. Are we too pampered with forgiving games? Perhaps. Here's a game that you can seriously break by playing it wrong (or right, in a good way!). Here's a game that requires putting those annoyingly flexible talent points into right places. So begrudgingly thumbs up for this one.

content:
Posted: March 21
												The first time I came to write a review for this game it was going to be a vitriolic missive of woe and anger. In true fashion, and not for the first time, the game had put me on my♥♥♥♥♥ It was during the games infamous second chapter, where fights come thick and fast, and leave you feeling brutalised and frustrated. I perservered however and came out of the other side happier for it.This game is far from perfect, but for fans of tactical RPGs it is a truly a diamond in the rough. Battles are varied and interesting and party composition and tactical choices really make a difference. The combat system is deeper than it first appears and that hidden depth is one of the games finer qualities. It is also it's biggest drawback. The game is closely based on a pen and paper RPG and unfortunately in many ways just as indecipherable to the beginner. The character progression system is almost arcane in its complexity, to the point that it is almost certain that you will make mistakes in the way you build up your party. These mistakes will be deadly on even normal difficulty. It's reliance on a pen and paper system mean that unless you have a copy of the rulebook and many hours to ponder it and try out permutations, your characters will be woefully shy of optimal. This may lead to you having to restart the game several times as you begin to unravel its mysteries.That being said , the game is sufficiently fun, interesting and challenging that you won't mind having to restart. I didn't.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												In brief: fairly linear hex-map RPG with good character system and decent storyline. You'll enjoy it if you like that sort of thing.Blackguards is an old-school gaming experience dressed in modern threads, a pen-and-paper RPG brought to life on the PC. The graphics are appealing, animations smooth, sound effects satisfying and voice acting mostly good. You take the role of an assistant to a noble family who gets into trouble at the outset and goes on the run, and your attempts to unravel what's happened ultimately take on a global significance. The story, chiefly told in cutscenes whose animation is best described as economical, follows a fairly linear path, but a wealth of subplots and sidetracks provides a pleasant illusion of free movement which probably won't convince today's open-world gamers.Your character is provided with several sidekicks and you marshall and move your party on the world map. Movement is essentially the selection of locations and passage of time is not tracked. In towns and similar locations you'll find traders, trainers, inns, healers, and the like, as well as NPCs who advance the plot and give you quests. Party management is done through the stat sheet and inventory of each character, and true to the RPG that gave birth to this game, the system is satisfyingly deep and complex. Your decisions about character development will win or lose you the game, and new players should take note: it is possible to build a character badly and it's very difficult to undo this once you've done it, so take the time to read the manual and the in-game character creation notes (which don't appear in the manual and are very useful).Quests and plot advancement almost always involve a skirmish, and it's these hex-map clashes where you'll spend most of your game hours. It's clear that a lot of thought has gone into skirmish map design: in some cases it's a straight fight to the death, but often there are environmental factors to deal with and in some cases the map is a puzzle which you must solve to win. In fact you can think of every skirmish as a puzzle which must be solved, as enemies differ in their capacities and susceptibilities and you must apply the right tools in terms of weapons, spells and equipment to prevail. That said, the game depends ultimately on the roll of the dice, so luck is always a factor. Fortunately death isn't permanent and so long as you have the last man standing, you'll walk away with your party intact.Some reviewers have complained of the game's excessive difficulty. At the time of writing this review I've completed the game on Normal difficulty and have clocked up over 80 hours of play. I think I saw every skirmish there was to see, well over a hundred in total, and more than half of those I completed first time. There were only a handful I had to attempt more than twice. The final battle is difficult, but so it should be – my only gripe is that the plotting, or perhaps the scriptwriting, feels a bit wrong at the end, but YMMV. If you find yourself stymied by a skirmish, see whether you can go elsewhere to level your party up a bit; if not, it's very likely that you're either missing something important in the skirmish (always check the interactive objects) or you've taken a serious misstep in character building. Be careful not to spread XPs too thin on your characters: you can't take all spells and weapons to the maximum in the course of the game, and you do need some top-level skills and spells by the end if not by the middle.Two things bothered me about this game: loading times, and the ending. My system isn't top-of-the-line but neither is this game, and I saw far too much of the loading screens for my liking (Mengbilla in particular tried my patience quite a bit). The ending... without spoiling things, I was surprised to see essentially the same cutscene after winning the final battle that I'd seen when I lost it. I'm unsure if your choice in dialogues makes any real difference to the way the game pans out, and online chatter suggests that a lot of players were left confused by the denouement. I can't honestly recommend that anyone other than a genre purist buy this game at full price, but if you see it on sale grab it and give it a try, and be sure to get to the top of the bow skill tree as early as possible!

												Great game. I'm an older player. If you like old school D&D themed type of games and turn based combat with quite a few skills spells and stats..... this game is for you. content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												This game is the equivalent of Iron Man 3 - plenty of potential, a winning formula but just didnt pull it off where it mattered.Let me explain..... It has a good story that makes you want to invest time to find out what happens to the characters. It has turn based mechanics with lots of flexibility - shall i use the environment to my advantage, shall i switch weapons or shall i just spam the most powerful attack i have (yes. do the latter). Just the WORST thing about the game is when you successfully miss 4 attacks in a row each with a hit chance of 80%. This sort of treachery happens often and really spoils the battle.The battle map is great and you can easily find your way around the battlefield although in my opinion the user interface is lacking a bit - all the useful buttons are grouped together and are a little bit too small for my liking. You can semi-personalise each character and evolve their skills and attributes to your liking - although unless you want to turn a mage into a bad-boy-brawler (and why the hell would you do that) there isnt that much choice.All in all it is a better than average game although is only worth buying when on steam sale.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												Not a particular amazing game, but enjoyable enough and some cleverly designed scenes here and there prevent you from tackling each and every battle with exactly the same old strategy.  Comparing the number of pros and cons, it's a really impressive game; but one of the cons just happens to be super important to me, bringing the game down to just decent instead.CONSThe game can basically be broken down into four parts: cutscenes; inventory/ability screens; towns/shops; and battle scenarios.  Each of these is actually very well done.  But it leaves the game feeling a bit hollow simply because you don't get much of a feeling of exploring.  You move around the map by clicking on dots.  You move around submaps by clicking on dots.  Even the towns/shops just feel like clicking on dots.  They shouldn't, because they're much more visual, but the game just builds that feeling of dot-clicking into it, and you can't shake it.  The inventories get messy.  Weapons and armour can be seen separately, but everything else is all piled up in one section with no sorting options.  So when you're looking for healing or mana potions, be prepared to go through page after page of poisons, traps, buffing potions, throwing weapons, and EVEN all the 'quest items' - new and old, jumbled up with them.PROSThe cutscenes are well done, the plot's interesting enough, and you really feel like you get to know the characters.There's a good number of abilities, categorised in some interesting ways.  Most importantly, the spells have enough variety that you can really explore a range of different strategies.  Even within typical categories like direct damage or buffing, there's still variety.  (Potential SPOILER examples:  Direct damage has single target, area of effect, enemy hunting single target, cloud spawning enemy hunting single target, and whole map blasts; and some of those stun, or knock down, or curse/debuff.  And that's just within direct damage.  My favourite quickly turned out to be a shadow duplicate spell - which for me meant creating a second archer-mage for 3-5 turns, whose arrows are shadow too, so it was like getting double the mileage out of each arrow).   The variety might take a little while to sink in, because at first it looks like 24 spells with 4 levels of power each.  But within the 4 levels for each, most have at least one significant change, so it's actually more like 48 spells.The options for non-spellcasters are more limited, but still allow for some good variety - especially since you can have up to three weapon sets; and/or make use of traps and throwing weapons.  It's hard to do early on, but each route you take eats up experience points, but this ultimately allows you to do things like: (a) Carry a giant two-handed bashing weapon for massive damage and quick battles, but be ready to switch into sword and shield if you need more defense and accuracy.  (b) Run around with a two-handed pike-style spear, but pitch javelins and poison bombs at your enemies before they get into melee range.  (c) Mix up archery and fencing.  (d) Go all archery, but set traps - especially stunning or slowing traps - around you when melee fighters look like they're going to get too close.  (e) etc, etc.The weapons and armour are pretty bog-standard for an RPG overall, but are just varied enough.  The expense might seem frustrating at first, but I enjoyed the way it made me mix and match parts more often, and set different characters up with different equipment sets.  And when there are all kinds of traps and poisons and buff potions, etc, as well, it feels like you've always got something new to pick up.The combat!  At first it looks like each map is going to be a matter of big vs small, wide vs narrow, and empty or covered with traps or blocking environment.  That'd lead to a bit of variety, but eventually you'd work out a couple of strategies that you'd just use over and over again.  But soon enough, you start seeing unique twists (some are repeated a couple of times; some are just used once).  There are plenty of them, and they are what really make the game worth it in the end.  (Potential SPOILER examples:  A super long get to the end before the poisonous mist catches up to you map.  Skeletons keep coming back to life unless you smash the crystal maps.  Sneak through the dark and you won't have to fight at all maps. Maps with cages to open to let out support.  Maps with cages to close to trap beasts.  Maps with buildings you can knock down to crush some enemies.  Maps with spider webs hidden like traps and as bridges you can knock out from under the spiders.  And more and more.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2016
												I really enjoyed it.. The difficulty can be ridiculous on certain enemies, and is extremely punishing if you screw up your builds.. Its very rng based, and people who hated the hit% crap from Xcom EU/EW will hate this as much.. I didnt have many technical issues, and I really enjoyed the game, and am looking forward to playing through part 2 when i get around to it.. I did have to turn the diff down to easy, as I was just unable to get through some fights (one in particular, which repeates later on, and is where i finally gave up) Irribar Illy or something.. Has tentacles, and wisps which can only be dmg via magic..  Not only can melee attacks fail, but so do spell casts.. I dont mind misses when its a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ chance to cast/hit, but when 90%+ chances miss consistently and consecutively, it just promotes save scumming to advance, and thats what i felt i had to do to progress..  Even on easy, as i said.. Later on, you feel much more powerful, but some other cheap feeling tactics are then thrown at you, often far out numbering the player.. Like I said, I enjoyed the game, but Ill be damned if i could figure out the difficulty, and Im no stranger to tactical games..

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												Decent turn based tactical game. Tends to get somewhat repetitive over time, and suffers somewhat from the inherent weaknesses inherited from the Dark Eye game system and background. It also lacks somewhat a real feeling of character advancement - after playing a decent amount of matches you feel barely much "better" than in the bginning: the character have little more HP, the weapons do little more damage, etc. Full price I'd say it's not worth it, but on a sale it's a nice game to sink some hours into - if you like turn based fantasy tacticals, that is.I still prefer the "old" stuff like Icewind Dale or Baldurs Gate for turn based combat, though, or the non-fantasy new ones like Shadowrun - which has both better system, and better plot. One thing I didn't really like was the chained battles - in the later part of the game you can have two or three battles chained after one another, without any opportunity to rest & recover, or even to reload bolts & arrows or potions & poisons. 6/10

content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												Great turn based tactical combat RPG.  The non-combat parts of the game are really just "interface" and story board.  Kind of like a Dark Eye based XCOM.  Combat is great.Character development can be frustrating at first if you're not familiar with Dark Eye rules, but once you figure out the basics (focus entirely on a skill or two to start until you're competent at them before branching out), it's a smooth progression.Not at all loot based.  Combat is pure character build and tactics based.  Pay attention to the environments, they are key.  Some battles will seem impossible if you didn't pay attention to the commentary leading up to it and use your "V" key to highlight the interactive objects.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												Fun game so far, I'm enjoying it... Scratch that....Combat which you will be doing alot of is bland and repetative. Be prepared to be posioned in alot of battles, also prepare for your spells to fail regardless if you are maxed out in them, For example I had 1 spell called  Cold Shock (Level 18) Maxed in the description I have a 99% chance to cast, in one battle this % drops to 8% with no explaination. This game is not not very forth coming in telling you the negatives that effect you well unless is poison :). Magic, What the game does not tell you is with spells that effect all enemies your chances of casting these spells drops to stupid odds... For example in the last few fights in Chapter 5 I was trying to cast a few spells the chance was 1%, please understand I had all my skills maxed regarding spell casting, even reliable spells like the Fireball one was reduced to 48% from 99%. As a whole being a magic user you are punished. Does the enemy get punished in the same way? No they are able to case level 4 spells at 99%.Storyline, seems non exsistant at the moment and I am on chapter 5 the last chapter, you arent made to care for your choices or characters sorry I like to feel my choices in RPGs actually make a difference.Skill Trees, again like combat it is bland, if you go melee you want to go for Hammer Blow which forces you to take Two Handed Bashing or Axes and Maces. I did start the game of as dual wielding swords how wrong I was :(. There is very little choices in skills say unlike games like Path of Exile.The equipment you get is standard and boring. You would expect from a Fantasy RPG to get some magic items well dont hold your breath, there are a few items that will give you the odd boost but they are few and far between.Overall as a fan of Turn-Based games and RPGs Blackguards comes up short in so many ways.I am glad I paid less than what its on sale for.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												Ok, let me start by saying that I absolutely love this game; its got everything a true RPG'er would want in a game; good story, great game mechanics, addictive gameplay, good graphics, outstanding music score, and probably excellent replayability as well. So why am I giving it a thumbs down?? its difficulty is just...brutal, before anyone accuses me of being a pancy COD button masher let me say in my defense that A) I have never played COD and B) I am actually an old school rpg'er that has bagged several classic rpg's on my resume, Wizardry games? check, Baldurs gate? check, Icewind Dale? check, might and magic? check, and also most modern RPG's as well such as the Witcher and the Dragon Age series. So I *know* when I talk about difficulty I mean it, this game is absolutely frustrating sometimes; on easy the enemies are more forgiving ( and I am not one to use that setting unless absolutely necesary) BUT the hazards and Obstacles are NOT.I will still purchase whatever DLC the devs decide to release, and I will definitely purchase a second part of this game, just because I am a very passionate RPG'er, and this is truly a gem of game. However, a lotta folks will be put off by the brutal difficulty the game throws at you constantly and the (somewhat) steep learning curve.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												EXPLORATION & ADVENTUREThe game has no exploration or sense of adventure. None. Zero. Your experience with exploring the world of Blackguards consists of clicking on an icon on the world map representing a settlement and loading up a marketplace view, said view having a few icons to click on that load up the various types of stores or that occasionally (a different icon) offer quests. And that's it.The various settlements are highly detailed, but all of that detail exists on static backgrounds. The backdrop pictures could have offered a great sense of place simply by utilizing a nice exterior shot. Indeed, this being a fantasy world, and one where many of the settlements offer a rather distinct size and local elements, exterior views could have added a great deal of wonder and adventure to the player's sense of the world. As it is, though, settlements are just a series of the same four stores with minor hints at the diversity that the world has to offer with a few extra flourishes added to some of the marketplaces.For the most part, one's interaction with the world is on the level of an mmo. There are stores to click on and buy stuff, and there is the occasional quest giver that is met once or twice, says his generic spiel to send you off on your generic quest, and one never sees them again after. Leaving the game with no sense of character.STORYThe overall concept of Blackguards is generic chosen one gets chosen for unknown reasons to save the world. It's a bland and generic concept, but there's nothing inherently bad about it. One can take a generic concept and sprinkle originality upon it to make an exciting concept. Operative word being can. With Blackguards, the one conceit to originality is that the characters are "blackguards".Except they're not. The main character is, in actuality, falsely accused of a crime he/she didn't commit. And he/she now roams the badlands, an outlaw hunting outlaws...a RENEGADE.Some of your cohorts have committed crimes. But other than a few - very rare - jokes, this never really comes into play. The only character who is actually a criminal during the game is quickly killed off. The rest of the characters are more in the "gang of rogues and misfits" territory. And the things that that band of rogues and misfits are called upon to do during the game are the usual generic RPG quests. Find the lost "ring", rescue the damsel in distress, kill these bandits, etc.With only that unused conceit to count towards originality, there is nothing original in the Blackguards storyline. It is, unfortunately, the usual generic, bland template upon which to hand an RPG. But it actually gets worse than that, because the various enemies and situations are also generic, and the core development is a jumbled mess, leading to no driving reason to progress through the story. (Stressing here that there is no driving reason to progress through the story, not the game.)There's a core of a good story lying within Blackguards. Evil villains, saving the world, high adventure. But none of it ever gets used. Instead, the overall story sits in the background while the characters get captured - again - and drug around doing random combats against generic foes that have no personal stake in the overall story. The number of times that the party actually fights people who are involved in the threat to the world before reaching the final chapter is incredibly low. Instead, in a world threatened with destruction, it's mostly bandits, gladiators, various animals, and independent undead that the party meets.The characters of the main party have some personality, even if it is a bit two-dimensional. Their personalities are well-written. But there is little there to most of them, and those personalities do not drive the story. The only driving force in the story is the Chosen One main character. The other members of the party simply offer some localized color here and there. And unfortunately, the best personality is killed off early and replaced by someone as bland as the Chosen One main character. The remaining personalities are well-written, but bland. Which brings up one of the major points that are often brought up about games like Blackguards - "It's not about the story; it's about the combat". And while it is true that the centerpiece of Blackguards is combat, one also spends a lot of time watching cutscenes following along the story. If the story isn't actually a major part of the game, then it shouldn't occupy a major part of the time of the game. If it does occupy a large portion of gametime, then it is a major part of the game. End of story. RESOURCE MANAGEMENTAt first, the resource management of Blackguards seems like it will be an exciting and detailed system. But like so much else in the game, none of what is met in that first impression is ever fully realized. There is a lot of meat here. The consumables system is highly detailed, with a lot to offer a game that put pressure on those resources. But there is never any pressure. None of the resources matter.  The most glaring of these is rations. The sole use of rations is to allow the group to camp out on the world map. Yet, since there are no wandering monsters and no risk or real time involved in traveling, there is no reason not to simply click on a settlement and rest at its inn rather than lug around heavy rations units (other than the obscurely long loading times for the settlements). The only resource that is regularly bought are arrows, for those rare times when there aren't bundles of them found on the enemy, or when - much more often - all of your equipment has been taken from you. As with so much else in Blackguards, resource management is a highly detailed system that a lot could be done with, but that never comes to fruition. Soon after it's introduction, it becomes left by the wayside.COMBATFor all of the famed glory of the Blackguards combat system, there actually isn't much to it. The party is made up of five members, and they usually fight from 6-7 enemies, occasionally more, sometimes less. The battles take place on a hex-grid, and they take place in turns based on individual character speed and an initiative roll. Unfortunately, the enemies are underdeveloped. There is not a great deal of enemy variety. There are a large number of enemy portraits to fight. But there are not a wide variety of methods of attack. Most enemies are melee grunts who attack using the same pattern and single attack, whether they are mindless zombies or (supposedly) intelligent bandits. A few combats have enemies with ranged ability, which they use in a largely random fashion, instead of a focused aggressive one. And a rare few  have spellcasters, which use their spells in a largely ineffective fashion. Combats against opponents with special abilities beyond that are really rare.On the other hand, it is good for the party that enemies remain stupid and unfocused, as the party are always outnumbered and usually fighting on empty square battlemaps, and thus a focused effort would likely easily overwhelm the party. Likewise, the enemy do not have all of the special abilities that the party do. Again, this is a must for the survivability of the party. The power feats that are available are just so intensely powerful, and there is so little defense against them, that having any of those abilities is essentially an I-WIN button.Which leads to the main issue with the combat - it's is badly balanced. Open character development systems are really hard to balance, and this one is not even remotely in the balanced ballpark. There are some aspects of the character that are hugely beneficial (Super Improved Power Attack), some that are only of minor benefit (Read Enemy hp), and some that are of no benefit at all (fireball). Thus, the difficulty of the lies entirely in the character sheet. Leading to different players having wildly different experiences in game difficulty.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												There needs to be a review on this page telling steam users that at least 11 out of the 45 achievements are bugged and most players cannot achieve them. There are plenty of community posts surrounding the faulty achievements.The game itself took a while for me to get into, it wasn't until part way through the second chapter that I found myself actually wanting to continue playing the game.I experienced 2 bugs during my gameplay, once the game crashed when trying to add a new save to my list of game saves and once when casting a spell in battle, nothing happened after the casting animation so I had to crash out and re-load the battle.As for game play and story line, you can tell this game was not finished when it was released due to the map being more than twice the size of the actual parts of the map you explore during the game. I found the ending very anticlimactic. The whole game is fully voice acted, yet the ending has a few words show up at the bottom of the screen over some scenic views... There is no obvious resolution to anything in the storyline and you are not told how the choices you made throughout the game have affected the outcome of the ending, meaning if you were to replay the game you wouldn't know what to do differently.The game is visually very nice and the voice acting is good, although some times in battle I had a mans voice sound when I hit a female enemy and vice versa.As a result, I have to say that Blackguards is a non-recommendation as I don't feel like the story provided me with anything to take away and think about, and also because of the bugged achievements meaning I can never 100% this game!

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												There is little to recommend, thinking I shouldn't have bought this.   D&D style RPG that invokes quests that don't use your current stats.  One that takes away all the party's armor and gives everyone clubs.  Another that takes one of your party out of the fight (and kills them off).  While one might say it's a strategic RPG,  that only applies if there aren't so may variables as to make strategy next to pointless (it's mandatory, but still comes down to plain luck far too often).  Bad enough the normal D&D variables to hit, the variable damage, but then lets toss in higher numbers of opponents, invisible terrain traps, and opponents that always have poisoned weapons.  Flanking an opponent doesn't seem to have been included, so pointless, and while crit hits are included, when the opponents out number you, they have a greater chance of getting crits, by benefit of more of them means more chances for a crit role. High level of frustration.Update - 2nd attempt, a little better.  Got to the point I quit first time.  Believe first time it was bugged as chance to hit was only 55% and bugs hit for 8-10 dmg.  This time I see my hit chance at 75% and bugs hit for 4-5 damage.   Meant I could actually get through the quest.

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												Blackguards is an  average game at its best . Follows genetic fantasy tropes . Character creation is bare bones , you cannot modify starting stats .  Game offers large world map , but due to its linear nature you will be just staring at places you can't go . Story progresses by clicking on hubs where you will either enter a city screen or combat . Side quests are very limited . Appearance customization is limited to picking  out of five pre-made characters per gender.  There is significant shortage of light and leather armor variety . 85-90% of all armors in a game are metal which means you spell caster wont be able to use it . Game has nice sandbox system where you are allowed pick whichever skills/perks you like . Perks require xp and trainer .  It can be difficult to find trainer to teach you perk . For example you might unknowingly leave act 1 and lose access to mage trainer for rest of act 2 . Combat is dull . Most of it involves using same spell/melee attack and hoping you will get lucky.  Graphics and are style are uninspiring .  There is no camera angle rotation and overall camera controls are poor . This can lead to some frustration such as inability to target or see enemy hiding in a corner . You can interact with some environment and there are some environmental hazards like methane gas in swamps. You characters and enemies can slip on wet floor . Some maps with lots of water spills turn into some kind of comedy involving every character falling to the ground at start of their turn . Voice acting is decent . And dwarf you get in beginning of the game is awesome . In terms of bugs and glitches game was polished in its early stages . I've only encountered one minor bug that was quickly fixed .

content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												I wanted to like this a lot but the complexity is a turn-off for me.  In the 75 minutes I played I maybe did 4 fights and read at least 20+ pages of tutorials that almost left me with more questions than answers. For instance, they told me to have my swordsman take cover from archers, so I did, but the archer movement was just as long as his (if not longer) and they all circled around the cover and shot me.  I tried another set of cover instead and the same happened.  In spite of all the other information they were giving, I was unable to find out why this was occurring, but I ended up hammering my way through them anyway.  I'm certain I must have missed something, perhaps to reader's fatigue.Then I fought someone in the mud, and the whole point was to show how to take advantage of the puddles on the ground to make the enemy slip and get some cheap shots in on him.  That was pretty cool.A shame, as it is a decent game, maybe even an epic one, which seems simply surrounded by too much complexity.  I'll give it another go later and see if I still feel this way later.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												This game is quite tough, but a lot of fun.  I am still really early in the game but here are my thoughts so far.Money is sparce at best and you can never afford anything but the essencials.  If you picked a ranged charcter like I did, assume all your gold is going to provisions, healers and arrows.  No farming, since you can't just go get in an random battles, if you have an area to explore it is best to visit every location to get all the EXP you can.  Make sure you save in multiple save slots, you can get yourself in a chain of mission that you just can't win without an extra provision or something.  If you don't have that save game from before you trigger the chain of events you could be stuck.One last thing, don't be afraid to click end turn 50 times in a row if monsters aren't activated to get your magic points back and heal everyone and then get them back of to be ready for combat.Overall, I am really enjoying it so far.  I'd recommend a play.  I'll updated the review it if I feel the need later.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												I can sum this entire game up in a sentence and a half. A three or four layered pile of stat sheets that serves to slightly improve your chances of besting the RNG gods on a turn by turn basis. With the odds against you.If you think this is a dark, or pessimistic way to sum the game up, I can tell you that that is actually the nice way of putting it. To the list of gaming sins this game commits you may a redundant and unrewarding item system, the most difficult to navigate skill system I have seen since the sphere grid in final fantasy X (which is mainly out of your reach anyhow, seeing as it depends on trainers which appear at arbitrary points in the story), multiple attempts at large scale battles which quickly descend into long lines of infinitely spawning enemies dog piling on your phalanx of heroes, percent chance failures on pretty much everything that mean any well laid plan can come to a deadly end at any point in your game, and a difficulty curve that pretends all the random the dice wielding percent chance jockeys whom designed the game smashed into every nook and cranny of the game does not exist at all. The end result will leave you hitting the (restart battle) button on the second or third turn of each attempted play because your warrior's power attack whiffed, which you immediately realize means you won't be able to kill the enemies quickly enough to keep up with the level. Assuming none of the heals whiff (yes, your heals can whiff to, about 33% of the time in most cases), which is also a death sentence. I could go into the ham fisted attempts at interactive levels, mysterious and all around dumb line fo sight mechanics that let bows shoot a seemingly infinite distance but leash spells at just a few tiles, impossible side objectives, and lack of actual counter play and tactics, but my ranting would fill three pages.All this is a shame considering the clear level of effort and passion that went into designing the graphics, story line, and characters, who despite being completely archetypical adventures manage to characterize themselves wonderfully though they're well developed connection to the adventure is set in. If half the effort that went into all that were part of the game, this would likely be a tbs to the caliber of dynasty tactics or r-type command. Instead, you have either a slightly better version of fire emblem, or a slightly worse version of final fantasy tactics, both of which are mind bendingly boring and tediously frustrating to begin with. If you enjoy either of those than you richly deserve this.If you read nothing else I have written, read this: This game is a pretty face and nothing else. Looks great, plays very poorly. It would be worth about half the forty dollars it costs if it were a graphic novel. Like this, it's not worth the four bucks it was on sale for when I wrote this. WOULD. NOT. RECOMMEND. TO. ANYONE.

												Blackguards is a very interesting game with complex dynamics of the Dark Eye.IMHO this game deserves a 8.5/10 and definitely worth hours of gameplay and to some extent re-playability. I found myself planing for hours what spells to get and how to develop some characters. Pros:- Detailed characters that come to life- Good roles mixture (I played as a mage but my real emphasis was a fighter with usage of the shadow spell)- Detailed scenarios- Fantastic spells and animations.- Hard difficulty requires strategic previous character planning to be able to beat some encounters.Cons:- No 360 camera support- Sometimes win or lose a battle feels more luck than strategy (Fail all the hits and all the magic, bad luck meaning lose).- Mechanics such as Buy/Sell kind of feels incomplete and Weight system feels off- End of the story is incomplete and leaves you wondering (Blackguards 2 continues this?)Overall I must say I did really enjoy the game, and the story development might is interesting although not among the most interesting from the Daedalic games or Baldur's gates games storylines.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2016
												It's just... bad.  The visuals are average, with bits of them bordering on terrible.  The story and exploration are linear, and the story itself is just plain boring.  The voice-work is just good enough to point out how comically bad it is.  Towns are bland and lifeless.  Combat is stagnant, and shows no complexity.  Even if you buy Blackguards on sale, you likely still won't find the time to sit down with it.  There just isn't any single thing exciting enough to make up for the blandness of the rest of the game.  Nothing to draw you back in, after the first time you've played.It's well done from a mechanical standpoint - The skill trees are well thought out and balanced.  There's just nothing flashy in them to draw attention, and the execution becomes poor when you see your character dully performing their moves and abilities with passable graphics and poor weapons/equipment.  Blackguards is a pen-and-paper RPG adaptation that never really got past the pen-and-paper bit.  More of a visualisation of some DM's real-world tabletop setup that would seem much cooler set up with cardboard on your buddy's gaming table.If you're hellbent on playing Blackguards, I hear Blackguards 2 is actually worth the time.  It's on my list of 'soon to play' games, so I'll put up a review ASAP.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												I'm enjoying it. There are parts that need tightening up, like seeing the console commands on screen, but aside from that it's been a smooth experience for me.The story is interesting, the world is intriguingly dark and the characters, so far, are all interesting (my favourite being Niam the crackheaded half elf). Combat plays out on small, hex based maps that keep the action from getting bogged down or boring. And, while in combat, that's all you focus on; you can't loot corpses, for example. All of that happens afterwards which I like a LOT. The combat system is simple, really, but it works. There are enough special abilties to keep it all interesting and to give you a wide variety of tactics (at least when you get the right people to suit your style) but they're not exactly trying to break the mold here. Basically, you've probably seen this all before. It didn't bother me, but I could see it boring some people.The graphics do their job, though they're nothing to write home about. The voice acting has been surprisingly good for the main characters, although I find the NPCs tend to fall into stereotypes (villains sound like they're about to go "NYAH I'M EVIL"). It's not really distracting, since their lines are short and to the point, but it was something I noticed so take that as you will.Which is really the best way to sum up this game; to the point. There are side quests and the like, but this isn't an open world game like Skyrim where you can spend a fair amount of time just walking around. You move from battle to battle, taking breathers when you need/want them, and then get right back into the thick of it. It is for this reason that I recommend this game. It's fast, fun but not short. Buy it.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2015
												Blackguards is a RPG with a decent number of dialogue choices. The story has its ups and downs and early it is a bit confusing because they throw alot of unknown terms at you and and most of them you will only learn halfway through the game. And the end is kinda lackluster in my opinion.The combat is turn based and the battles are mostly diversed since some can have puzzle elemnts others can have a few stages and so on. And your choices along the game influences some of the battles you have.One of the biggest problem in the game is the amount of stats and character builds you can do makes the game way to difficult and players that dont understand how the game works in that regards can completely screw their games and be forced to start from scratch. The game does a really poor job of explaining how the overall stats work and the only way to learn about them is looking at help menu and read it or go to the manual. On the positive side when you learn to make a proper build your mid-late game characters can have quite impressive abilities and power, the high level spell effects are rather impressive.Also it is worth mentioning some of the achievements don't work properly or don't work at all.Overall I liked the game however the high learning curve that can really punish you is something that only some people can tolerate. And the game only really offers a couple of playthroughs in terms of story and in regards to builds I dont think that people will play purely on the interest of seeing builds with diferent weapons, the spells are nice but they will not make the players play the game again just to see their high level form.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												This is again a tricky one. Overal Blackguards is an extremely fun game but it has one big flaw. First the positive points: The strategic turn-based hex battles are great, I'm happy that finally game developers are taking this up again instead of all that RTS nonsense. The combat system with different moves goes smoothly, also the interface using a radial menu is OK. It does take a while getting used to.Nice character development using a skill/talent system which is unconventional. This feels fresh and is an interesting change compared to other typical RPG's.The voice acting is great and really adds to the immersion, also the characters themselves are well fleshed out and the interaction between them is hilareous at times (which is positive i.e. there is a lot of humor in the game).There are many different (side-)quests, lots of items to find and experiment with etc.The story itself is interesting and while the game is very linear it doesn't come as a hindrance. This also is a nice change of pace compared to other games recently where everything has to be 'open'.Now to the one flaw which at times totally screws up the game: 'nonsense' battles ...Each time I play, the battles are sometimes challenging, sometimes easy but overal quite fun. However, when you reach the pinnacle of that fun and are really enjoying the game ... the devs throw in what I call 'nonsense' battles which totally kill the mood and make you want to remove the game from the harddrive.These 'nonsense' battles for example require you to rescue someone in 6 turns. The first say two attempts it won't work since you have to figure out what is needed, the next couple of attempts you run into traps (you can't detect them since there is no time in 6 turns). So in the end you have to constantly reload and reload and reload. Try a fireball on the first turn, if it fails, reload since no miss can be afforded. The game in such battles also feels as if the 'to hit' percentages are inversed. For example a 'to hit' percentage of 95% in these battles feels as if it's 5% since suddenly everything misses (so reload and reload and reload). It thus has nothing to do with strategy anymore but purely boils down to finding that one single path which 'could' lead to victory and then pray that your attacks actually succeed.The above is really sad since it totally spoils the mood. After completing such a 'nonsense' battle (which is really a waste of time) the game is again great and fun until you again reach a point where they decided to dump such a miscreation.It feels as if the game was designed by two different people. One person designed 85% of the game which is great and 15% was designed by someone who's only goal was 'How can I annoy the player the most?".The game also has some minor issues like incorrect voices in cutscenes or a slight stutter when using certail skills (hammer blow) etc but nothing game breaking. I didn't have any crash or anything, overal it runs smooth.In total it took me 47 hrs to complete it on medium.  Considering the fact that it has some interesting replay value (different starting class, different spells, ....) the game delivers quite some content.So, in summary, it's a great game if you're into turn-based combat and will give you a lot of fun and funny moments, but beware the 'nonsense' battles since they can make you switch to a different game in a blink. When looking at the whole package the 85% definitely outweighs the 15% so I recommend it.
