content:
Posted: October 26, 2016
												Bad: The story ending feels very rushed and tagged on, compared to the plot development in the other chapters.The  battles clearly have a "right" way. (I like this, it feels like puzzle solving, but that's a matter of taste).Items, even basic items like arrows and health potions, are limited.Very, very constrained in level-up points. The leveling up system is quite involved, and the constraint from the points is too tight. It feels like that there is one layer too many,,,The animation is... special. Everyone has a dislocated jaw. The good:Even though you can see the plot twist coming from a mile away, I still struggled to make the "right" decisions to try and get a "good"ending. (Once you play enough games, you begin to see the "right" choice.)The game has a high F-U factor. Spent 20 hours and tons of money leveling up a character? Guess what, they're dead now, too bad. You think your arrows can break a crystal and you didn't think to equip your archer with a different weapon? Well, that's sucks for you.  Overall: This game needed a little bit more time and polish. If it had that, it would have become a classic. In it's current format, I find it highly enjoyable but I can imagine if you don't play many old games this will test your patience.  ***IMPORTANT*** Given how limited level-up points are, for your first playthrough you should use one of the pre-created classes. I would advise not playing a mage, given that there is an entire fourth page of skills to level up.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
												I have wanted to love this game. I really, really have. The character development system is complex and has a depth rarely found in RPGs. The story and choices are a combination of dark and darker, and yet there is no shortage of humor in the game. Having said all of that, I do NOT recommend this game for the casual gamer who enjoys RPGs. This is for the hardcore gaming fans who want to spend hours agonizing over points spent in skill and character development, only to find that you have to start over because you lack core abilities in your characters to survive. Further, the combat system is ridiculous. You get a wizard at the beginning of the game as a companion who has an ~80% accuracy range - however, in my experience, his spellcasting is weak at best, and backfires most of the time, and at often critical moments. Unfortunately, healing is also problematic because it uses an entire action (turn), and so by the next round, you may be down more health points than you were before you healed. Following me so far? That's good, because on top of that, you can count on being outnumbered and outmaneuvered in nearly every battle. I could go on to wax poetic about the ineptitude of the combat system and the way the developers correlated character development with combat in a way that is clear, but I think you can get the gist of it from above. I have to quit playing this game because after too much time trying the same battle over and over again to rescue some baroness who loves the less than useless wizard companion I have, I am going to retire this game entirely and quite playing it. It simply lacks any enjoyment for me at this point. I think the game designers have a lot of work to do to create a product that I would ever consider purchasing again. I feel cheated of my money and my time. Oh, and you don't have the option of really grinding your characters up to par, either. There are a set number of quests and side quests, and you spend those character development points at your own risk. Again, there may be a market for this to hardcore gamers and some others, but it is definitely not for the faint of heart.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												Blackguards is a turn-based combat focused RPG, that will most likely frustrate you a lot with the amount of dice rolling in it!My opinions won't really add much to the discussion, as they're mixed... like almost everyone else's. Also, I'm farily new to the genre, so the min-maxing aspect present in the attributes and skill-trees in the game don't really appeal to me, yet (mostly how of ignorance, but anyway...).I really like RPGs in general, but I'm not one to read up on the game's numerous systems to learn what the optimal builds are -- I like to shape my characters as I please, leading to some interesting, fun, but not necessarily good decisions. I've done the same in Blackguards and will admit that, for the most part, it went alright. I played through Normal mode, and never got truly stuck, which was my biggest worry.Many people complained about reaching an unbeatable point in the game because they had a sub-optimal build. Maybe they were either playing on Hard, or I've simply been fairly lucky in my decision.I will say that there were lots of details in the game that I simply did not delve into -- potions (offensive), traps, etc. Those didn't seem all important in any of the battles in Normal.Anyway. It's tough. Some of the battles were infuriating, missing 3x in a row when I had a 90% chance to hit, having some periods of extended battles that far overstayed their welcome, etc.But I did enjoy it quite a lot. Until I finished the 3rd Chapter, that is. Then the game offered nothing new.The game is very linear, although it opens up a bit in the 3rd Chapter, giving you quite a lot of sidequests. The following 2 chapters barely have any of those, which felt strange.It seems like the focus of the game was only the 3rd chapter, the other ones being mostly to build it up or simply carry the story.The story was pretty bland, and the sidequests weren't too interesting either. Gameplay-wise, it's almost a pure combat game. You move from battle to battle. Other than battles, you just go to cities to buy equipment/heal/train, and get sidequests. Sidequests simply lead you into more battles. You never explore anything, never really find emergent gameplay or anything of the sort. It's very, very combat focused.But hey... I really have very little to add that would be in any way meaningful. I want to talk about one thing exclusively -- and that is how opaque the game actually was! It was one of the biggest sources of frustration, for me.Sometimes, the game pushes you into extended battles. Battle after battle after battle without an opportunity to heal, restock, change equipment, etc. These, of course, are a much bigger challenge -- especially because, if you do poorly on one battle, you'll carry that penalty onto the next one.These battles felt extremely tense, to me. Sometimes they could go on for 2 hours, even if they were just 2 or 3 battles. The game is very slow paced, and a mistake can cost you quite a lot of time, which is frustrating. And the game often likes to pull tricks on you that it never pointed to. They're unwelcome surprises.This is one side of it. The other, happened in the end of the game. After the point of no return, you're lead into a serious of battles, but you can heal and re-equip between them. What you can not do, is buy anything. Every healing potion, equipment, etc. that you can use is what you've taken with you. There were a few problems here -- first, you had no idea how many battles there would be, so you couldn't really judge. Second, what the game showed you was very misleading, by having it spread over 2 "pages", but only showing you the first.Basically, you're expecting x battles, and suddenly, after wasting most of your potions, you're shown that there are actually twice as many. Well,♥♥♥♥♥♥Thankfully, the game wasn't tricking the player and ramping up the difficulty artifically -- on that second page, there was a healer and merchant that was essentially a safe point. And that was a very nice thing.The problem is how the game never communicated that beforehand. Every battle I fought felt that much more frustrating because a small mistake seemed like a colossal one. Arguably, that the feeling that the game was trying to carry -- I doubt it, though. In this case, it was simply a case of bad communication with the player, it seemed. And similar issues happened throughout the game -- often leading you into "extended battles" without warning, and the like.For me, at least, it's a huge source of frustration, to have to "judge" something without information. Especially when mistakes can cost hours.So yeah. That's basically it. The game is a huge "tension" without the "release"...Regardless, I enjoyed it. I'm not a hardcore player of the genre, so my appreciation is certainly different. It was a good challenge! There was some frustration with the dice-rolls, but overall, I'd recommend it to anyone who is looking for a tough turn based rpg.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												Wow, it has been a long time since I played the old "The Dark Eye" - Games. This game brought back some memories.It has a nice atmosphere and is quite challenging. I really missed the roundbased RPGs, which is, for me atleast, revived in this. Sometimes you have to think ahead, sometimes you can just bully everybody down. Some fights are really stressful, while others are straightforward. The point is that almost no fight is like another one, each requires new tactics and strategies, atleast to a point. Of course you have your base tactics, which, in my case was a mostly ranged combat play style. But pure melee or multiple spellcasters sound interesting too. The good thing is that every character is can mostly do anything, aside the fact that only characters with magic potential can become wizards.Another interesting thing for was the whole plot. Having played the other TDE games made it easy for me to fit into the world with its twelve gods, its mostly human based civilisation, with much prejudice against other races and of course its bright and wild country side, which makes this world a beautiful place. But the beauty in this is just a mask for all the darker happenings in this world.All in all, if you love Roundbased Strategy, a good and detailed told story and funny, yet serious, characters, this game is for you. Just bring some time and patience, because the downside of this are the time consuming fights and the kinda missing background story of your secondary characters.

												I have just finished the second chapter and I find the game really fun, so the large number of negative reviews surprises me. Actually one of the few games I got hooked on lately. Well, on the other hand since the score was so low, my expectations were quite low as well, resulting in a nice surprise. It is less RPG than tactical combat game but it is very good at what it is doing. Frustration because of hits are not landing even when the indicated probability is high, comes probably from the fact the people do not develop skills properly. All in all, recommended, my score is 8/10.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												While I don't have a lot of time invested yet in Blackguards I must say that I am enjoying the turned based combat and overall feel of the game.  The game is very pretty and seems bug free for the most part at least for the 3 or so hours I put into the game.   I really haven't gotten to invested into the story yet but it is interesting enough.  Visually the game is very pretty and gameplay wise it seems rewarding.   I haven't seen anything that reinvents the wheel but that said what it does it does well.  I so far highly recommend the game.  Honestly in the short time I have been playing I have had more fun combat wise than with games like Dragon Age.  Of course it isn't completely fair to compare a Real Time with Pause game with a turned based game.   I will say that between this and Divnity: Original Sins it makes a turned based strategy RPG gamer happy with glee to see such great games coming out.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14, 2014
												This is just the sort of game I love and as it was half price I snapped it up. That is where the fun ended sadly. The skills/abilities sound great but there is no way you can know what you need to go for. I built a fairly rounded party so I could be flexible and now can't even defeat basic enemies. This is, for me, a major problem as I now have to go back to an earlier save to re-spec. Not so bad you would think. Well this is where the problem is multiplied hugely. The point I am at in the game, for some unknown reason, is at the end of a series of very tedious battles. These do not allow you to save of even gather experience between them. So I have to go back beyond this point. Which is frankly killing any enjoyment I got from this game. Honestly this is a decent attempt at a turn based RPG. What lets it down is the total lack of freedom in your choices. No random battles means you have to know where to spend those skill points as you aren't getting any more from anywhere. Couple this with the fact that there is no real way of knowing what you need to spend them on till you have a go and this ruins what could have been fun.I am aware of the online guides on how to spec characters but what is the point of having lots of options only to have them reduced down to a handful that are actually feasible? Really feel that at half price I have been robbed.

												Definitely a must-have for old cRPG turn-based fans.This is the first turn-based I'm enjoying so much after years (on PC Plattform).Simple but very nice story, characters with his own personality, battles are never boring because different goals or external elements interaction, enough spells/skills to customize (shame that you know already all spells in game from the beginning, was more interesting if talents/spells would be revealed only when meeting NPCs who can train it)A game that reminded me FFT and Vandal Hearts on PSX, and definitely a good one! No resource management, no extreme high graphic, just turn-based battles, equipping/healing in cities and pure enjoyment...as it used to be!

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												Not ready for primetime.  First the good:  It looks fun and I enjoyed the first part of the first chapter.  Voice acting is decent and the combat flows OK if you like turn-based (and I do)The Bad:  Constant crashes; gamebreaking to the point where I can't continue.  Not my first rodeo and I have tried all I can think of to resolve them.  I deliverately waited until the game was out of early access and patched before purchasing.  I regret doing so now.  I'm not your beta tester.  I'm a customer or WAS a customer.  Look elsewhere to avoid frustration.OK Update - After several trys, I was finally able to get the game to continue.  Felt like walking on eggshells.  Did I do anything profound? Nope.. Just kept loading from a save until it finally continued.After further play, I still feel the game needs balancing.  Some of the fights are super-easy, others are nigh impossible.  I stand by my review.  Will this game be enjoyable at some point?  I bet, sure.. Does it need patching?  Yes it does...

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												A terrific return to Turn-Based Combat, with a slightly darker, fantasy story. It at once feels like a renaissance of the turn-based genre, but with some newer, unique ideas. Character customization looks outrageous and daunting at first, but with a single type of Adventure Point and clear class-goals, linear guidance eases the pain, while still allowing anyone to experiment with wild combinations. It's a classic tale of old-school meets new-school, all in a really tightly-produced package. Graphics, story and gameplay are all great.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												Just finished the game.  After getting to the last battle and finding it frustrating not to have Aurelia, I went back through chapters 4-5 changing strategies. The good:-If you really miss Temple of Elemental Evil, this game will be nice for you-Not a lot of min/maxing of gear (some of the best gear is available early in the game, and most of the stuff you'll find in the game will not be an upgrade)-Each of the companions have really well-drawn out personalities (the dwarf, for example, will complain when you heal him that he "doesn't need it"; the playboy mage will flirt with NPC's you meet).The bad:-There are not a lot of varieties of bad guys in the game.  You'll find yourself saying "didn't I just fight this battle?" a bit too frequently- For people that like seeing gear progression, you will not get it here.- The ending was quite a bit of a let-down.- During combat, there is no way to speed up the monsters' turns; and you will sometimes literally be waiting a minute between turns while a slug slugs its way across the screen.Will you like it?-If you liked Temple of Elemental Evil because it was super "true to the rules"--Yes-If you liked Baldur's gate because your Party AI would let you not have to micromanage--No

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2014
												Full Review: http://www.coffeebreakgaming.co.uk/pc-game-reviews/review-blackguards/Blackguards is a turn-based fantasy RPG from German outfit Daedalic which is solely based on the Dark Eye roleplaying system. It provides a welcome return to the true turn based RPG combat genre which forces you to greatly consider every action you make, whether that be skill points, combat skills and many more. It provides a good level of difficulty, without going too over-board whilst allowing you a ‘life-line’, a bone for when things get tough – i.e. the all-important and crucial save feature between battles. The overall storyline, writing, voice-acting is good whilst providing enough depth to avoid it being a drag.Combat is where Blackguards best feature occurs and is perfect for players who enjoy the battles on hex tiles to that of the stories behind them. The use of objects on battle-maps combined with an easy to understand combat interface and a variety of character abilities/skills allows the player to get in and get on with gameplay.Difficultly in digesting a variety of character abilities, skill points and equipment load-outs, specifically the equipment system, as that proved most challenging and somewhat confusing due to the amount of resistances available. However, once you’ve taken the time to understand how they all interlink, this section opens up to provide the player with a great variety of levelling up elements.Can appear to be somewhat repetitive if players aren’t enveloped in the storyline. Far too many loading screens which stops the flow of the story and battles far too often.A very stylish and graphically intense RPG, scoring high on the styles category, specifically in the gorgeous looking towns/outposts, where players are faced with beautifully designed shops and scenery which differs throughout the storyline.A mediocre score for value with its current (09/03/14) price tag of £26.99.Blackguards provides players with the opportunity to play for hours on end, experiencing a whole array of new content/utilising new tactics, however players are forced to read every snippet of information/guide to fully understand its complicated character system and some battles can appear to be rather repetitive.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												Tough but rewarding. This is (luckily in my eyes) a typical The Dark Eye game. If you do not know this RPG system: it's Germany's biggest and probably oldest Pen & Paper RPG system that is still maintained. And as many things from Germany it is deep and complex, but needs a certain degree of dedication. You will not be able to simply start this game, kill some enemies and have fun. You really need to have a look at the rule system and how all the character values influence your fighting, casting and other skills. The same goes for spending your experience points, if you simply raise a stat here and there you will find the game very hard and probably quit. If you decide what role a character will have and raise the necessary stats and skills for this you will have a much easier time and will be able to enjoy the very complex fight options.One definitive pro from my point of view are the really varied battle maps. Most maps have unique interactive features that you can use in the battle, like alchimistic tables that will poison bystanders when smashed. Or drawbridges that can be raised or lowered. Or cranes with crates that might smash your heroes from the docks - or the enemies if you position yourself smart enough.Alltogether it is a clear recommendation for me if you like complex strategy games with RPG-like character development. Do not buy if you look for Diabloesque casual RPGs.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												A horrible turn based RPG. The A.I. makes no sense at all and seems to just roll of RNG. For instance, you could be in combat with an insect, a large dumb version of 'lice' that would waltz right by your entire team to go secure an objective that you should be holding that the insect doesn't even KNOW about, story wise. There is no way to view your armor as a whole, to compare it to other armor sets. This also doesn't let you save in combat, and the combats are slow and tedious. Matter of fact, I had the FINAL gladiator fight I was in crash on the next to final turn as a waited out the final baddy to blow up (was on a timer in an arena and covered in oil and lit.)This game will make you rage, not because of the difficulty, but because the horrible interface, no real enemy A.I. (I swear they go full retard half the time. "Oh hey, spikes. I should jump up and down on this space over and over again until I keel over!)Overall, go with something more polished that you can get your hands on. Only 5 characters to play as in this one too, so I suggest you roll an archer, considering you don't get to keep one, forcing you to roll an archer (or gimp someone else into an archer) if you want a balanced team. Also, no explanation of half the games mechanics makes this a very annoying venture. Really don't recommend this game.

												the first few fights are all i played, as the game lacks controller and hdtv support... it works, if you dont mind its clunky seeming interface. can't recommend it as i have uninstalled it and won't be playing again, at least not for awhile.    the impression i got from my time with the game is that it's a b-lister, mostly directed at heroes of might and magic fans of the easy-to-please variety. boring maps with just stupid combat, hexagonal set pieces with stupid cover and a stupid skill/attack wheel which is too small to see in 1080p on an hdtv without straining. just the most basic of games whos aim was too low and hit the mark squarely (the 'too low' mark).  if i had played the entire game, my opinion might matter more, but i gave this what i feel was a fair shake, and even submitted recomendations about controller support and the ui, which were apparently ignored (probably because i wasnt♥♥♥♥♥kissy enough, according to one random poster- paraphrased by me of course).      if you are a fan of xcom enemy unknown, you are going to know what you are missing when you play this electronified board game. xcom does all the things right that this game ignores in favor of flashback hour (think ff tactics, but with crappy gameplay). the way you are thrust from one fight to the next is lame, when, given this is 2014, i expected to be able to a) walk around freely or somewhat freely between fights, perhaps with interesting things to do or b) same as 'a'. instead, the story is fed to you between battles and that's it. fight! crappy fight! if the price was 10 dollars, it would excuse the quality in my opinion, but they want to charge like the big boys, they get judged like them.to make a long story one sentence longer, i dont dig it.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												I've clocked about 34 hours with this game at the time of my writing this and have gotten through a fair portion of Chapter 3, so I think it's fairly safe to say that I've formed a solid enough opinion. Simply put, Blackguards turned out to be a rare gem and has already, surprisingly, found its way to my personal list of all time favorites. A few minor glitches aside, it's a lovely blend of dark fantasy storytelling, challenging tactical combat, and flexible charachter development that so far hasn't failed to delight. And it looks quite attractive to boot, with a fantastic UI and lovingly crafted imagery. The cast of lovable rogues that comprise your party is well acted and well written. The story as a whole, at least so far, is engaging without being overbearing, maintaining a light touch while never failing to be consistently interesting. It ain't Shakespeare, but it never aspires to be. Instead, it accomplishes exactly what the early hours of the game promise: it is  a damned enjoyable caper of a kind that perhaps we need more of in the world, a slice of true, unabashed, adventure escapism that somehow evokes the simpler, formative days of a young nerd's nerddom. The subject matter is often dark, but it always feels like an exciting journey above all else. And sometimes that's more than enough to make something worth one's time. While I am sure it's not for everyone, players who enjoy tactical combat, roleplaying games, and being entertained can find plenty to love here.

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												The game itself is about gathering a group of criminals and misfits together to form a band of anti-heroes to take on the bad guys and rescue a damsel in distress.  Its broken down into Chapters which were released through beta piece at a time.  I bought the game in beta and enjoyed playing it immensly.  The battles are turn based so no need to rush and a much better opportunity to win through tactics and strategy.HOWEVER when the full version was released it all went drastically downhill.  Yes there were a few minor bugs that I could live with when it was a beta.  The final release version has a number of major flaws in it.  My existing save game made any new battles unfinishable as you couldnt end a turn - all your characters just stood there with no end turn available.  That's okay I thought, I will start a new game, it will be fun choosing a different character from Chapter 1.  Oh no ....... BIG FAIL.  When you try to start a new game, you get the character creation part fine but once you finish adjusting your new hero you try to start the game and all you get is a black screen and some music.  Immediately I thougt oh it must be a graphics resolution problem, but yet I had just loaded a older saved game and it loaded fine (even if I couldnt advance through the next battle) and indeed it loaded fine again when I tried.  So now I am at an impasse, with no new game possible and all my saved games bugged.I checked the forums and it is not just me with these issues.  And it appears that the publisher is doing nothing to resolve the said issues.So overall this game now has some major flaws that make it unplayable.  Stay away.

number of helpful: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												I am glad I only got this as part of the HumbleBundle (Side note, support Humble).This is a turn based, hexgrid, dungeon crawler, rpg based on a not unheard of tabletop system.It plays like a fan created mod to another game, in every way this game screams its lack of polish, it's terrible design and its aweful assets. This game makes NWN 1+2 look cutting edge*FLAWS*1) Inconsistant Mechanics; in short, they're half baked. An early mechanic is terrain tiles (water is slippery, bushes are flammable etc) and in theory these could make for some more complex tactical play, but sometimes thats not the case, water may just be a watery looking tile, or it may cause you to fall on your♥♥♥♥♥and be prone for a turn. Enemies never use them either, they just move to attack range throw fire, ice and poison.2) Incorrect RNG; this is a tabletop system adapted for the PC, so of course its simmulating (with a pretty bad generator I might add) die rolls under the hood. You get told a percentage chance to hit (and can level up enough to see other stats) but the percentage shown is WRONG. That's right, the game actively lies to you because its number generation system isn't implemented right. 100% chance is actualy 90%, 65% is actualy 40%. You will also see the same resualt consistantly for mid range %, every time I fire an arrow at a humanoid enemy with a 65% chance to hit I would miss without fail. same goes for 50% with melee, this makes me think the random generator isn't so random after all.3) Atrocious Voice acting; Dear gods is it terrible, it's not even laughably bad, the actors are often re-used but its like no-one told them they were doing different characters so everyone they voice sounds identicle. They were also clearly recorded completly seperatly without any lead in or practice because they're all delivered with the same dry detatchment of people with a full frontal lobotomy.4) Poor story telling; The plot may improve as time goes on, but from what I've experienced so far I can already tell you my version "And so it was that the brave ranger stabbed the annoying sidekicks while they slept and went to live away from the continent full of madmen". Honestly it started out bad enough with the giant wolf having killed (or having been eating) a random damsel, you kill the wolf and then get arrested for her murder. The wolf was right there, you kill it, its body is lying on the ground next to the corpse, yet they arrest you for her murder. The rest of the story was following a bread crumb story into a veriaty of linier dungeons, speaking of which.5) Dull Dungeon Design; if you're making a dungeon crawler then you need decent dungeons, so far everything has been a straight line with preset encounters, no element of maze, mystery or surprise. You know you will need to enter each point on the dungeon map, you know that each point is going to have an encounter, and you know that you will want to save scum the hell out of it just to preserve your precious resources.6) Cheap assets; It's ugly. Very Ugly. There is no sense of unifying aesthetic. Everything is the same blocky 3d models with dodgy shadowing, terrain detailing can actualy conflict with mechanics "is that shoreline tile a water tile or a land tile? You won't know till you step on it" the models are barely detailed, only slightly more complex than the 3d models used for CIV V (the ones designed to render quickly at distance and not be looked at too closely). Combine this with a lack luster muZak score and it just doesn't feel good to experience.7) Poor Performance; for a PC game, its not offering much in the way of performance options. You can set nebulous graphics quality but get no fine choice, you can pick a resolution but theres no windowed mode. In game I've seen multiple graphics glitches caused by lighting effects, flickering textures and even the Hex Grid breaking and flashing at the bottom of the screen.

number of helpful: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												For the most part I really like this game. Character development is very deep and interesting for an indie RPG and the combat, while not incredibly nuanced, is fun and challenging. On the other hand however, the game's marketing material tout that you play as a band a criminals and miscreants - even the name of the game hints at this. However the game appears to reward you for being the 'good' guy and punish you by omission for being the 'bad' guy, which is surely counter productive if you want your players to be nasty 'Blackguards'. However that's just my opinion.I can't recommend this game in its current state. There are far too many bugs and design issues that should have been weeded out during testing. Another testament to how pointless and anti-consumer the early access system is. The game is simply not worth the asking price as it is. However once these problems are fixed and perhaps the game comes down in price a little, I'd happily recommend it. At its core it's a very enjoyable game.

												Although it has an interesting idea for a story, the gameplay itself is porrly executed. The fight sequences are repetitive and even on normal mode seemed arbitrarily hard, suggesting not a lot of creativity went into the difficulty just number values. The side quests were uninteresting, the characters were fairly stock and it just had the feeling of an unfinished game in general. Too be fair, I never made it out of Chapter 1, so I can't say it doesn't get better; however, I'm a firm believer in having the beginning of the game be the hook, to entice the gamer to play more. Another reason being: if the first chapter feels unfinished, how is the rest of the game going to feel better? And spells that have a chance of failing? I understand Magic Resists/Immunities creating another level of gameplay, but buff spells that have a 46% chance to fail?  Overall 5/10.

number of helpful: 11 of 21 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												Blackguards is at first an interesting turn based RPG, with combat occuring on premade hex grid based maps. It is interesting because it does away with most of the filler that comes with most every RPG. You do not control your characters in any way outside of combat, you simply shift to a different spot in a city where you can talk to a couple of NPCs and that's it. Outside of towns you travel on the world map by clicking on a selectable point on the map and you are instantly transported to a town, or into combat if you have a quest going on outside of town.This makes the game more fun at the beginning, because you always get to the important parts of the game instantly, that would be the combat and the story. However as you progress through the game the positive turns into a negative because you never start feeling a connection with any of your characters. The only time you control them is in combat and in combat they are simply damage dealing stats.So the game becomes tedious as you start clicking through all the dialogue to just pick up the quests and then you do the quests, almost always by going into combat and you soon realise that the primary things you do in the game are combat and clicking through the story, which I might add is very simple and not at all interesting.The combat at first is satisfying, especially for me since I am a fan of turn based, tile based combat. However you will probably start getting more and more annoyed with it because of its randomness (nearly every action has at least a small chance to fail and it seems to happen more often than it should). And also because of the lack of data while in combat, the battlelog is very nearly completely useless so you have to constantly pay attention to know what is happening, since the camera can jump around a bit if it's a larger map and you can lose track of the enemy actions. And there isn't enough contextual information with the game for when you move your characters. For example I'd like to know if one of my characters will pass through where an enemy can do an attack of opportunity on him, it's true that it isn't too hard to figure out for yourself if that will happen, but honestly you probably won't have the patience to do it after you are controlling 5 characters and have 5+ enemies each taking their own turn. The combat just becomes too slow at that point.Outside of combat you also manage the equipment of each of your characters, which isn't really that interesting because there isn't much choice of weapons or armour and what little there is it's always a straight upgrade or not, so there isn't much thinking involved. Somewhat more involved is improving the skills of your characters, but even that becomes straightforward after a while, since you get an abundance of points to allocate throughout the game and you soon pick up the more desirable skills.So to summarise my main points: no filler makes for a fun start, but it also destroys any potential character building, the story is very simple and not at all interesting, the combat is at first fun but it becomes tedious after a while, not much variety in equipment and finally not enough interesting skills which are worth putting points in. Definitely try the game if you are into turn based, tile based RPGs however be warned that the game can become tedious to play and it did so for me.5 / 10

												I really don't like this game.Confusing for the sake of confusing doesn't make a game complex or interesting.  The character stat screen tells you very little of the impact that your leveling decisions make.  So much of the directional choices you make with characters appears to be hidden.  The hit percentage system, how to recover health/mana efficiently and the effects of decisions are just a few examples of this.I understand that a fair amount of people believe that this hidden veil makes the game more complex, and that they consequently are "more intelligent" because they "figured it out".  I would argue that they wasted their time fiddling with a poorly designed game when they could have been playing a game that isn't a waste of time.I should have played the friggin' demo first.  So for that, I entirely blame myself.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												Would I recommend this game to everybody?  No, not at all.Would I recommend this game to people who I know love Dungeons and Dragons?  Yep! (Only when the game is on sale)This game, as you know, is based on the Darkeye D20 ruleset and is only for those who like stategy turn-based RPGs.  Darkeye is pretty big in Europe from what I understand but I personally never ran a game with it and I wanted to experience the system in an easier to digest way and I felt I got that from this game.  Package that with the honestly funny writing and interesting characters and I enjoyed myself.  Note, however, that this game is entirely about the combat system and RPG progression.  The story is there, but weak, and there is no exploration.  The retail price is too steep for what you get but if you see this game for $15.00 USD or less then I'd suggest picking it up for fans of the genre.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2014
												I know its been a long time in the making, but I have finally defeated the game that is Blackguards. In this game you will be taking on the role of a commoner who is friends with those in high places, especially a princess, but wait, what was that? Oh no the princess has been killed, and you are having the finger pointed at you. This is where the true story begins, and where you will met the first of your companions that will help you through the game with either their strength or their magical abilities.Graphically this game has a couple of small hiccups from time to time, but the overall game gives you the feel of a dark and desolate world that is clinging to the world of old gods. Even though you don't get to actually walk through the towns, you are given 3D scenes that you can click on the action icons to interact with, they all have depth and personality. Another thing is that there is a lot of different models used when it comes to interacting with towns, you are not going to see a lot of repeats, though to be fair its not like any of the towns are overflowing with people. Now as far as the combat graphics are concerned you are placed in a 3D hex-based grid system in which you will be moving from 3/4s side view to top down view so that you can see the whole field and make sure you're not missing anything such as traps or enemies that could be hiding behind walls, plants, etc. I do like the fact that at the bottom of the screen, since this is turn based, that there are images of the enemies, and they have about 3 to 4 stock images so that the enemies have a little bit of variety to them. Sure the models all look the same with the exception of if the enemy is a specific class or sex.The music in the game was very well made, and there were quite a few haunting tunes that as soon as they start I immediately think about the game. The voice acting for the most part was solid as well, there were a couple of over the top performances, but sometimes that's going to happen when try too hard to capture a specific type of character.The controls in the game are pretty straight forward. You are going to use the mouse coupled with WASD for most everything while moving around a map, or on the battlefield. You will of course be using the usual 'i' for inventory and 'c' for character sheet.So this game is pretty deep when it comes to all the little tweaks you can make to your character. There is a good number of spells to cast, there is weapon proficiency to think about, active and passive skills to learn, traits to learn, and of course stats to increase. I have to say that this was always a daunting task for me, but for the most part, once I really got into the game, I had the feel for what was really important for my party to not only survive, but to succeed. You'll also be given weapons, armor, and items galore that you will have to learn to balance. I found out the hard way that putting items or equipment on your characters does not take away much if any of the load in your inventory. So when I had my party fully decked out I almost had no room for much else, unless of course I wanted to play encumbered. That being said it didn't created THAT big of an annoyance.You of course have your own main quest, starting off with you trying to figure out what is really going on, and then of course the twists happen and all hell possibly breaks loose. The thing is that there are a ton of side quests to keep your eyes out for. Now I will say this, until the very end of the game you might lose access to some quests, but have no fear you will regain it later on in the game. There's also many quests that you might miss out on if you don't periodically check in on all the cities. Yes, I understand that that means that you will be dealing with a ton of load screens, but none of them are really unbearable, and when you get to the end of the game, you will thank me for making you search for extra quests.I'm going to be totally honest with you, it took a couple of attempts for me to get into this game, but once I was invested in the game I couldn't stop. I wanted to see what was behind the next bend in the road, what enemies would stand in my way, and of course it stood out to me because I've always loved pencil and paper RPGs, and this felt like a pretty good transition from sitting around a round table with friends and experiencing and adventure. So in the end I have to say that through it all I have to give this game an 8.9 out of 10.

												I'm going to give it a thumbs up, but don't buy this thing at full price. Its a £5 game that is very simplistic. Whoever designed those needs to be taken outside and beaten with a small fish which recently died of natural causes. If you like them too, then get it when its on sale.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												Blackguards is a turn-based fantasy, often dark and frequently humorous, RPG.While still a beta product it is polished and one of the best RPG's I have played in a while. It is a good feeling to catch myself laughing at the well voice acted humorous dialogue, which I haven't experienced to this degree since way back in games such as KOTOR and Jade Empire. Daedalic Entertainment might just be the new old pre-EA BioWare we all fondly remember.Probably the only frustrating thing I experienced was the questionable stated odds of a spell succeeding, but I am also not sure if that percentage was meant to take into account the defender's resistances.I give it a 9 because it is hard to me to envision a better RPG without my mind drifting back to old BioWare. So this is a real user score, not an artificially inflated rating meant to preemptively fend off the incoming 0's from reviewers that found fault in this product.I eagerly await the Chapter 5 release...

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Really love it! This game is misunderstood very often.+ great gameplay (not as good as XCOMs but still nice)+ based on The Dark Eye - refreshing compared to all the games based on D&D+ nice story+ nice quests (and side quests)+ funny interaction in-between the characters+ really good value for money when on sale+ lots of different skills and builds to explore (a bit confusing and overwhelming for beginners though)+ good difficulty (it will be very challenging at times and you will have to change your tactics which worked before)-	Obviously not a huge development budget (they made the best out of it)-	Graphics are nice but could be way better (eg. cutscenes …)-	Skills & talents can be difficult to understand. You’ll probably need to google a bit to understand the different character values.-	Some bugs can be frustrating, eg. when the healer in-between the gladiator fights won’t heal you anymore. There aren’t many but this one made it very hard for me-	Save often. (same as xcom). It could save you time.-	Usability in the stat/spell/… screens could be better, especially when trying to figure out which weapon does more damage.All in all, I can live without the best graphics and animations (like XCOM does superb). I was willing to learn about the skills and mechanics. I accepted the couple of bugs I encountered – it only lead to the game being more difficult but didn’t break the game itself.After reading many negative reviews I think the problem is that this game isn’t like many other games out there, it’s comparable to XCOM but with possibility to skill your characters in a complex way. You can’t save every minute and decisions you made today could be a problem much later. You may have to do some side quests to get the experience to advance. You won’t be able to blindly upgrade every skill and spell there is. You will have to use different tactics. Using Takate with his piercing skill will work awesome most of the time, but if an enemy is immune to piercing you should better have given him some other weapon and skills (I learned this the hard way).Obviously something went wrong during the beta version, because most of the negative reviews are from back then. I didn’t experience many of the problems from back then. If you like turn based games with a lot of strategy involved you’ll probably like this. If you want to kill many monsters with huge firewalls better get path of exile ;)

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												Just finished Blackguards, and it took about 50 hours of play time (this includes the DLC). I am a big fan of turn based tactical RPGs, and Blackguards does very well with the genre. Game difficulty is good, the story (though not amazing) is told well. Graphics are all right, but nothing to write home about. The maps are well designed and do not feel re-used, but the characters look like something from a game that was released over 6 years ago, not just over 6 months ago. Only being able to pick a head out of a choice of 6? I expect that from an indie company, not an established development studio.Enemies are diverse, and they tossed in a good amount of missions with different obectives so the goal it's always just to wipe out the other side. There are times when it does get frustrating as the number of enimies can be many on a map, and we feel like you're spending more time waiting than actually playing the game.When I first started playing Blackguards (during version 1.2) the game was buggy af. Some trainers did not work, some healers did not work (including what that was kind of critical to being able to progress in the game). Thought this was fixed in patch 1.3, but the game still has its bugs. These range from minor annoyance (I swear 25% of the achievements are bugged), to "Why isn't this fixed yet" (Big huge massive spoiler --> Seriously, what's up with Aurelia? I trusted her and sided with her on everything, and in the end she still dies... Not that I even got the achievement for that)Despite the frustration of the bugs, it is a very good game, and one I would say should be added to anyone's list if they like turn based tactical RPGs. Just be aware that it still needs some work.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												Glad I got this in the humble bundle and didn't actually pay for it. After muddling through some quests and putting up with the seriously terrible random number generator (honestly, the RNG is reason enough not to play this game, but I gave it a shot anyways), I was starting to have some fun and enjoy how my party was shaping up. Then I was suddenly rewarded with the death of my best ranged damage dealer for no reason at the start of a boss fight. Not death as in incapacitated in combat, but a scripted event that apparently just takes the char away from you. Gee thanks. Uninstalled.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												The Combat in Blackguards obviously carries this game through all its shortcomings. Each battle-map is different fom the last and has a unique feel to it. Customizing your characters in weapon skills and magic feels rewarding. The most fun comes from figuring how this game actually works, like when the points you just spent make a noticeable difference in the overall challenging battles. Don't expect too much offensive magic, you're better off keeping your mages in a support-role (where they ROCK hard). You probably heard about the interaction with stuff in battles, but that's totally overrated: Wasting a turn to push a box or set something ablaze is rarely worth it. Occasionally this is implemented quite nicely, like trapping something in a cage, but most of the time there's only boxes to push.I hear people drooling over how interesting the characters are, but honestly your party members are *completely* one-sided and sometimes downright dislikeable  (*minor spoiler* Zurburan selling Takate to some slaver...seriously? *spoiler end*). Their is no intruiging background story to them and definetly no progression in personality whatsoever. The story on the other hand is compelling, but since story-specific dialogue is only few and far in between the dominating combat, it's ultimately thin...very thin (if you know DBZ, you lnow what I'm talking about *lol*). The world itself feels a bit on the bland side and the streamlined gameplay leaves little room for Lore or in-depth consideration of your potentially stunning surroundings.The biggest issue here is how barebone the gameplay is. After a fight you basically point&-)click your mouse button a few times to advance the dialogue or move to the interchangeable towns to check on the completely interchangeable merchants and start the next fight. Combat-Dialogue-Click-Combat-Repeat. Kudos for the quest-writing though which I found top notch!So: Combat: AWESOME. The rest: *MEH*. I enjoyed it a lot, also because it is more fast-paced than some of its TBS-brethren.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												Great game!This is my 3-part review of the game. 1. The RPG system, 2. The actual roleplay, 3. The feel of the game. It is worth mentioning that I am a RPG guy with long experience in both Pen and Paper RPG (mostly PF, but also Vampire), and a lot of CRPG. So, naturally, this has an impact on how I liked or disliked the game.1. The roleplaying system The Black Eye is really nice and has a lot of depth and will be candy if you, like me, havent tried it before. I cannot accout for the differences between the pen and paper 4th edition (witch the game mechanic is derived from) and the system Blackguards has implemented. But as far as I am concerned its really nice. Different attributes combinate to give different base statistics - and control how well you fight / use talents / casts spells. There are no levels for characters, insted you gain Adventure Points from combats and finished quests that you either continually spend or save up to spend on more expensive upgrades. It really is a fun system and has similarity with the way Vampire the masquerade works. The turn based tactics is nothing but pure enjoyment!2. The actual roleplaying is somewhat linear. If you like that then no problem. If you want more choice, then it has shortcomings. Things are pretty much set up and you cannot deviate too much from the path. The choices you are given doesnt even have that much impact. For instance one side quest presents you with two identical twins, the one is evil and the other is good - but who is who. In the end, if you chose to root out the good guy OR the bad guy there is no impact on the game other than your own conciousness. (...and honestly, who cares abouth truth when it comes to a book worth 50 ducats?!)3. The acutal feel of the game is, at least to me, awsome. The characters you pick up are rather strange, a paranoid dwarf, a sleezy magician and later on a drug addict elf to name some. But this is what strangley keeps it interesting - actually highly enjoyable. Bugger off with the lawful good paladin that does good at every turn. Here its like "plant unlawful poison at a highly esteemed noble to get him arrested" or "Get a new slavegirl / trophy for the master of the city".To sum up, I really enjoy the game - (not finished yet as this is written) and I see a replay possibility with choosing differet abilities. If you enjoy RPGs and in particular the combat part - this is a game for you.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												A very challenging but interesting tatical RPG with puzzle like battle maps.  And by that I mean the battle map may be unbeatable if you don't figure out which enviornmental trap to use at what time and figuring out how to get the enemy to stand where that trap will be most effective.While the games tatical battles are quit enjoyable due to this puzzle aspect, at the same time can be frustrating because you can end up spending hours having to try and retry a map to only figure out that in addition to the puzzle you already solved but keep losing at you need to rebalance your attack/parry skill points on your weapon type for the fight in addition to solving the puzzle. Which brings me to the only thing I have come across so far in my play that I have disliked about the game, the combination between having no way to gather more xp since each map seems to be doable only once with the fact that there does not seem to be a way to respec where you allocated your xp. I don't mind that the game does not allow you to grind to over level stuff, infact I like that it prevents you from doing that, but it also means that if you spent all your xp in the wrong areas you can reach a point to where a battle becomes unbeatable because you have all the wrong skills win.  Maybe later in the story it allows you to realocate xp at the cost of gold or something, but currently where I am in the story I can see mismanagment of xp making the game unbeatable.With that said, despite this one major consern with the games mechanics dealing with xp I would say it is a very enjoyable though sometimes frustrating game. I would say play this game on normal difficulty and if you get stuck on a puzzle don't feel bad having to turn it down to "easy", because some battle maps are hard to complete even on easy unless you have the perfect build where no xp was spent in the wrong place. And as I say this game is definitly worth picking up might I just suggest that for a few of the puzzles do not sell your torches even if your close on weight limits because you will come across some puzzles that become 100x easier to solve with having more then just a mage to use fire damage.Edit: Also the soundtrack is pretty good, is it $20 of value good, eh, to most people no, but just putting it out there for those debating on picking up the regular edition or the one that comes with the soundtrack.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												Very nice tactical RPG. Characters reminicent of old school bioware characters and the combat is very thought-out. Each battle map is very different from the last in the way it impacts the battle, the developers seem to have spent a long time designing different terrain and objects that have effects. For example in one map there are fire braziers which you can have your characters knock over and they set large patches of oil on fire. In another there is a huge crate hanging from a crane which is operated by the enemy and it moves to block off your advance and knock your characters into the sea if they are in range.Overall if you are looking for an RPG with smart combat and a non-generic story, you could do no better then Blackguards.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												Great hexed based rpg, I really enjoyed this game and would recommend this game to any rpg fan. I have read some of the reviews that were negative and I don't understand how people give this game a negative rating because they thought it was something different. That is their fault for assuming they knew what the game was. If you watched the trailer, it shows what exactly the game is, a hexed based rpg with strategy elements and has a story that has been done before a bunch of times. That being said I enjoyed the game very much and while the story wasn't groundbreaking the story kept my attention, kept me interested enough to see what was going to happen next and did have a few suprises. While the game can be cheap at times during combat, in no way is the combat broken or unfair, you just have to use your head a bit and have a strategy which I can understand might be hard for some people on here. Great game and you should be able to get it on sale but even at full price game is still worth playing.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
												Not for the weak at heart, or those looking for an ARPG.This has got to be one of the hardest RPG's I have played since Pool of Radiance, and I'm tempted to place Blackguards higher in that category just because I know very little about The Dark Eye rules, or at least much less than D&D. And it is great because of it.Graphics are wonderful. They won't blow you away but are for the most part hand drawn and look phenominal. Musical score is excellent. (Really wish I had gotten the SE for the bonuses) The story seems well written, however I have not gotten very far to give a decent opinion about it.The combat may turn some people away as it can be very difficult at times (and since it relies on dice rolls it can be quite rage inducing) but if you show determination (there is no shame in saving and walking away for a bit, might save a monitor and keyboard or 2) the combat is extremely rewarding.If you like The Dark Eye world, or am just a fan of strategey based RPG's, take a long look at this game. Just don't forget to spend time reading details about every skill and stat before you use your AP (like XP) on them, because it can be really easy to screw up a build.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												I could not safely recommend this game to anyone, because I'm not sure who it appeals to, and this is why:1.  It's certainly not for rpg gamers because at its core, Blackguards is nothing more than a series of battles, one after the other, with the 'choice' being where you're going to fight next and a brief respite in 'towns' that are no more than venues to heal and restock between fights.2.  Strategy gamers will find the combat tacky and repetitive because it always comes down to enemies trying to overwhelm you with odds with very simplistic AI.3.  It can't possibly appeal to people looking for a great story because the story is clearly an afterthought.  You get brief looks into your characters pasts between drawn out combat sessions but there's no real development.  Things just happen and force you into the next fight.So really, who was this game made for?

Too often, though, the challenge is presented unfairly, in a way the player can't possibly avoid; taking away your party's gear or positioning your party disadvantageously at the start of a fight are examples.Character building has interesting elements, the way stats and abilities interact and a slider for individual weapons to favor chance to hit or block/parry.But Blackguards as a whole is disappointing.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												I really enjoyed Blackguards. For the same reason I enjoyed other old school CRPGs. It had enough of a story to keep it interesting, the combat was challenging and very tactical, and the character/skill/spell system was deep and interesting. If you like old school CRPGs, I highly recommend this game.What does old school CRPG mean?Graphics - while good for a CRPG are nowhere near cutting edge. If you must play something to justify your $1000 dual video card setup, this game is not it..Sound - voice overs a generally very high quality and clearly done by professionalsCombat - this and the skill system are the meat of any CRPG. Combat is very tactical which makes it fun for me. Anything on the field of combat can be pushed over, destroyed, lit on fire, etc. So for example you can lure your opponents to stand in bushes and cast a fireball on them and not only will they take the initial damage they will take per round damage when the bushes catch fire. Lots and lots of tactical depth and different options make combat fun and at times quite challenging.Character/Skill/Spell System - the other key part of any CRPG. I like The Dark Age system and this game uses that system to create a very deep and interesting set of skills, spells, and attributes to choose from to build your main character and your party of NPCs.Party-based - Old school CRPGs are almost always party-based and this game checks that box with 5 NPCs that join (and in most cases stay) with your group throughout the game. You'll play most of the game with you PC and 3 NPCs.LInear - all good old school CRPGs are linear so they can control the level of opponent you face and unfold the story in a particular way. Books and movies and are linear too and that's what makes them good. I like old school CRPGs to be linear and tell a story and create custome encounters (rather than random ones). Don't get me wrong, I like games like Skyrim, but I generally prefer old school linear CRPGs as the rule and open games like Skyrim as the exception.Story - good enough to keep it interesting.....If you like old school CRPGs don't miss this one.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												Its not a bad game and I do appreciate a developer bringing turn based fantasy RPG's back to the market. However, it just feels like it fell short of its potential. Not to knit pick but starting with the lack of facial customizations. I know its not a big deal but in my opinion, it starts the game off on the wrong foot and goes on from there.there is really no exploration, its extremely linear and predictable as far as the encounters go. The rules of turn based combat are also not the greatest and are very vanilla. No attack from behind bonuses that I could see so you can retreat and not worry about taking a blade to the back if you were standing in a hex next to an enemy.My biggest frustration was in upgrading my gear. Theres RNG involved for what you can loot from battles, so dont count on picking up that axe that this guy just done done whacking at you with for the past 10 minutes.  It just vaporizes apparently leaving you with your trusty ol' starter torch. Weapons and armor cost a lot of money and while you may be able to gear your guy up with a basic sword after the first half dozen encounters, that will be it for quite a while until you can afford more. Meanwhile, wave after wave of baddies wielding swords, shields, axes, armor, bows and arrows will make sure you pull your hair out before you can afford to gear your party adequately enough to fight them.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
												Let me just say off the bat, I'm a huge fan of turn-based rpg's/strategy rpg's. I'm a long-time player of the Heroes of Might and Magic games as well as the King's Bounty games. Now, I'm not saying that these games are the same, they aren't, but they should at least have prepared me for Blackguards. I felt at home in the first few fights, and had a great time leveling and progressing. But, and this is a big but (tee hee), things soon fell apart, and I could not be more disappointed. Here is the list:1) Difficulty Spikes - Elitist players can go on and on about how 'you aren't playing the game right', but this game is fundamentally flawed; with *five pages* of things to use your AP points (think leveling points) on, it becomes *incredibly* easy to spec your character incorrectly, thereby completely and utterly breaking your game, forcing you to start over. Not to mention the fact that the first handful of fights are pretty easy, then suddenly the game shoots up in difficulty. A game like this should have the ability to respec your characters, or to at *least* give you more of a guide on what you should be spending your points on; it's WAY too easy to make a mistake if you're not familiar with the system the game is based on.2) The Fighting - The basics of the battle system seem quite good; all of the things are there to make them an enjoyable experience, however... The sheer amount of missing, dodging, and obviously AI-weighted dice rolls makes this game ridiculous. People can say what they will about "99% chance to hit still isn't 100%", but there are clear patterns of AI-rubber banding/favoritism, making the game *incredibly* frustrating, and fights lasting WAY longer than they should.3) Spellcasting - Never have I played a game where spells fail so. bloody. often. What is the point of playing a mage? Their spells fizzle so incredibly often, and they take so much damage that you're pretty much forced to use bows or crossbows to keep them alive, and, as another reviewer mentioned, the only point in having them around is to heal/buff/debuff. Incredibly disappointing.4) Poor Battle Structuring - I probably should have put this onto the fighting or difficulty section, but I felt it merited it's own section. There are times where you're in a tough battle, but you manage to scrape by by the skin of your teeth, and you're elated. Bask in your rewards! All those AP and Go...wait what? There's ANOTHER battle IMMEDIATELY after? And you don't get a chance to heal? What? You're out of Mana??? Guess that means you're going to have to start the first battle all over again! What's that? There's no potions left? Etc, etc etc. There *needs* to be a way of either warning you of multiple fights in a row(some places like the Gladiator Arena does), or at *least* give you the chance to heal between battles. I'm currently at said gladiator arena and have basically given up on the game and wish I hadn't spent my time and money on it.This game could have been SO much better; the story is interesting enough to keep you going, and the visuals are quite nice, (and DWARVES!) but the poor battle structure, difficulty spikes, flawed dice rolling (Seriously, a weak 'normal' monster dodged me literally 11 times in a row from all four characters..?), and unfortunate leveling flow choices make this a "do not buy unless changes are made". If things are tweaked, this could be a fairly good game, but at it's current state it's nothing more than a frustrating game of blindfolded tennis, (Whiff, whiff, whiff, whiff) and I regret spending money on it.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												This game is based on a tabletop RPG called "The Dark Eye" which will likely be new to even most pencil and dice junkies out there.  It's a turn-based, hex-based, combat-oriented game that presents some of the most wickedly challenging combat scenarios I have had to face in a turn-based game.  The developers have made excellent use of the environment, using traps, environmental effects, hindering terrain, and interactive objects integral to most combats.  This, combined with a wide array of special abilities available through warrior training or spell effects, makes combat very dynamic and challenging.  It can also be very frustrating.  On the plus side, when you lose a tough battle, there is an option to replay the battle from the beginning of the battle, as well as from your last save, so you need not redo extensive amounts of replay to "get to the good stuff."There are four character generation options for this game, three basic with pre-builds of a melee warrior, a hunter archer, and a mage, and fourth option to custom build a character from scratch.  I have tried all four, but recommend trying building a character from scratch only after having tackled at least the first chapter of the game to get an idea of what the game is like.  I wanted to build an archer-mage, and found that it was easier (and you got better abilities) by starting as a straight mage and then investing experience points in archery talents and proficiencies to make up the difference.  The NPCs in the game are fun and all dialogue is voiced.  The dwarven NPC (your first ally) has some really good lines.  The story is VERY linear, literally a "go here and do this" with arrows pointing your next route, which is nice in some ways and very frustrating in others. You get advancement points for every fight and story event, and you get a lot of them.  They accumulate quickly, but you need a ton to advance a stat or skill.  Stats, talents, weapon talents, and spells all rank from 1 to 18, with varying costs from 6 to over 480 to advance to the next level.   Experience comes in multiples of 25, depending on encounter difficulty, with more coming in the later stages of the game. Still, your Special Abilities are what makes your character be able to do extraordinary things like being able to regenerate Astral Points (mana) or Knockdown an opponent in combat.  These are relatively cheap to buy, at around 300 Advancement Points, but Special Abilities often have stat and weapon talent prerequisites that in turn cost advancement points to purchase, which all adds up to more advancement points....  I could not imagine playing "The Dark Eye" without a computer to aid me, especially as your Attack Value, Parry Value, Dodge Value, and Ranged Attack Value are all based on three stats added together and divided by five.  And that every roll in the game is a test against three ability scores.  All of this is handled by the computer and done very nicely in a battlelog that summarizes it in a percentage chance for you.  It can be a bit confusing when your 100% chance to hit misses, because evidently the computer rounds to the nearest %(?) but that's a quibble.  In all this is an exceptionally fun game.  I keep telling myself I am tired of getting my♥♥♥♥♥handed to me by the game and will quit THIS TIME for sure, but in minutes I am back to beat the fight that got me.  It's so linear you can hear the train whistle when you play.  You will have your butt kicked routinely.  But if you like challenging turn-based combat and designing your own characters, you will likely love this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2014
												Before you read the review:1. Ignore Daedalic fanboys who praise and defend their every game with religious zeal.2. This is not a good game, not worth 40€ at all.3. Since I was a little boy, I have played A LOT of turn-based games (from Jagged Alliance, Silent Storm, Heores, Disciples, Age of Wonders to the newer titles like Frozen Synapse, Xcom, Expeditions Conquistadors and more) and they are probably my favourite genre.Oh boy, where to start? On paper this game looks fantastic and fools you into thinking that you are in for a exciting experience. You are not. Every aspect of this game is lackadaisical, poorly executed and underdeveloped. Let's take a look at each component of Blackguards:Character creation:You create your character from three available classes: warrior, ranger and mage. However, classes don't determine anything as you can specialise in anything you want. I choose to be a dual-wielding fighter who helps with buffs and some offensive spells. I quickly abandoned that idea, because the game heavily favors archers and maybe heavy-hitting warriors. Not really adequate for an RPG, is it? The battles became impossible and I was literally forced to respec and become an archer. Also, certain skills are a must, other are a bust.The world:On your quest you travel across the land, visit different cities. Each city/town is represented by an image on which points of intrests are clickable (tavern, blacksmith, healer). Those town screens are pretty but mostly unremarkable and you only visit them on some of many, MANY fetch quests. In fact, everything in this game is point and click (like in adventure games), which creates a very static feel.The universe itself will be familiar to players that have played other Daedalic games (Chains of Satinav, Memoria etc) - the Dark Eye universe. As with many other games by this developer, there are references to the their previous entries here and there and you may encounter characters that appeared somewhere else (ie a certain NPC from Chains of Satinav can be found in Blackguards). It's definitely a nice touch.Your party:Before the game was released, there was a lot of hype concering your party - a bunch of outlaws and criminals. Ugh, not really. Playing Baldur's Gate 2 and taking Viconia, Edwin and Korgan is waaaay more badass. You never get the feeling that they are really on the run, criminals with disgusting past. No, nothing like that. Half of your party (which is fixed, you can't choose between a bunch of characters) is bland (main character included), the other half is fleshed out, but not spectacular.Dialogues:The dialogues in Blackguards serve one purpose only - to push the story forward (or give you fetch quests). As a player, you just click every option of the dialogue (not a lot of them) and very rarely can choose between different answers. Voice acting is hit or miss. Dialogues are done through the dialogue boxes and again, they feel extremely static.Story:As for the story, it is indeed intriguing. Side quests are a grind - you just run errands and they always end up with a fight. Main story is what drives you forward. The ending may be a bit underwhelming but I won't spoil anything.Items, loot:Forget it. Basic weapons and every once in a while their magical variations, which are still unremarkable and differ only slightly from the ordinary equipment. Combat:Ah, Blackguards is supposed to feature a deep, dynamic turn-based combat. Well, I can tell you it is turn-based. It's nowhere near 'deep' nor 'dynamic'. Out of advertised 40 abilities I used maybe 5 throughout the entire game. Out of 90 spells (wait, what? where?) I used 10 at best. The combat just fails to be exciting or rewarding, despite the environment interaction which becomes repetitive and not worth the trouble. The saving grace here is that each battlefield is special - you will not find two the same, reused battlemaps and that's a treat. The challenge (beware of sudden and unexpected difficulty spikes) comes not from tough opponents but from a vast array of cheap shots and irritating design choices the developers throw at you when it's time to ramp up the difficulty. Examples: you fight a giant lily and a wood troll. Giant lily takes control over your character and draws him into the water where several tentacles (they come out of nowhere) rip him to shreds in a matter of few turns. Now, giant lily grows in the water - if you want to approach it with you fighters and beat it to death, forget it. The tetnacles will block your way and pound you. So you figure to stay on land, as it's a viable option to defeat the lily. You use your archers (did I tell you the game favors archers?) and have 60% to hit the lily. Out of 16 shot, 4 connected. I counted. Some of the hits do no damage (don't know why, it's random). Magic should work, but usually does no or very little damage. Sounds fun? Well, don' forget about the wood troll knocking your guys down every turn. Yay.Another example. You have to hold on and kill 27 zombies that just keep spawning. You try to hit a zombie, have 75% chance to hit and surprise, surprise you miss 4 of your 5 blows (then you read 'Zombie dodges the shot masterly'). Then you hit the damn thing with magical short swords and do 3 damage. Zombie retailiates and does 14 damage with his bare hands. Logic anyone? Whatever. Bottom line is - combat is rarely interesting, mostly infuriating and frustraing. And this is supposed to be the main point of the game... Ah yes, there are also stealth maps, but they are flat out awkward.Graphics:The town screens are indeed a joy to look and the world map is arfully drawn. Other than that, the graphics is mediocre and so are the animations. Whan characters speak their jaws are flapping unnatrually, but you won't see that other than in cutscenes.Music:Ah, yes. Apart from the story, the only strong point of Blackguards. The music always accompany you and creates a curious mood as you progress through the story. It's always in the background, never imposes itself, and yet you remember the motifs and find yourself humming the melodies.Immersion:Unfortuantely, I was never immersed. I blame the overall static feel of the game, the point and click nature of it. There is no fluidity, as the game is chopped by frequent loading screens as you jump between towns. The lack of environments to explore (I'm not expecting Skyrim here, just your ordinary Icewind Dale locations), lack of movement is what absolutely kills this game. Maybe it would be salvagable if the conversations where meaty and interesting, but the interactions between characters are limited to few lines.Bottom line:Do not buy this game unless you are absolutely desperate for a turn-based combat game set in a fantasy world. It's annoying and frustrating. Tell you what. Save your money and buy Divinity Original Sin instead. Or go play Jagged Alliance. Blackguards is a waste of your time and money.Score: 2/10PS.Man, this game was bad!PS 2.Before purchase, try the demo out.Peace.
