content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												man seems to me alot of these reviews are harsh on this game. i have played many tactical strategy games over the years and this is a pretty good one in all parts.  I think the thing most people have a hard time with in this one is the dificulty of the game and them not really explaining on how attacks work. like in the percent chance to hit someone.  but if you do a little research you can figure out how to make it easy. like all spells have three attributes allocated to them. so if you want to cast a spell that has agi, cha, const then you would want all 3 of those stats to be high. the higher they are and the higher the spell lvl is the better chance you have to hitting someone with them.for rng and mele you want have the stat to be high to hit. for range its dex for mele its str. think there are also others that help. then you need the weapon you are using good also. plus therre is also a slider on the weapon. that lets you decide if you want to defend or attack better. so if you are on defend on the item you wont hit as often or as hard. so set it to attack.all in all i think this is a decent game worth a shot. at least on the demo for anyone who has an interest in tactical strategy rpgs.  i got it on sale and im not disapointed at all. also the difficulty can be a little harsh you will not win a battle the first time everytime. but im not one for easy games i loved temple of elemental evil and others that are harsh.

												It's a good game in general,Positives:1) Long Playtime; I got around 40 hours out of my first playthrough, got half the achievments2) Story and Characters are good, interesting and likeable3) Voice Actors and Music are both great4) Complexity of Character Building and Fighting is something I hope for in most RPG's and I got it in this one, lots of stats to invest points in and to costumize your characters5) Sometimes the dice won't roll your way, sometimes they do, it's as close to a D&D experience in a modern Video Game you will ever getNegatives:1) Loading times when you enter a city, or go through areas in a city are attrocious and can get really on your nerves when your try to check NPC's for side quests2) Unbalanced Encounters, Not that big of a deal but sometimes you can get your♥♥♥♥♥kicked out of the blue which can be frustrating3) Encounters that don't tell you what the goal is4) Slow Battle System, the more enemies there are the longer it takes for everyone to finish their turn which can♥♥♥♥♥♥me off5) Lame EndingTips for Beginners:1) Choose Hunter as your MC; You won't get one for 80% of the game2) Sword and Shield sucks, Spears are great and so are 2 one-handed Weapons3) Always carry a blunt weapon with your chars to switch to when you encounter UNDEAD enemies, they are immune to piercing dmg4) Train Perception high with your quickest Character(With highest initiative, mine is Takate) and use it at the begin of every fight to check for traps5) Spells to lvl for your Mage: Haste to lvl 13 and cast it on your best fighters, it rly helps and is srsly good; Also I like Fireball @lvl 3 and the AOE Spell the 2nd Mage gets can be rly great coz it knocks down enemies.6) Try to push "Astral Energy Regeneration" as soon as you can, helps out alot too.

Posted: February 1, 2015
												Blackguards has issues. As an avid fan of turn based games, this is severely lacking. Inconsistency is the biggest flaw. The game is seemingly okay for the first few battles however soon after, it quickly becomes a reload and try again, 12-20 times. Go to a prior save, make adjustments and try again. Too often, for instance, my mage character with 80% and above chance to heal fails, too often failure to use the environment will make a battle impossible. Too often your characters will miss leaving foes drooling at another chance to make you reload.I had high hopes for the game. The menus are not great, the story is rather drab, but it only felt horrible when every map because a reload the game fest. If you're looking for turn based... I HIGHLY suggest looking elsewhere.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2014
												Before you read the review:1. Ignore Daedalic fanboys who praise and defend their every game with religious zeal.2. This is not a good game, not worth 40€ at all.3. Since I was a little boy, I have played A LOT of turn-based games (from Jagged Alliance, Silent Storm, Heores, Disciples, Age of Wonders to the newer titles like Frozen Synapse, Xcom, Expeditions Conquistadors and more) and they are probably my favourite genre.Oh boy, where to start? On paper this game looks fantastic and fools you into thinking that you are in for a exciting experience. You are not. Every aspect of this game is lackadaisical, poorly executed and underdeveloped. Let's take a look at each component of Blackguards:Character creation:You create your character from three available classes: warrior, ranger and mage. However, classes don't determine anything as you can specialise in anything you want. I choose to be a dual-wielding fighter who helps with buffs and some offensive spells. I quickly abandoned that idea, because the game heavily favors archers and maybe heavy-hitting warriors. Not really adequate for an RPG, is it? The battles became impossible and I was literally forced to respec and become an archer. Also, certain skills are a must, other are a bust.The world:On your quest you travel across the land, visit different cities. Each city/town is represented by an image on which points of intrests are clickable (tavern, blacksmith, healer). Those town screens are pretty but mostly unremarkable and you only visit them on some of many, MANY fetch quests. In fact, everything in this game is point and click (like in adventure games), which creates a very static feel.The universe itself will be familiar to players that have played other Daedalic games (Chains of Satinav, Memoria etc) - the Dark Eye universe. As with many other games by this developer, there are references to the their previous entries here and there and you may encounter characters that appeared somewhere else (ie a certain NPC from Chains of Satinav can be found in Blackguards). It's definitely a nice touch.Your party:Before the game was released, there was a lot of hype concering your party - a bunch of outlaws and criminals. Ugh, not really. Playing Baldur's Gate 2 and taking Viconia, Edwin and Korgan is waaaay more badass. You never get the feeling that they are really on the run, criminals with disgusting past. No, nothing like that. Half of your party (which is fixed, you can't choose between a bunch of characters) is bland (main character included), the other half is fleshed out, but not spectacular.Dialogues:The dialogues in Blackguards serve one purpose only - to push the story forward (or give you fetch quests). As a player, you just click every option of the dialogue (not a lot of them) and very rarely can choose between different answers. Voice acting is hit or miss. Dialogues are done through the dialogue boxes and again, they feel extremely static.Story:As for the story, it is indeed intriguing. Side quests are a grind - you just run errands and they always end up with a fight. Main story is what drives you forward. The ending may be a bit underwhelming but I won't spoil anything.Items, loot:Forget it. Basic weapons and every once in a while their magical variations, which are still unremarkable and differ only slightly from the ordinary equipment. Combat:Ah, Blackguards is supposed to feature a deep, dynamic turn-based combat. Well, I can tell you it is turn-based. It's nowhere near 'deep' nor 'dynamic'. Out of advertised 40 abilities I used maybe 5 throughout the entire game. Out of 90 spells (wait, what? where?) I used 10 at best. The combat just fails to be exciting or rewarding, despite the environment interaction which becomes repetitive and not worth the trouble. The saving grace here is that each battlefield is special - you will not find two the same, reused battlemaps and that's a treat. The challenge (beware of sudden and unexpected difficulty spikes) comes not from tough opponents but from a vast array of cheap shots and irritating design choices the developers throw at you when it's time to ramp up the difficulty. Examples: you fight a giant lily and a wood troll. Giant lily takes control over your character and draws him into the water where several tentacles (they come out of nowhere) rip him to shreds in a matter of few turns. Now, giant lily grows in the water - if you want to approach it with you fighters and beat it to death, forget it. The tetnacles will block your way and pound you. So you figure to stay on land, as it's a viable option to defeat the lily. You use your archers (did I tell you the game favors archers?) and have 60% to hit the lily. Out of 16 shot, 4 connected. I counted. Some of the hits do no damage (don't know why, it's random). Magic should work, but usually does no or very little damage. Sounds fun? Well, don' forget about the wood troll knocking your guys down every turn. Yay.Another example. You have to hold on and kill 27 zombies that just keep spawning. You try to hit a zombie, have 75% chance to hit and surprise, surprise you miss 4 of your 5 blows (then you read 'Zombie dodges the shot masterly'). Then you hit the damn thing with magical short swords and do 3 damage. Zombie retailiates and does 14 damage with his bare hands. Logic anyone? Whatever. Bottom line is - combat is rarely interesting, mostly infuriating and frustraing. And this is supposed to be the main point of the game... Ah yes, there are also stealth maps, but they are flat out awkward.Graphics:The town screens are indeed a joy to look and the world map is arfully drawn. Other than that, the graphics is mediocre and so are the animations. Whan characters speak their jaws are flapping unnatrually, but you won't see that other than in cutscenes.Music:Ah, yes. Apart from the story, the only strong point of Blackguards. The music always accompany you and creates a curious mood as you progress through the story. It's always in the background, never imposes itself, and yet you remember the motifs and find yourself humming the melodies.Immersion:Unfortuantely, I was never immersed. I blame the overall static feel of the game, the point and click nature of it. There is no fluidity, as the game is chopped by frequent loading screens as you jump between towns. The lack of environments to explore (I'm not expecting Skyrim here, just your ordinary Icewind Dale locations), lack of movement is what absolutely kills this game. Maybe it would be salvagable if the conversations where meaty and interesting, but the interactions between characters are limited to few lines.Bottom line:Do not buy this game unless you are absolutely desperate for a turn-based combat game set in a fantasy world. It's annoying and frustrating. Tell you what. Save your money and buy Divinity Original Sin instead. Or go play Jagged Alliance. Blackguards is a waste of your time and money.Score: 2/10PS.Man, this game was bad!PS 2.Before purchase, try the demo out.Peace.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2014
												Daedalic's first attempt in the RPG genre is a solid one. An experienced software house, mostly famous for their many graphic adventures, managed to bring us a game which delivers a grand amount of turn-based tactical rpg goodness, focusing on combat, even if it doesn't shine in terms of storytelling and pure roleplaying. What is mainly fine with the game is the fact that it never gets boring, since every battle is different, well thought and characterized, other than being intelligent for example making the battlefield often interactive with the party characters skills: a mix of variety and possibilities with a functional adaptation of the TDE combat system. Personally enjoyed all over the long duration of the campaign, planning and battling with satisfaction on a game that needs attention and ability over situations thankfully non-easy nor banal. Dealing with improvements on the less considered sides of this role-playing game, like story, characters history or C&C, would make a perfect sequel for an already substantial and well-directed game.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												This game is based on a tabletop RPG called "The Dark Eye" which will likely be new to even most pencil and dice junkies out there.  It's a turn-based, hex-based, combat-oriented game that presents some of the most wickedly challenging combat scenarios I have had to face in a turn-based game.  The developers have made excellent use of the environment, using traps, environmental effects, hindering terrain, and interactive objects integral to most combats.  This, combined with a wide array of special abilities available through warrior training or spell effects, makes combat very dynamic and challenging.  It can also be very frustrating.  On the plus side, when you lose a tough battle, there is an option to replay the battle from the beginning of the battle, as well as from your last save, so you need not redo extensive amounts of replay to "get to the good stuff."There are four character generation options for this game, three basic with pre-builds of a melee warrior, a hunter archer, and a mage, and fourth option to custom build a character from scratch.  I have tried all four, but recommend trying building a character from scratch only after having tackled at least the first chapter of the game to get an idea of what the game is like.  I wanted to build an archer-mage, and found that it was easier (and you got better abilities) by starting as a straight mage and then investing experience points in archery talents and proficiencies to make up the difference.  The NPCs in the game are fun and all dialogue is voiced.  The dwarven NPC (your first ally) has some really good lines.  The story is VERY linear, literally a "go here and do this" with arrows pointing your next route, which is nice in some ways and very frustrating in others. You get advancement points for every fight and story event, and you get a lot of them.  They accumulate quickly, but you need a ton to advance a stat or skill.  Stats, talents, weapon talents, and spells all rank from 1 to 18, with varying costs from 6 to over 480 to advance to the next level.   Experience comes in multiples of 25, depending on encounter difficulty, with more coming in the later stages of the game. Still, your Special Abilities are what makes your character be able to do extraordinary things like being able to regenerate Astral Points (mana) or Knockdown an opponent in combat.  These are relatively cheap to buy, at around 300 Advancement Points, but Special Abilities often have stat and weapon talent prerequisites that in turn cost advancement points to purchase, which all adds up to more advancement points....  I could not imagine playing "The Dark Eye" without a computer to aid me, especially as your Attack Value, Parry Value, Dodge Value, and Ranged Attack Value are all based on three stats added together and divided by five.  And that every roll in the game is a test against three ability scores.  All of this is handled by the computer and done very nicely in a battlelog that summarizes it in a percentage chance for you.  It can be a bit confusing when your 100% chance to hit misses, because evidently the computer rounds to the nearest %(?) but that's a quibble.  In all this is an exceptionally fun game.  I keep telling myself I am tired of getting my♥♥♥♥♥handed to me by the game and will quit THIS TIME for sure, but in minutes I am back to beat the fight that got me.  It's so linear you can hear the train whistle when you play.  You will have your butt kicked routinely.  But if you like challenging turn-based combat and designing your own characters, you will likely love this game.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												I am not sure why this is getting so many negative reviews. I have played a pretty good amount of this game so far. Is it the best? No. However it is not bad by any means.If you like turn based RPGs then this game is great. People REALLY should research games before they buy them. The game has a little bit of a steep learning curve but if you are even a semi-decent gamer and are familiar with TBS games then that should not be a problem at all.Personally I am REALLY REALLY sick of all the games nowdays hand holding you and making things so simple. What some say about the leveling and skills/stat points is true however. There is really not alot of explaination about how to do this. Trial and error is all you have. I ended up starting the game over a few times before I really started to figure out how to do it properly.The story is not the greatest and neither is the gameplay or graphics. However I have had alot of fun with this game. I like the darker story. I like that your crew is not a bunch of goody goody types. The movement and cities are pretty bland but that is ok beacuse the fights are alot of fun IMO. The enviornmental parts of the battles are very cool. I like that you have to open cells to create a distraction and get away from the guards. It was way cool that I had to lead the troll into some flammable gas and then shoot him with a fireball to do a ton of damage. Cutting the rope and dropping a chandelier on some  guards was pretty damn cool. There is alot to like in this game if you can get around the mediocre graphics and horrid voice acting!If you are looking for a AAA super polished graphical game this is not for you. If you like a decent story, dont really care about graphics, and you like TBS RPGs then this is for you!Overall this is a pretty good game. There are not alot of TBS RPGs out there to pick from and if your a big fan of that genre then you will like this game.Divinity: Original Sin is a better choice IMO but that is still in Alpha and has ALOT of bugs. I bought both of them and I really enjoy them both.Again this is not the prettiest game. The voice acting and cut scenes are ATROCIOUS!!!!! But who cares as long as the combat and RPG elements are good.Graphics: 5/10Sound: 5/10Story: 5/10Gameplay: 7/10Overall: 6/10Like I said its not the greatest game out there. But in this genre there is really not much to choose from. TBS RPGs are probably my favorite type of game and this game does an above average job.Buy it if you are like me and really jonesing for a TBS RPG!

content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												Blackguards is a hexagonal turn based strategy game with some fun elements to it. The story line is fairly interesting, with many offshoots in the plot to keep you entertained.The graphics are nice and clean and the voice acting surprisingly good, with many humorous lines from the characters as they play off of one another during your adventures together. The learning curve isn't too harsh and the tutorial helps a lot during the start.However it can at times be a little punishing and you will find yourself hitting the restart button on quite a few occasions, especially any levels involving poison, to which there seems to be many. In my opinion the mechanic is used maybe a little too much throughout the game and the effects can start to become a little irritating, so spec to counter this when you get a chance. There are a few bugs, but nothing I would consider to be game breaking, so all in all Blackguards is worth the buy, but I would recommend waiting for it to be on sale and avoid the full price. I picked this up discounted and am more than satisfied with what I got for the money.

												This game is such a tight experience.  Combat is refreshingly good, and it offers a healthy amount of customization for your characters, with multiple viable builds.  The story is sufficient to get you to keep moving, but it's no Planescape: Torment (which is fine by me).  With all of the other RPGs on the horizon and in Early Access, I took a bit of a flyer on this one, and I'm really glad I did.  I don't know who these devs are or where they came from, but they have created a really good game here.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												I decided to give this game a go and said to myself "I'm gonna finish this one"...oh, how I was wrong. The world is interesting, but it gets lost when you fight very samey enemies all the time. Story could be interesting if characters wouldn't change their motivation every now and then, yet they keep being predictable. Also the world is very limited to a 1-3 screens per town.Battles could be fun - the system has some neat ideas, enviroment has traps and cool strategic placements, but you very rarely get to use that, since you have to attack or you get surrounded and can't move. But the major flaw is that the game FEELS UNFAIR all the time (even when maybe it is not really). Instead of making battles interesting, the game more than once takes your whole inventory and offers you bad equipment in exchange, then you have to battle and find out that enemies in that arena are better equipped than you.Attack chances are random at best  (a number like 90% chance don't mean anything in this game). Damage you inflict is always small unless your character has fully invested in one weapon skill (which I had to change for one character because it had the same setup as my main character and then spent many hours inflicting 3x less damage than the enemies). The whole unfairness also applies to experience point requirements - some skills seem very out of reach (I can see the options ahead, but what I can actually afford/choose is 1-2 options and get stuck with that for hours). "Special" attacks make very little difference most of the time and are in no way interesting.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												I enjoyed Blackguards. The gameplay is fantastic and the level design is great. Unlike most of the RPG I played, this game is brutal*: the heroes are either undernumbered or weak compared to the enemies and you have to take advantage of the environment in order to win. On top of that, my mage, the squishy guy with low initiative was always in the wrong spot at the start of the fight. On the other hand, some fights (only a few tho) were simply bad designed: in one of them I had to fight a mage and a tank with my mage and tank who's weapon was poisoned. They were way better than my guys and there was no trap, no object, no catch on that map. It took me about an hour to win and it was only possible with the help of the RNG gods. I did not like the story. The "RPG" aspect is ok. There are a few weapon categories with unique features and access to a number of skills, but there are only a few weapons in each category**. My main character used a spear, but later on the spears look more like strange polearms. I wanted to see a partisan spear as endgame weapon, instead of a mace with a spike mounted on a big stick. The spells are interesting. I like how they gain a new effect when you level them. The character development*** is similar to NWN / Drakensang. However, due to the low numbers of characters in the party some characters need to go hybrid and fill multiple slots. They ask 40euro for it. Well, that is too much - 20euro is more like a fair price for this game.* I have only played on the hard difficulty; don't know about the others;** I don't count this as a "con";*** attributes and how they influence the gameplay

content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
												Not for the weak at heart, or those looking for an ARPG.This has got to be one of the hardest RPG's I have played since Pool of Radiance, and I'm tempted to place Blackguards higher in that category just because I know very little about The Dark Eye rules, or at least much less than D&D. And it is great because of it.Graphics are wonderful. They won't blow you away but are for the most part hand drawn and look phenominal. Musical score is excellent. (Really wish I had gotten the SE for the bonuses) The story seems well written, however I have not gotten very far to give a decent opinion about it.The combat may turn some people away as it can be very difficult at times (and since it relies on dice rolls it can be quite rage inducing) but if you show determination (there is no shame in saving and walking away for a bit, might save a monitor and keyboard or 2) the combat is extremely rewarding.If you like The Dark Eye world, or am just a fan of strategey based RPG's, take a long look at this game. Just don't forget to spend time reading details about every skill and stat before you use your AP (like XP) on them, because it can be really easy to screw up a build.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												Its not a bad game and I do appreciate a developer bringing turn based fantasy RPG's back to the market. However, it just feels like it fell short of its potential. Not to knit pick but starting with the lack of facial customizations. I know its not a big deal but in my opinion, it starts the game off on the wrong foot and goes on from there.there is really no exploration, its extremely linear and predictable as far as the encounters go. The rules of turn based combat are also not the greatest and are very vanilla. No attack from behind bonuses that I could see so you can retreat and not worry about taking a blade to the back if you were standing in a hex next to an enemy.My biggest frustration was in upgrading my gear. Theres RNG involved for what you can loot from battles, so dont count on picking up that axe that this guy just done done whacking at you with for the past 10 minutes.  It just vaporizes apparently leaving you with your trusty ol' starter torch. Weapons and armor cost a lot of money and while you may be able to gear your guy up with a basic sword after the first half dozen encounters, that will be it for quite a while until you can afford more. Meanwhile, wave after wave of baddies wielding swords, shields, axes, armor, bows and arrows will make sure you pull your hair out before you can afford to gear your party adequately enough to fight them.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												RNG is godawful. There is no way to properly strategize, because you can miss a 90% chance to hit 3 times in row. It's all luck and restarting a battle hoping the next time it all works out better. I finally gave up on this game when, in the second chapter, after a long, long series of battles, I had finally defeated the boss and only had to kill off the trash mobs when a gamebreaking bug made me unable to move or act with one of my characters. I couldn't even have him wait or end his turn.Even if you got this game for free, don't waste your time.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2014
												Stale and unappealing, but it's close. If I could give a thumbs-sideways, I would.Actual battles can be enjoyable, offering challenge and rewarding strategy. Too often, though, the challenge is presented unfairly, in a way the player can't possibly avoid; taking away your party's gear or positioning your party disadvantageously at the start of a fight are examples.Character building has interesting elements, the way stats and abilities interact and a slider for individual weapons to favor chance to hit or block/parry.But Blackguards as a whole is disappointing.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												I really enjoyed Blackguards. For the same reason I enjoyed other old school CRPGs. It had enough of a story to keep it interesting, the combat was challenging and very tactical, and the character/skill/spell system was deep and interesting. If you like old school CRPGs, I highly recommend this game.What does old school CRPG mean?Graphics - while good for a CRPG are nowhere near cutting edge. If you must play something to justify your $1000 dual video card setup, this game is not it..Sound - voice overs a generally very high quality and clearly done by professionalsCombat - this and the skill system are the meat of any CRPG. Combat is very tactical which makes it fun for me. Anything on the field of combat can be pushed over, destroyed, lit on fire, etc. So for example you can lure your opponents to stand in bushes and cast a fireball on them and not only will they take the initial damage they will take per round damage when the bushes catch fire. Lots and lots of tactical depth and different options make combat fun and at times quite challenging.Character/Skill/Spell System - the other key part of any CRPG. I like The Dark Age system and this game uses that system to create a very deep and interesting set of skills, spells, and attributes to choose from to build your main character and your party of NPCs.Party-based - Old school CRPGs are almost always party-based and this game checks that box with 5 NPCs that join (and in most cases stay) with your group throughout the game. You'll play most of the game with you PC and 3 NPCs.LInear - all good old school CRPGs are linear so they can control the level of opponent you face and unfold the story in a particular way. Books and movies and are linear too and that's what makes them good. I like old school CRPGs to be linear and tell a story and create custome encounters (rather than random ones). Don't get me wrong, I like games like Skyrim, but I generally prefer old school linear CRPGs as the rule and open games like Skyrim as the exception.Story - good enough to keep it interesting.....If you like old school CRPGs don't miss this one.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												It could be a really nice game but it's plagued with bugs. Unfortunately it's the kind of game that will irritate you to a point where you just don't want to play it anymore - and it's not because of it's difficulty level, which is really nice. Two big issues here are the constant game freezes and bad math for hit calculations. 100% chance to hit? Sorry, you've missed three times in a row!  These kind of things happen all the time in this game. I don't mind having crappy chance to hit in the beginning, as long as I'm correctly informed about it. About game freezes, it appears that enemy spellcasters tend to try to take some action that they're not allowed to in their turn, hence not finishing it so battle moves on. I've faced TWO spellcasters and both times I had to reload a LOT, because the aforementioned problem happened like 80% of the times. There's no screen rotation on battles. The official excuse is that "it's because of the way the levels are built". C'mon, guys... This game's visuals are not that intricate, some rotating functions would help a LOT, specially when scenarios have so many "dead spots" where you can't properly see enemies. I think that Blackguards developers might actually be talented and competent, however this is not a good job. As a turn-based strategy fan, I've played many smaller games that were much more satisfying and polished.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2014
Super satisfying tactical combat, but a little short of brilliantThe meat of this game is developing your characters and engaging in challenging tactical combat. I played on hard difficulty and it was no joke. You know you have a winner when your first time through a fight feels like a hopeless battle you can’t possibly win, but coming back for another try (or 5) you start to see a path and sure enough you snatch victory from the claws of your enemies. I found myself saying a lot of “No no no!! and Yes yes yes!!” and that is a good sign indeed.A decent system for equipment and hard choices to make for what kind of characters to develop and when make for pretty reasonable strategic choices between fights. I never quite felt like re-starting to make different choices but I switched focus and direction a few times as I learned what worked and what didn’t. Better yet, different fights call for very different approaches and play to the strengths and weaknesses of your character. There is no one right answer or best build, just a lot of different good choices you need to learn how to utilize. The only mistake you can make is not learning the mechanics and failing to do any specialization at all.On the other hand, while the voice acting is fine and the writing is decent, I was never all that compelled by either the characters or the story. It was never daft or cliche or bad in any way, but rarely all that awesome or intriguing. There are minor choices to be made here and there but rarely do they feel all that impactful and while the order you do quests is often open, there is rarely a feeling it matters all that much either.The game is worth the money, especially if you love tactical combat and like a stiff challenge. If you are looking for a story driven RPG or something with a feeling of grand adventure, this might not be your game.

												I liked the idea behind the story of Blackguards; there aren't enough games out there with 'evil' characters, however this game had a really slow story with frustrating blockages from not being as overpowered as the game expects and no way to 'grind' up the levels. Only worth playing if you are *really really* into repetivie turn-based combat

content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
												I think that this game can best be compared to playing chess.  Chess is often a slow game and to play it you have to think.  Sometimes you have to put several minutes of thought into a move before making it.  This game is like that but you have to put a fair amount of time and thought into almost EVERY move that you make.  When I was younger, I liked chess a great deal and I probably would have liked this game more.  But I havent played chess in years and find this game to be agonizingly slow to play.   The graphics are fairly decent, the voice acting is ok, the combat IA is pretty good but its just way too dang slow!  Im glad that I got it on sale for 3.99.  I may come back to it and play it some more on a rainy day sometime but probably not.  Actually, I havent played 2 hours yet.  I should just get a refund...PS: BTW, I put "no" for this game based on whether or not I would recomend it to myself.  Nope!  But folks who like turn based games should go for it.  They would probably enjoy it very much.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
												I don't get it why its size is 17 GB, cause the graphics are far from sophisticated. And I don't get it why its price is so high, cause its gameplay is mediocre at best.There's one basic, huge condition that could "make or break" when it comes to turn-based combats: don't let the random factor be too important. That's the same hugely important condition this game failes completely to fulfill. It says 95% yet it feel like 50, and when it says 90%... well, you'd better skip it, you're screwed anyway. Using the "try again" button a couple of times after some lost battles proved nothing but the fact that random is all that matters. Only based on random I nearly won, I clearly won, or I badly lost the very same battles. Only based on randomness, and not on the decisions I made. And that's simply not Ok.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												Blackguards is an interesting concept with quite poor execution. The main problem is that it's built around an obscure role playing system that is both punishing and not fun. It's based on the Dark Eye role playing system in Germany. It's a fairly punishing system that gives too much power to the RNG and not enough to the player. What do I mean by that?It's just no fun having a 50/50 chance of casting a spell fail 6 or 7 times in a row and that costing you a battle. It's luck, not tactics or skill, that will get you through battles and luck doesn't make for a fun game. The "tactics" are minimal and your choices in leveling a character are severely restricted because if you don't take certain paths with certain classes you simply won't be able to proceed through the battles. This is the core problem with the game. It's like playing chess with an RNG. It simply defeats the purpose.The game wants you to play it one way. It discourages experimentation and creativity while demanding that you play it the "right" way with the "right" skill and classes or woe to the user. This isn't a strategy game but more of a puzzle and one that's not fun to piece together. Either you read a guide or you will be forced to start over at some point. That's just really poor design.As for the other aspects of the game, consider me unimpressed. The voice acting is truly horrible and the plotline is both forgettable and so dumb as to be insulting to the player. You can't rotate the camera and often enemies are obscured. The graphics are decent but nothing fantastic. The videos stutter and tend to happen too often. When it comes right down to it, there's really nothing redeeming about Blackguards beyond the fact that when you finally uninstall it you'll clear up 17GB of hard drive space to use for something better. You'll get better tactics out of King's Bounty and Divinity: Original Sin than this game plus better exploration and more personality. Save your money, buy those and you'll have far more fun than you would with this game.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
Blackguards by Daedalic - A promising game with some annoying flawsI've spent 112 hours meticulously stripping down every area, every character and every side quest I could find during my first (and so far only) playthrough of this game. For the record, I'm a seasoned RPG-player and accustomed to the old-school turn based games.Short version: Bl♥♥♥♥guards is an average game which could have been a lot better without some of the bugs and a more intuitively developed story engine.For those of you who remember the glory days of the genre with Baldur's Gate I and II, IceWind Dale amongst others, Blackguars might still be worth looking into. I enjoyed playing it, but I would also like to post a warning about some of things that knocked down the total score for me:The main plot is... kinda slow. And dull. I actually enjoyed several of the side-quests a lot more than the main story. The ending is very dissapointing (and without giving any spoilers, that is an understatement). I also missed having background stories unfold for the main characters, but perhaps Daedalic are saving those for the sequel(?). Several achievements are (still) bugged. 5 of them simply can't be completed at all (confirmed by the steam community) but I've had a total of 6-7 that bugged in my game. It's been more than a year since these bugs were first reported and the steam forums have had no response from the developers yet. Like I just mentioned above, they are currently developing a sequel to Blackguards, so chances are that these bugs might never be fixed. Hence: be warned if you're one of those players (like me) who wants to cross off every achievement from the list. For future reference: I have not bought or played the DLC. Some of the game mechanics are not explained (at all) in the manual and I had to scavenge the steam forums to see if they actually worked or not. Armor is perhaps the most obvious aspect, where players have no way of telling if the armor skills makes any difference or if the character is encumbered (and if so, what penalties to expect in battles).An abundance of spells and skills makes things look very promising at first glance, but in reality, most of them are pretty much useless. Even when taking in account different preferations/play styles, at least 50% of the spells are likely to never be used by any player. Unfortunately, that goes for weapon types, talents and weapon skills as well. I can't shake the feeling that these worthless skills where put only there for marketing purposes rather than adding flavour to the game. It's either that, or Daedalic simply ran out of time/funds and had to release the game without proper (re)balancing tests.Although you are frequently presented with alternatives and choices in NPC dialogues, it rarely matters what you choose. I guess you could say that they are there to add some RP, but even so it could have been handled with more finesse. Instead you're bound to a main plot that you have no chance of altering the outcome of. I really don't want to spoil anything for you, but a frequent bother is when the game removes one ore more of your followers (and sometimes even your main character) without warning. A new player might have to start from scratch halfway through the game. Hint: make sure that your main character is at least somewhat decent in ranged combat.The 20th time the game presents you with two choices where one gives you a handsome reward (typically the "evil" aligned choice) while the other leaves you empty handed you can't help but wonder why? Most players expect good deeds to add up to some kind of greater reward later on. In my personal opinion, this is perhaps the single biggest flaw Blackguards has, and it feels like the developers rushed the story instead of taking time to plot out great stories. Let me underline that I don't think that "good" alignment should be favoured in any way. The rewards doesn't have to be better gear or more gold, it could for example be new dialogues/NPC's that are unlocked at some point further down the line. For a game that relies so heavily on RPG stereotypes it's dissapointing that karma is pretty much non-existant in Blackguards, And yet, sometimes the choices you make are actually so important that it could warrant starting over from the beginning. I would advice all new players to SAVE, SAVE and SAVE their game as often as possible. Think of Blackguards as a Bethesda title in that aspect.With the bad stuff out of the way, let's round things up with the more positive aspects of Blackguards: it's an ambitious attempt at rebooting the genre (yes, I'm aware that there are several other similar games on the market nowdays) based on a popular tabletop theme. The graphics are decent and the voice acting is top notch.Currently priced at €39.99, I'd recommend potential customers to wait for one of the steam sales before buying. For that kind of money you'll likely to find plenty of better alternatives. Personally I bought it in a Daedalic bundle and 120 hours of gameplay is more than I expect to get from most titles these days.All in all I'd score Blackguards a somewhere between 6 and 7 out of 10.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												It could be a really nice game but it's plagued with bugs. Unfortunately it's the kind of game that will irritate you to a point where you just don't want to play it anymore - and it's not because of it's difficulty level, which is really nice. Two big issues here are the constant game freezes and bad math for hit calculations. 100% chance to hit? Sorry, you've missed three times in a row!  These kind of things happen all the time in this game. I don't mind having crappy chance to hit in the beginning, as long as I'm correctly informed about it. About game freezes, it appears that enemy spellcasters tend to try to take some action that they're not allowed to in their turn, hence not finishing it so battle moves on. I've faced TWO spellcasters and both times I had to reload a LOT, because the aforementioned problem happened like 80% of the times. There's no screen rotation on battles. The official excuse is that "it's because of the way the levels are built". C'mon, guys... This game's visuals are not that intricate, some rotating functions would help a LOT, specially when scenarios have so many "dead spots" where you can't properly see enemies. I think that Blackguards developers might actually be talented and competent, however this is not a good job. As a turn-based strategy fan, I've played many smaller games that were much more satisfying and polished.

Two big issues here are the constant game freezes and bad math for hit calculations. 100% chance to hit? Sorry, you've missed three times in a row!  These kind of things happen all the time in this game. I don't mind having crappy chance to hit in the beginning, as long as I'm correctly informed about it. About game freezes, it appears that enemy spellcasters tend to try to take some action that they're not allowed to in their turn, hence not finishing it so battle moves on. I've faced TWO spellcasters and both times I had to reload a LOT, because the aforementioned problem happened like 80% of the times. There's no screen rotation on battles. The official excuse is that "it's because of the way the levels are built". C'mon, guys... This game's visuals are not that intricate, some rotating functions would help a LOT, specially when scenarios have so many "dead spots" where you can't properly see enemies. I think that Blackguards developers might actually be talented and competent, however this is not a good job. As a turn-based strategy fan, I've played many smaller games that were much more satisfying and polished.

												Blackguards is still in "Early Access" but is turning-out to be a very enjoyable light RPG/tactical combat game. 												Very decent turn based combat, and screen based towns and rooms is done nicely. The problem here is that it is seriously difficult even in Normal. It makes XCOM Classic Mode look easy. number of helpful: 16 of 32 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												This game has some good concepts, but unfortunately it simply balls it up. It commits every sin in the CRPG handbook. Ultimately this game is NOT an enjoyable experience. The first mistake the developers make is confusing complexity with challenge. The character system in this game is needlessly complex and completely opaque. The fights are incredibly unbalanced, and while it is possible to scrape your way through using tactics, it all comes down to luck.The combat system is absurd. My archer has repeatedly missed 100% chance to hit shots. Not parries, mind you, just completely missed. When you miss 5 90% shots in a row, against an opponent that has no special buffs, and meanwhile the enemy are not just hitting you but criting away, leaving you wounded and dying.Twice now the game has committed the cardinal sin of CRPGs of taking away your progression for the sake of a gimmick. Too bad if you were trying to make an archer, here's a club, go knock things on the head for 2 damage. See, the thing is, unless you picked the fighter class you won't have power attack, which makes melee weapons as good as useless since you'll just be scratching the ticks of the enemies back. You can play as skillfully as you want and you will still be screwed over by RNG and the absurd combat mechanics. Here's an example: My archer just missed 5 90% shots in a row on a target. Missed. Not parried. The target was not buffed with dodge enhancing stats. Now, in some games that would be okay, you'd curse your luck but recover and reorganize your strategy. In Xcom you might pull back and try to lure the enemy into an overwatch trap while you heal up your guys. In this game, every shot you miss, every hit you do not land sets you further and further behind and it is completely out of your hand due to the level up system and comparitive enemy strengths.This is not fun. The game itself is boring enough without having to go back and redo every freaking fight over and over trying to find some way to have just one of your guys survive. The loot drops are hilarious. Fifty pairs of hardened leather boots. Not one usable piece of armor. Boots. Boots all day. But don't think you can just buy armor for your party, the gold costs of the items mean that at best you will have one reasonably equipped and maybe leather pants on your other guys. And why on earth do the combat percentages change every round? Why when nothing else has changed does my warrior go from 90% to 50% then back to 85% ... if anything, im hitting the enemy it should go up. None of this makes any sense, it makes tactics pointless. Nothing is every explained.Honestly do not waste your money.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												When I first started this game I was like:"Oh it's gettind difficult" a sensation, we gamers long for in a tactical, strategy game like this.As I played it and encountered many quests, I realized that some of them, not all, are basically the same:*Go kill this, collect this, bring back* after this grind fest there is a few moments of joy when you become a gladiator and fight for your life but even that gets simply taken from you with just a few kills.The problem rises with Lysander, the guy who enprisons you, acuses you of murder and tortures you and than later on _________________SPOILER_____________________________________You find out he is your friend and he never trusted you and he is actually against the Nameless one and Urias.____________________________________________________________The game than ends shortly, I mean seriously! I finished the game in less than 22 hours of playing!Short game, and this is with the DLC (which I never felt as a unique experience).But the game provides some good experiences in controlling the battlefield with your unique spells, skills and etc.Btw Takate is useless as a Spear user, as you soon realize: Zombies, Golems, Humans with armor and mostly everything including those annoying healing crystals which you need to kill are immune to Piercing damage! Switch him to Bash damage.Do I recommend this game!?For 50 bucks, No!Than why am I in the helpful notes? Because when it is on sale for 20 bucks or less, is worth the 22 hrs of fun they provide.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												Blackguards is a good game but has it's flaws. Mostly I had fun playing the game. - The difficulty of the game is quite easy at the begining but later on it becomes really annoying because mostly your enemies use spells that lower your move speed, attack chance and health. Also it will become quite impossible to fight your enemies if you don't finish all of the side quest.- Interface/Combat  is excellent, but the controls are a little wonky and sometimes quite slow. There are some monsters that take up more than 1 hex ( places on the field) and it's hard to locate the spot to hit but it's not that bad that you will ruin your whole turn.- Information is a little unclear  but after few hours you should figure it out.- Loading screens. You will spend some time on loading screens.- There is not much of different gear and weapons. Don't expect to find a lot of variety of great weapons, few of my characters had the same weapon from the 1-2 chapter to the end of the game. Also my wizards had the same clothes from the 1 chapter to the last part of the chapter 5.- Opponents. There are a lot of different opponents and interesting ones. There are also opponents that are just frustrating you because they have have spells that lower everything (so yout hit chance isn't 95% but 45%) so they are hell to beat but when you beat them it's beautiful.- Characters. All of the characters u play have different personalities that are unique. In some dialogues you can choose what your characters will say.- Story. It's not a bad story at all and has some twists.- Graphics. Some people might not care at all about graphics but I like it when the game I play has at least deacent graphics. The graphics are not that bad at all but when you talk to some people they will look totally different in the picture then they look in the game. - Playability it depends on what difficulty you choose to play but It will surely have around 40 hours (surely more).- To conclude this review I recommend you buy this game but on sale. You will enjoy it and be frustrated.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 22, 2016
												Avoid this game.  I don't understand why game developers think that RNG and setting the odds against you makes a game fun.  If you enjoy loading over and over again until you get a perfect roll and get the scenario down perfect is fun than this is the game for you!The graphics are mediocre, they characters look mediocre and no way to customize, the classes are mediocre and you don't gain enough skill points to keep up with the difficulty curve.The game is linear, offering no real exploration.  Just move from one scenario to another.  One scenario will be easy the next not to bad and than they throw one at you that you have to reload over and over again until you get lucky.  No skill involved, just luck on RNG.  This game gets the terrible reviews it deserves.I am in the second chapter stuck on fighting the "newcomer" gladiators.  They split your group into 2 groups.  So if you didn't choose a warrior in the beginning you will be stuck fighting 2 ranged against a tank and range setup, which is painful.  There is making the game difficult and then there is making it silly just to extend the life of the game.  I will try to finish the game and see but my will to continue is slowly dwindling, I am beginning to think that this company doesn't know how to make games.OK Made it past that point, now I am to a part in the gladiator games where they throw 3 waves of enemies at you without any rest.  This really is some of the worst game design I have had the misfortune in playing.  You get no breaks, no way to bind your wounds... nothing.  I made it to the 8th wave and there is an instant win button the enemies can do that you have no way of stopping.  It is completely random.  I am very close to giving up on this game, it isn't difficult, it is, to put it country simple, stupid.  So far this game deserves all the bad reviews it has gotten.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												Do you love endless battles on a hex grid? Because that's what this game boils down to. At the core, this game requires you to really have some strategy and luck. The battles are always stacked hard against you, often feature respawning monsters that all need to killed at once, or have you slogging through ranks of enemies that are immune to your particular weapon type. The story is totally forgettable, the "tricks" to certain fights are not always clear, the inventory system is bizarre. While the game is slightly better now than in pre-release beta, it's still not what I'd call a "fun" or "gripping" game. I think TOEE pulled this whole thing off a little better, plus that game is way cheaper. I wouldn't pay more than $7 for Blackguards.

												Overall it seemed like an interesting game.The combat is what I dig for and the huge charactercustomization is just the thing I like.But it pains me how the companion are handled.Basically every other character than your main/self-created-one has predetermined stats, which cannot be reset.So you're more or less stuck with what the game gives you, instead of developing the team that you want to play.You can also lose companions midway through the game, for the sake of the story, which makes it even harder to have complete control over your team.The story seems decent and the combat is okay, but It would have been better just giving us overall predetermined characters, included our starting one, and make it fit the overall game, if the story was that important.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												Blackguards has a pretty standard premise, in that it is a save the world fantasy story.  Unfortunately, the dialogue is stilted and often disjointed and the gameplay is dense and perhaps overly complicated.  I can forgive the voice acting, and odd story easily, but it is the game mechanics themselves that perhaps need tweaking.   The dice rolls are punishing and heavily weighted towards failure.  It is laughably common to miss 3 75% chances in a row and taking a risk on anything under a 50% chance is pretty much a guaranteed miss.   It has been said on various forums that there are many mechanics that are affecting the probabilities that don't appear in the shown hit chance.  That sounds to me like a User Interface failure and a pretty important one at that.  Perhaps the most glaring issue of this is the arena fights at the beginning of Chapter 2.  When you have to pull off 6 hits in a row to kill the first enemy and then another 8 hits to kill the second.  Unfortunately you A) will die in 3 hits, B) Will get poisoned if you take a single hit, and C) the NPCs don't have an issue with the weighted hit dice.  Add to this the fact that you can't go back and level due to your captivity, can't buy potions (though the enemy gets 2 or 3) and lose all of your items means that you are pretty much screwed.All in all I was pretty disappointed.  It was exactly the kind of game I wanted.  It just wasn't.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												I won't repeat what the other reviews already said, so I keep this short:Pro:-Round-based strategy game (its like X-Com but with an actual story!)-complex character builds are possible and a lot of content (there are 5 chapters but I am still in the middle of chapter 3 after 19 hours of gameplay)Unfortunately the negative points are too much of an issue to recommend this gameContra-all towns kinda look the same and it gets repetive if you don't love grinding and collecting item sets-incredibly difficult to play because of unbalanced setup ( since you can build every character the same, you basically choose between characters that can use magic and characters which dont)-RNG makes your game so much more painful and very frustrating ( e.g. you have 2 casters who got a success spell cast of 93% but both still fail 3 times in a row which leads to an abortion of the spells; similar cases also with 95% melee hit chance and still missing several times)I don't know what the numbers of these probabilities are for, since they do not reflect the actual probability of hit or miss, but probably its a feature and not a bug. As long as this issue is not fixed, I cannot recommend at all.Update (after finishing the game):Another negative point: story is extremly linear. Your choices make no difference at all, because the outcome is always the same. The choices only affects the ending you may get but you notice this only at the very very very end (if you can keep playing that long that is...)

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												The game is based on a complex rule system, which is not explained very well, if at all.  They try and simplify it where possible to simple percentages, but it is often unclear what exactly causes these percentages to rise or fall, leading to the game feeling much more complicated than it needs to be. Coupled with a difficulty curve that transitions from too easy to too hard with nothing inbetween, makes playing this game a frustrating experience.  There are much better turn based strategy games out there, wouldn't recommend this one.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												Quality SRPG, that is both strategy AND real RPG. Xcom fans will appreciate the turn based style of combat, but be amazed at the depth of character customization and talen trees. RPG fans will appreciate the sensible approach to letting you move about an over world map with freedom, and continue moving in dungeons via a map of rooms.And lastly, strategy fans will love the character devolpment, voice acting, and over-all attention to detail that is lacking in most SRPG games.While there might not be anything stunningly "new" or unseen before in Blackguards... there's so much that's done exactly as you'd want it done, that it's easy to overlook what few missteps they made.A solid reccomendation for fans of turn based strategy games, RPGs, and fantasy gamers. A no brainer for pen and paper fans!

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												To get it out of the way, like all Dark Eye computer games this game is built from the ground up to appeal to the "rules lawyers" of the tabletop gaming community. The Dark Eye is like Dungeons and Dragons for people who think that what Dungeons and Dragons really needed was more math and latin.In keeping with the analogy for Dungeons and Dragons, which I use because as a franchise it is one that most people are more familiar with, the Drakensang games were kind of like Neverwinter Nights. This game, by contrast, is more like Temple of Elemental Evil. The game is almost entirely action, incorporating as much of the nuance of the tabletop game as possible, and takes place within a turn based framework, although with the incorporation of an actual hex grid battlemap rather than the approximation thereof. The combat options are numerous and exceptional in variety, with a number of opportunities to interact with the environment lending additional depth to each of the maps. If it has any weakness, it is perhaps that it is too pure; encumberance limits and limits on the skills offered by trainers and the goods offered by merchants seems inconvenient at times. More than once I wished that I had unlocked a skill at character creation that I can no longer find a trainer for once I discovered that one of my abilities lacked the punch that I expected of it.This is not a game for everyone, most people will probably find the experience frustrating. For gamers like me, however, it is exactly the sort of game we've been waiting for.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												Took roughly 40 hours to beat the game and enjoyed the majority of it.Though there are some serious bugs and exploits possible in the game to beat encounters (such as the final boss), I vastly enjoyed this game. I would recommend it to anyone that enjoys tactical RPG's or just decent RPG's in general. However don't expect a super duper in-depth story experience. This game is based heavily on the turn based combat and in a lesser extent on the storyline.Things that are good:- Stupidity gets punished- Upgrading characters is really mandatory- Reasonable dynamic encounters, that ask for different approaches.- Letting you wander around the world to do sidequests and unlock trainers- The exp-gain system (named AP)Less impressed by:- Cutscenes were useless and lacked in quality compared to the rest of the game.- Balance in the different roles is off, my Archer is 1-shotting 80hp enemies.- Encounters vs caster NPC's are completely random; no synergy or logic in their spells.- Best in Slot gear is fairly early obtainable, roughly 50% of the game. Didn't feel like a superduper reward.- Few bugged encounters- Storyline bit meh, jumps a few things if you chose the wrong conversation choices. Which can complicate the logic of the chain.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												Bloody brilliant. There are some seriously bizzare negative comments on this game but let me clarify some points. 1. Does it have a plot? Yes. Is it linear? Yes. Does it matter? Not really.2. Is the interface aweful? No not in the slightest, you can choose between a right click menu or a standard button bar.3. Is it full of bugs? No, the bugs like the character inventory head and feet images in the wrong place has been fixed.4. Is the character creation and character sheet bad? No, actually its very good. You spend 10-15 mins reading everything and realise there is so much death there are lots of replay options to have a different game. Its essentially D&D stats. Played Baldurs Gate, Diablo or any other game like that and its simple, intuitive and in this case, very good.5. Its all combat, is this bad? Not really, I enjoy limited dialogue and lots of fighting. Baldurs Gate 1&2 are mostly this and they are cult classics. How good was The Banner Saga, I mean we all loved the talking but the hexed passed fighting where was it all was. This is that game on steriods.6. Is the fact the game based on a roleplay system a problem? No its actually its strength as it has lots of depth. You can turn the battle log to simple mode if you like or you can have the log go mad with the dice rolling detail. (I turn it off).Its a damn fine enjoyable game, the fact the scenery is a part of the game (Giant birds dropping rocks, crates being knocked over, tenticles from a monster breaking walkways, oil being set on fire, slippery mud, quicksand and bogs) makes this an awesome and unique experience.

												Overall it seemed like an interesting game.The combat is what I dig for and the huge charactercustomization is just the thing I like.But it pains me how the companion are handled.Basically every other character than your main/self-created-one has predetermined stats, which cannot be reset.So you're more or less stuck with what the game gives you, instead of developing the team that you want to play.You can also lose companions midway through the game, for the sake of the story, which makes it even harder to have complete control over your team.The story seems decent and the combat is okay, but It would have been better just giving us overall predetermined characters, included our starting one, and make it fit the overall game, if the story was that important.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												"Blackguards is a wonderful tactics game with some rough edges. The core gameplay and character progression elements are easily some of the best in the genre, but as battles tend to drag on and more and more enemies scream “owAUGH,” the interest tends to fade. The story is easy enough to follow and interesting enough to keep players interested, so fantasy buffs should feel engaged the entire time. Even if the sound effects weren't satisfying, the gameplay itself more than made up for that, and it’s easy to see that Daedalic Entertainment has a bright future ahead of them in the strategy sphere."In other words, a great game for fantasy/strategy fans! Full review here: http://www.destructoid.com/review-blackguards-272333.phtml

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												With the popularity of Dark Souls at the moment, difficulty seems to be the buzzword of the industry. This can be a great boon and imbues games with a sense of accomplishment and worth when done correctly. Blackguards seems difficult for all the wrong reasons, from an obtuse user interface to mindbogglingly poorly designed stats pages. While I appreciate that any game coming from an existing Pen and Paper world will always have a higher step up for the user than most, Shadowrun earlier last year seemed to create a system both faithful and functional while Blackguards seemed bogged down in it's own mechanics.The story is about par for course and the voice acting is quite refreshing, but it just seems like the clunky mechanics just get in the way of that experience and the difficulty wildly differs so much you bound between feeling elated and cheated every few minutes.While people howl off the rooftops at the percieved "dumbing down" of videogames, sometimes it has a point. Parts of the design feel snobbish, as if it wants to pat it's faithful on the back and tell them how smart and clever they are while with the other hand swatting away the "casual, filthy masses". Blackguards needs to get down of it's high horse and reduce the barriers to entry that stop it from being the good game I know underneath is has the potential to be.

												There are bunch of reasons I won't going to recommend this game, it's playble and good at some sides, but: Some time ago when it came out it was unfairly overpriced and bugged. number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												A game with the feel of a decently run D&D campaign, well worth the money. Especially if you get it on sale like me.The combat is usually more than just filler between story, it is part of the story and flows very well.There is a lot of versatility in your main character (mage/fighter/archer) and secondary characters as well. The skill point system is a bit unclear at times, but if you save often you can always go back and change something that wasn't as good as you thought it would be.Remember, though, that spells will not be great at first -- you'll have to use points carefully to make a good character.The story is also very engaging, and voice acting is quite good too -- for the most part.And side-quests: plenty of interesting little adventures to explore, and skill points to earn.All said, this is one of my favorite games from recent years, and I highly recommend the experience.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
												The game locks up consistently.  Which means alot of restarts and lost time.Regardless it's still boring.  Latest lock up came around the point I was feeling like it was all such a waste of time anyways.  Won't bother restarting again.  RNG, I hate to complain about it...but...it's ridiculous in this case.  That's coming from someone who didn't mind it in Darkest Dungeon.Linear.  With not much to do.  Imagine boring battle sequences with an even simpler point and click game in between.Character progression.  Bleh.  The RNG has this covered to a point of non-consequential upgrades because a 10% chance to fail still means a 110% chance not to succeed.  Not always, just sometimes three times in a row... Clunky.  So clunky.  Not alot of turn based combat games out there, which sucks.  But I'd give this one a solid pass if you're considering it.  It's just not worth the time.  I don't care how starved you think you are for that genre.Bought this in a bundle for fairly cheap.  But even if it was free I'd still suggest a pass.  It's just so booooring.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												Like Might and Magic X Legacy, this title is going to polarise opinion madly. Both are old-school turn based rpgs with more of a focus on tactics than on roleplay, and the ambition of this title is to feel like a real-life in-person, yes-there-really-is-a-live-DM kind of excperience, at which this game is mostly successful.The writing is adult, the tactics are tough, and the game has the sort of arbitrary cruelty and imperfection you get from a DMs interpretation of the rules. This is not a fps or action game, in any way, its a game for reflection. And yes its a pity there are a few genuine bugs.This game will appeal to fans of HoMM, Disciples, XCom turnbased, Badurs Gate turn based, and as I say to players of IRL RPGs. I would say right now that I prefer MMX - Legacy to this, and its kinda stoopid that both games came on within a few weeks, given that its 5 years since the last half-decent rpg.But if you're the kind of person above, then this is a truly excellent title, and you should buy both !!! Don't be put off by some of the reviews that score it for what it isnt....

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												This is my first early access game.  I had reservations, but so far I put in a few hours into it. It's fun, there are some mechanics that are not as intuitive, and I'm early on in the game.  For instance buying weapons.  Would be nice when buying a new sword, that it would list all the characters that can use that sword and their +- stats if they were to buy that sword. Hoping for more weapon variety in upcoming patches.  The game is sufficiently challenging.  Gold is hard to come by so items you purchase can be frustrating at times. If you spent all your money on an axe, you just happen to find during the next battle for instance.  But that's the nature of the beast I guess.  The battles are a bit more like HOMM vs xcom.   Overall, I would recommend this game! Good turn based strategy games are hard to come by so lets support them!  btw Bellarita mission =  Worse most frustrating mission ever.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												From the trailers one is given the impression that you're playing the roles of the "bad guys" for once but have to "save the world";  a more apt analogy would be to say that the characters would probably fit well into the world of the former T.V shows Breaking Bad & Sci fis Battlestrar Galactica.  Does each character have skeletons, of course but I've yet to see one that actually warrents a "Blackguard" title; in fairness here the Blackguard definition, a-la from Dungeons & Dragons, is in a different context then from this title.  As has been stated in other reviews & from Daedelic Entertainment, the game is based off a tabletop role-playing game from Germany. This is my first foray into this system in any case.  The story is OK, but not much more then that.  You don't gain levels per se, but you gain adventure points (AP) when either defeating foes or completing a quest.  You use these points to raise just about everything pertaining to your character, be it statistics, your skills, your resitances, & for magic users how effective spells are & the astral points needed to cast them.  The higher the "level" of the STATS, skills etc, the more AP they cost.  Unfortunately, I've not come into any battle where my group has had a "windfall" of AP, so far  I've either gotten 30, 60 or around 120 AP depending on the battle (whether mundane foes or major ones).   I've gotten a bit more AP when completing quests though. In fairness here I'm playing it on the easiest difficulty, maybe battles give you more AP on the harder ones, though I doubt it.  The hightlights of the game are the battle system, I've yet to encounter any "cut & paste" battle area.  The upgrade system for your characters is fairly subtle, but noticable for the most part.  In short, you don't feel like you're spending AP to upgrade your character & they don't feel like they're more powerful.   The spells are diverse & effective. Mapwise there is a fairly large area to cover in both the in battle maps & world map.   The weaknesses of the game, thus far are:  No areas to really grind for AP,  with possible exception of arena, but even there I believe you can only have a certain amount of battles in the arena.  You can't actually make things, not armor or weapons, at least not at the point in the game that I'm at.  There's no height or lowlands difference in battles; in short I've not had so much as 1 battle where either I or the enemy started at the top of a hill.  I've also yet to have been involved in a battle where I've gotten a huge amount of AP. I'm roughly at the halfway mark, going by what the creators wrote on the main page, but I've yet to see so much as one magical item, whether defensive or offensive item.  I don't know the tabletop RPG this is based off of so perhaps the world lacks magical items or if they're simply more subtle in nature when compared to games like Final Fantasy Tactics.   The spellcasters also need work, I find them more useful as party "buffers", and from what I've read on the forums I'm in the nearly overwhelming majority.  This game needs some minor tweaks to really grab you & keep you in it's grip; but so far any issues I have with it, in the scheme of things, are relatively minor & not game breaking.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												This game is somewhat interesting, but mostly meh, in my opinion. There's gameplay in there (and if you think of every battle like it's a puzzle that needs solving, it becomes even more interesting), but there are a lot of confusing and idiosyncratic elements that hold it back. The English translation is not very stellar, the story is pretty much nonsensical, there's no way to grind at ALL, and the party mechanics can be frustrating at times, making the game harder than it should be. It uses some D and D stats like Treat Wounds that make the levelling bloated. The battle environments typically work against you more than you are able to use them to your advantage. There are no ways to win some of the levels because they were designed so terribly (I'm looking at you, mission near the end where you're chasing away birds), and in others the AI doesn't actually do what it's supposed to do (mission with the alligators is pretty much ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥). Also, one of your characters dies in the middle of the game (it's unavoidable), which is annoying, and another character turned on me even though I did everything the wiki said I had to do to keep her faithful. Don't play it unless you absolutely LOVE turn-based RPGs. Three dollars or less would be a good value for this game.SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER: The elf chick dies in the final match of the arena, the other girl turns on you.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												This game somehow made me feel nostalgic for the first turn-based combat rpg I played as a kid, which was Farland Tactics 3. This is a good thing since I can hardly get into most games these days, but this one sucked me right in.I happened to love the town overview and simplified map where I only need to click the things I need without needing to walk around and finding things. This helped me to focus on combat, while the town illustrations and some dialogues from the overview gave me a sense of adventure at the same time. The difficulty is perfect when I played this on hard - a little challenging but rewarding. Also, the combat does depend on luck quite a bit, but I felt like this kept me at the edge of my seat. Character creation and development was simple and intuitive. I didn't need to spend time trying to figure out how to build my characters by looking up at numerous guides, so it made me focus on my own game. All in all, this game was what I was looking for. If you love turn-based combat while being able to have some rpg experience without certain tediousness that comes with rpgs, this would be it.
