content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												Note: While I do recommend the game it's more of a niche, hard core-ish title meant for the more dedicated turn based tactics and rpg fans. I read many complaints about the immense difficulty and frustrating rng before playing Blackguards but when I got into it myself I found the complaints to be exaggerated though it's a subjective impression of course. The Dark Eye rpg system can seem strange to those who've never encountered it before and are mostly used to dnd-esque games but if one takes the time to study and understand the stats and skills and plan their characters the game will flow much more smoothly though there are a few missions that can feel overly long and frustrating. The most underrated part of Blackguards is the writing I think. While the overarching story is fairly forgettable the characters and their interractions with each other and the world around them are a treat on many occasions and the humor feels fresh and I found it genuinely funny as opposed to meme-ish or pop culture reliant as is often the case. The game setting is gritty and reminiscent of the eastern regions in A Song of Ice and Fire (popularly know as Game of Thrones). It's a place where slavery and blood sports are considered the norm and the Poisoners Guild is the "most respectable" It's a great place for your band of greedy liars, violet thugs, lazy misfits and romantic rogues to have their adventure. I found the English voice acting for the main characters very enjoyable as well. I won't go indepth into the gameplay rules since the game is a year old now and there's dozens of reviews and let's plays already. The system isn't perfectly balanced (is it ever?) and certain skills are not so useful to put it midly but it also offers a lot of flexibility in how you build your characters and it's satisfying to see your characters mature into serious♥♥♥♥♥kickers.While Blackguards is a bit of a rough diamond I enjoyed my time with it quite a bit.

												While I only played this for 30 minutes I was bored out of my mind the entire time. Story is all over the place. Starts with a common trope of put in prison for something didn't commit and has no memory. Another prisioner "rescues" you for no apparant reason, and you resuce another prisoner on your way out. So of course you become close friends and adventure together.Combat was bland. I chose a ranger as my class and after the first battle which saw me kill a single creature in two attacks, I spend the next three combats using a torch as a melee weapon against armed and armoured guards. I won of course.Maybe it gets better over time, but I'm not wasting mine after the introduction.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												The game itself is fun and worth a full playthrough, but that's about it. The loot is pretty uninteresting, and I wish there was more things that mattered.EDIT:Finished one playthrough. The game story itself isn't that interesting honestly, it feels rather cut in pieces. Also, the whole 'choices' thing seems to be a trend lately mostly along with the popularity of visual novels that actually are totally based off only those choices...but if you're going to have a game that really wants a diverging story up to that level, blackguards isn't your thing.The selling point, however, is that the battle system is awesome and pretty fun. True, it can get a bit repetitive and annoying, and perhaps easy if you're not playing hardmode. Still, the combat is solid and pretty fun. Overall, I'd give this game a 3.5 / 5. Good enough for a single playthrough unless they come up with more updates. Is it worth the money? I honestly dunno, but I'd pay around 20 i guess. If you want this, perhaps wait for sale period or something

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												Turn-based RPG's are usually sterile affairs that lack the grit provided by many of the modern day role-playing games. However, if anyone can deliver on the dark side of fantasy in that particular genré, then it's Daedelic. Engrossing and challenging - this game is different to the other strategy offerings like XCOM: Enemy Unknown and such. It's more refined and delivers hours of entertainment. Easy learning curve but a very deep game with many nuances and less than obvious solutions to problems.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												For a game stripping down RPGs down to the basics - combat encounters - it sure does a tremendously bad job. The combat UI is clunky as hell. You cannot turn map apparently, so every obstacle on the map is also an annoying obstacle for your mouse and eyes. The game loads a lot and I have no idea why, because the graphics are not anywhere near current single player games standard, but rather low on the MMORPG scale even. Inventory management really sucks a lot, not too mention quirky little fun things like characters using bandages to cure lasting injuries only on themselves - means you cannot reliably heal with a character you build for such stuff. This game is a big disappointment, if you want DSA nostalgia, buy the very old Nordland-Triology, still better and technically more adapt than this here. Certainly not worth the price of a AAA-game, which sadly it features.

												Shame really, there's a good / great game desparate to show itself among the mess that overrides it. The balancing is just wrong for me in this (as others have said) and it's never a good sign when you have to change difficulty just to have a chance at doing a quest (save person in 4 combat moves with 9 men on you, hidden traps and objects / said men blocking path for instance even having done all side quests).It also doesn't help when your playing an excellent turn-based combat game at the same time that gives you freedom and reward in levelling and experimentation like Divinity Original Sin (just buy that!) where while challenging the rewards match the effort and the party feel capable against all odds (not missing 4 out of 6 times on a 85% swing) and complement each other truly.So in closing if you don't mind shifting difficulty or following a strict guide to levelling / using characters etc (all of which feel cheap as your not making your own choices / victories) then go for this otherwise go for suprior alternatives like the excellent Divinity Original Sin or XCOM Enemy Unknown heck even XCOM Bureau (early days on that one but seems far more balanced / rewarding / less restrictive).

												Blackguards really opens up as you proceed through it, there's a lot of great content here. In the game though, the traditional aspects like the resting and healing really show through, reminding us why we moved on from some of these mechanics. content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												BlackguardsBlackguards eschews the traditional “you are the hero!” trappings of most games and instead places you into the shoes of escaped convicts. Granted you are still on a quest to save your world, but you do go about it in a slightly different manner. Does the game differentiate itself enough from similar competitors, or should it have remained in solitary confinement? Suppose you’ll have to read on to find out eh?Let’s be honest, if you have enough interest in the game to have happened upon this review then you’ve probably seen a couple of videos. From there we can assume you know what kind of art style is at play here. It’s dark, it’s got a lot of browns and grays, and it’s a high-fantasy setting. Dwarves, mages, swords and archers are all present. This is all to be expected, so we won’t cover the art beyond that. It’s pretty generic but it does the job. So we’ll go ahead and move on to cover something you’re more interested in instead.The gameplay! This is what you were looking for, right? It’s alright. You don’t have to be ashamed that you skipped directly to this section. I won’t hold it against you. I’ll still tell you all about the game and help you decide if it’s worth the price or not. Let’s begin shall we? Blackguards is an isometric turn-based strategy game with all the expected trappings that come along with it. You begin by creating a character via a fairly detailed skill/attribute tree using a preset number of character points. You may begin as either a warrior or a mage, with the mage class costing you extra points to unlock. Points may be spent on spells, skills, attributes and upgrades for all of those. Further character points are earned by completing quests and missions throughout the game. As you play, you collect various companions who can be fully customized in the same fashion, giving a great deal of customization options and variations to be had. Each character, including your own, is fully voice acted and animated. Though it is hit or miss, none of it is particularly bad. It certainly doesn’t detract anything from the game even if it doesn’t always add to it either. The gameplay itself boils down to what you might expect; characters act in turns based on their initiative values, which are affected by what armor you have equipped. Heavier armor lowers initiative, light armor lowers it less. It’s fairly straightforward. Combat is equally typical of the genre. During a turn you may move and attack, or move a little further and not attack. It has a bit of depth, but not so much that it needs any more detail listed here. Where Blackguards separates itself from the pack is with its tone. You aren’t a band of heroes out to save the world. You are a band of outlaws, cutthroats and brigands who just happen to be on the path that might end with the world being saved. As a result a lot of your quests have to do with helping a party member engage in some…bedroom fun times, we’ll call it, with a local baroness. Also robbery, murder, chaos and overall mayhem. It’s a nice change of pace from the usual save this person or that thing and be all heroic that usually come in games like this.Overall, Blackguards is a fun game. It has some downsides, being low-budget, but nothing that detracts in any meaningful way from the quality of the game. It’s worth the price of admission if you’re looking for a turn-based rpg to sink some time into. Give it a shot if it looks interesting and you like the genre. I don’t think you’ll regret it too much.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
												Starts solid, fizzles BAD later.Balckguards is challenging tactical RPG great focus on tacital, the characters strenghts are based of of the skill points you allocate into different areas such as weapon profficancy and constitution, and to note you can only carry four items per character in battle that includes arrows.  Combat is the typical turn based Hex grid goto but this is when the game can be a pain, traps are invisible of course you can take an action to scan the area around you for them, BUT to scan furthur areas you must move another character into the area avoiding the traps that are reveal. Movement is crap, the Hex grid makes thing wonky and you end up having the character accidentally move through a trap, inflicting damage, possible status effects, and ending their turn. If you don't end up walking through a trap on your way to the empty space you will likely hit a trap that is still hidden. Also the  AI opponents know where the traps are so unless it plays stupid and tries to make it's way to a weakend ally it will almost never hit them.I am saddend by this spike in difficulty but if you enjoy masocistic gaming feel free but other wise avoid.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												Blackguards is a full game for a fair price, which is a rarity these days.  No silly DLC or micro-transactions.  Just a solid, fun, tactical game for one price.  The game, based on a German pen-and-paper RPG system has a deep stat system, and great tactical battles.  It lacks real exploration, and the plot is on-rails, but servicable.  If you enjoy games like Fallout Tactics, or enjoyed other Dark Eye games (e.g. Drakensang), then you will enjoy this one.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												A piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥♥  DON'T BUY THIS GAME !!!!!!!!  This is the German idea of balanced gameplay!?!?  Continual misses by your characters (at 92%!!!!!) but the enemy will hit you, for two or three times your damage, at 45%!!!  WTF !?!?!?!?!?  Dead-alic.........we're done with you.  You couldn't program your way out of a wet paper bag.  It takes a helluva lot more than some pretty sprites to make a worthy adventure game.  And the notion that because this takes place in the Dark Eye somehow justifies this travesty of computer coding.  You're fifteen years to the party too late, and you STILL can't hold a candle to classics like Baldur's Gate.  That's SAD, SAD, SLOPPY CODING.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												Blackguards is a great rpg. The characters feel nice and different, they folow certain cliches but those are unavoidable. For me what makes this game shine is the characters and he conversations, i mean how can you not love the joke "An elf a human and a dwarf were wading through a river, the elf said 'This water is up to my chest' the human said 'It's up to my neck' the dwarf said... nothing." The combat in this game is often a challenge and requires you to think out your attack, use the environment and each character's abilities together or suffer heavy damge in most situations. The story is a nice break from the typical "We are the heros out on a noble quest to defeat evil." that often plagues the rpg genre. Overall if i had to rate this game i'd give it an 8/10, great game, fun characters and a nice story ut very unforgiving at most times, but at leas it gives you a "Try again" button for every fight.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												I think this Blackguards has a strong base and may lead to a very good sequel.  The game is flawed though.  For a game that states:"Your choice of spells, skills and abilities determine your battlefield tactics. Aggressive? Defensive? Tactical? It's your call how to tackle each challenging encounter! "There is very little choice.  If you want an RPG where you can build your characters and team this is not it.  The game give you a very well defined group to play with.  It makes the game extremely difficult if you do not build your characters to a certain role.  The other characters are far enough down their progression that it makes little to no sense to try and change them.  What is so maddening about this game, is that there is a lot of really cool things you could do.  You are just not able to do them, because they game gates skills, and locks players into roles for you.  If the game just let you have 4-5 characters to build as you see fit it would be far better.  The story was fine.  The voice acting was ok.  The game is good.  There is no real choice in the game though.  No characters progression choice and no choice in what you do.  That is why the game falls short for me.  It is not worth the full price.  If you are looking for a decent game that has limited flexibility and is on rails this might be for you.   This game just falls way short of how it is advertized.

Posted: June 6, 2015
												Starts solid, fizzles BAD later.Balckguards is challenging tactical RPG great focus on tacital, the characters strenghts are based of of the skill points you allocate into different areas such as weapon profficancy and constitution, and to note you can only carry four items per character in battle that includes arrows.  Combat is the typical turn based Hex grid goto but this is when the game can be a pain, traps are invisible of course you can take an action to scan the area around you for them, BUT to scan furthur areas you must move another character into the area avoiding the traps that are reveal. Movement is crap, the Hex grid makes thing wonky and you end up having the character accidentally move through a trap, inflicting damage, possible status effects, and ending their turn. If you don't end up walking through a trap on your way to the empty space you will likely hit a trap that is still hidden. Also the  AI opponents know where the traps are so unless it plays stupid and tries to make it's way to a weakend ally it will almost never hit them.I am saddend by this spike in difficulty but if you enjoy masocistic gaming feel free but other wise avoid.

												Turn-based RPG's are usually sterile affairs that lack the grit provided by many of the modern day role-playing games. However, if anyone can deliver on the dark side of fantasy in that particular genré, then it's Daedelic. content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												100% manure.While first 2 chapters are fun, from 3 it goes down hill. Especially chapter 5, which is incredibly cheap and frustrating. The game explains itself poorly and people comparing it to xcom should play xcom first.In this game hit chance % is actually not a real one, because the one that is displaying doesn't add dodge/parry/block to the equation, so the real hit chance is much lower in the end.Graphics for a game from 2014 are meh, but fps droping to 35 on gtx980 show what an unoptimised mess it can be. If you want to actually check where it drops like that, go to arena and when there is a level with torches and what appeares to be rivers of oil, touch the torch, so half the map is on fire. If you will make them all fall, the fps will go down significantly. Music is unmemorable, characters are just there (with no real development) with really awful VO work. If you thought Bethesda was worst, check this game out on youtube. Completely stoned elf chick is horrendous.Overall the game is incredibly buggy, from missing sound to other hilarious things.The only pros for this game that I can think of are:- cards, which you can sell- if you really care about playtime, it can be from 20 to 50 hours.- it is buggy. Why count it as a pros? Because there is a bug in the final fight when the game will beat itself, even if you lose, so you don't have to suffer this cheap and unfair fight anymore (with a trophy for completing and supposedly best ending!). At least I got it and I'm really happy.2/10, stay away.PS I will give you some awesome trivia and food for thought - only 7% of the owners actually beat the game.

Posted: November 23, 2014
												I was not certain whether I will like it or not due to some negative reviews on the  board complaining1. random battle resultsand 2.  the difficulty of the game. However, it turns out that this is one of the top 5 games I played in 2014 (including Last of Us, Distant Worlds, Dominions 3, and Tomb Raiders). If you like turn based combat in a fantasy world, this is a must. I enjoyed this game far much more than I did for UFO Enemy unknown.  I do not have any experience with the dark eye world so I browsed steam community guides (class guide was most helpful) and some forum posts. Concentration (on certain skills or spells for a character) was advised and it is really important.  I tried to max weapon talent, base stat and skill which are matched (refer community guide). Chapter 1 was a bit difficult since the system was new to me but the remaining chapters became more comfortable as I learn combinations of spells and base stats (for example, one of the  spells that I specialized requires cleverness and constitution). All the information is well presented in game. Carefully building your character not wasting points here and there is crucial. (Dont be afraid if it sounds complicated. If you play 3-4 hours, every thing becomes clearer). Certainly, randomness is there but every RPG has that element. So it wasnt a big deal for me.I am looking forward to Blackguards 2. Congrats Dev for a quality game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												6.5/10Blackguards is a decent turn-based tactical RPG with gameplay mechanics based on The Dark Eye, which is basically the German equivalent to Dungeons and Dragons.  But unlike most games based on D&D, Blackguards (and most TDE games) is based on a relatively low-magic world.  This and some other things makes me think that TDE was perhaps not the best ruleset to base the game's engine on.THE GOOD-Challenging difficulty-Characters are cliche, but well written-Battlefields are almost always unique for each battleTHE BAD-Needlessly complex character customization with very linear results-Extremely frequent loading times-Occasional chore-like battle-Story falls flatBlackguards plays like a more linear King's Bounty, except more linear and with actual party members instead of squadrons of soldiers.  I played Hard Mode on my first playthrough I found it to be very challenging; the game punishes you greatly for building characters incorrectly, doing poorly in certain battles (because you don't get healed for the next at!), and picking the wrong fights at the wrong time.  However, there is a good amount of diversity in game objectives and the battlefields are mostly unique for each battle.Strategy in this game favors positioning above all else, because the strongest abilities in the game belong to melee and rangers whose primary attack abilities have no cooldowns and insignificant downsides to their use.  Mages are primarily support characters, and their best spells simply involve turning your melee guy into an even stronger skill spammer.  Had they used a different ruleset or made one of their own, they could have improved the strategy element of the battle system.  If you're going to make a turn-based strategy RPG, isn't strategy a lot of what the whole idea is about? Don't expect the same kind of class diversity that D&D games have.  Despite the complexity of TDE's character customization, there isn't a lot of customization to be done.  Blackguards doesn't take a lot of steps to simplify the rules, but despite all of the little things the player must keep track of, the end result is almost always the same; melee and ranged guys hit hard, mages either cast support spells or suck.Load times are unnecessarily frequent.  The game features a lot of cities, most of which don't have much unique to offer, yet trying to find quests in them involves watching a loading screen for each one.  It gets ridiculous because some of the cities have more than one section, with each section requiring even more time at the loading screen to move around to.It was suggested by previews that Blackguards would set the player in the role of being the "bad guy" or at least the guy most people think is the bad guy.  The story even sets itself up with an intriguing mystery of laser guided amnesia, but aside from a couple scenes falls flat after the first chapter.  However, the voice acting is pretty good, and the characters, though cliche and mostly linear, are written quite well. Hell, Naurim is more memorable to me than any of the characters from Dragon Age: Origins.With all of this negative stuff being said, I had decent fun playing Blackguards.  It's challenging, offers some diversity in scenarios and battlefields, and has decently well written characters.  Definitely try the demo before buying, it contains hours of content.  Buy it on sale.

												I wish there was a middle choice like, "If it's your cup of tea," or; "If it's on sale."  Anyways, I can't openly recommend this game though I will continue playing it and do enjoy aspects of it. It's a start over too many times kind of game. Sometimes the CTH (chance to hit) can frustrate you more than anything else. Because it's played tactical turn style this makes some battles painfully long, and some easy battles unneccsarily hard. I truly had a fight where luck jsut spit on my and I failed every spell, before writing this review actually, and I was killed by two wolves...eh. It does get better, obviously as I said I will keep playing it. Nice feel, voice acting is ok, story is fine so far though nothing pushing the limits I feel it could move forward readily. I'm interested to see how strong I can make my characters and well I can customize them. Still, I can't recommend it.Why?It falls into a category of games where there are many options for you that are easier to pickup and just as customizable. If you've already played through a plethora of these titles you will then enjoy this as you're out of new stuff to do. But get a coffee, or whatever relaxes you, because it will frustrate you to ****.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 1, 2015
												I bought this on sale for like $3. I regret buying it.Pros:Hex-based tactical combatLots of character customizationPoints system for leveling skillsEnvironmental effects such as setting bushes on fire, slipping in puddles, or knocking stalagtites off the ceiling of a caveCons:You will likely hit your opponents maybe 10% of the time. You have a hit percentage ranging from 0 to 100. This is based on your skill with the weapon, your attack stat, and the level of the creature you're attacking. This does not take into account their ability to dodge or parry. A character (opponent or ally) can parry the first physical attack against them each turn. They can dodge any number of attacks per turn. So, if you have a 90% chance to hit, it is then further reduced behind the scenes by their dodge rating, and again by parry if they have not yet been hit. If you have anything less than say, 80% chance to hit, it may take you dozens of turns to end a battle that could have ended in like 6.Enemies at the beginning of the game hit every hard, and rarely miss. You can increase your dodge and parry ratings through skills, but at character select you can't exactly make it huge. This would be fine, if it weren't for the fact that enemies can quite often hit for 10-15 damage, while your character only has about 30 health. Early game you only have 3 party members, and very often face off against 5+ enemies. It's easy to get swarmed, so using choke points is a must-- at least it would be if the majority of the levels they put you in weren't open rooms.Cover doesn't seem to do anything. One of the earliest tips you get is that you are harder to hit in partial cover, and even harder to hit in full cover, like behind a tree. Archers have no trouble hitting you from the full length of the map behind full cover for 5-8 damage a turn, and it will take at least 2 or 3 turns to be able to reach them.Some quests/scenarios are outright impossible if you try them too early, and the game has no qualms about sending you to your death. A good example of an early scenario in this game is facing a Wood Troll (like a treant). It has a ton of health and does a lot of damage (like 15-20 per hit), but it's slow and in a gaseous swamp. You can stand in front of a gas pocket and  use a fire spell or torch on the gas to explode it a few times to win the fight. You could do this at level 1 if you wanted, but an uninformed player would try to rush it and die quickly. A bad example is later on. You fight some dwarves in an arena. They have a lot of health, do a lot of damage, and can move as far as you. You're *supposed* to use the same method as the Wood Troll. Stand in front of the mace trap before it activates, lure the enemy into it, and do most of the damage through the trap. My issue is I was underleveled, and there was no way for me to know this until it was too late. The enemy dodged 100% of my attacks, knocked down a character per turn, and the melee dwarf hit for 15+ damage per turn plus 5 poison per turn while 2 of my characters had ~30 hp, and one with 46. The melee dward also parried the trap that was supposed to deal the damage to him each turn, so he was functionally invincible. I tried at least a dozen times, looked online, and saw the only real way to win the fight is to ignore the mission until you had another party member and were a little more leveled. Looking at my saves, I had one auto save right before the fight, a quick save right before the fight, and a manual save about an hour and a half prior (Which isn't the game's fault, but frustrating nonetheless).You can't level skills without finding a trainer, even if you meet the pre-requisites to unlock it, or had the option to learn it during character creation. If I don't spend at least one point into the mend wounds ability at character creation, I cannot learn it until much later when I find the right trainer. I would understand for some skills, but for the basic levels of some passive abilities or skills it doesn't make much sense.Overall, the game is difficult for the sake of being difficult, but not in a way that self improvement can make it any easier. Unlike an action game like Dark Souls, dying isn't always the result of you ♥♥♥♥ing up. A lot of the time, it's because a creature rolled the highest it possibly could 3 turns in a row, or all 3 of your characters missed every single roll 3 turns in a row. If you're okay with restarting a mission over and over just to beat it, or to avoid getting knocked down and started on fire before your first turn, go for it. If you're as easily frustrated as me at a game where RNG is the core mechanic of the game, avoid it, even for $3.00

content:
Posted: April 29, 2016
												I wish there was a middle choice like, "If it's your cup of tea," or; "If it's on sale."  Anyways, I can't openly recommend this game though I will continue playing it and do enjoy aspects of it. It's a start over too many times kind of game. Sometimes the CTH (chance to hit) can frustrate you more than anything else. Because it's played tactical turn style this makes some battles painfully long, and some easy battles unneccsarily hard. I truly had a fight where luck jsut spit on my and I failed every spell, before writing this review actually, and I was killed by two wolves...eh. It does get better, obviously as I said I will keep playing it. Nice feel, voice acting is ok, story is fine so far though nothing pushing the limits I feel it could move forward readily. I'm interested to see how strong I can make my characters and well I can customize them. Still, I can't recommend it.Why?It falls into a category of games where there are many options for you that are easier to pickup and just as customizable. If you've already played through a plethora of these titles you will then enjoy this as you're out of new stuff to do. But get a coffee, or whatever relaxes you, because it will frustrate you to ****.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												Where to start? Most reviewers/trolls/noobs outright complain about the difficulty of the game, calling out bugs on things like dmg type resistance or getting knocked down because they cant figure out character builds.if you want a game that its pretty much like click here to win, you are in the wrong genre.if you want a game where you dont want to retry the same fight a few times to get it right, you are in the wrong genre.This is a turn based rol-playing game, you won't get things right from the beginning withouth knowing the game beforehand. I can almost assure you that you might screw up the builds of your party and there wont be an easy way to fix that, but thats the idea of the game, you either push through, start over or go to forums or reviews to whine like a noob because you failed to see the game manual/help/build guides.Now if you like challenges, and turn based RPGs this one is for you, you have magic, killer snipers and swords! bit of a spoiler if you mayyou get a very functional party consisting of: A greedy sort-of-crazy dwarf, a gigollo magician, a stoner elf, a killer jungleman and a witch.you can mold the characters as you damn well please, with some restrictions of course, but who dosnt want to have a mage in his party?what else? main character is not gender or class locked so that gives you some freedom to choose what you want to do.oh and yes don't forget: willpower -> def vs spells : body control -> falling/getting knocked!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												Everything that can be wrong about this game is wrong.The mechanics are broken (IE you get 1 parry a turn except for when you dont, that guy who has parried 3 attacks already, well your 100% to hit which you should never even have got because a 20 is a crit fail, he parried it because he also rolled a 20 on his parry roll, 4th parry out of the 1 he has per round),They are also counter intuitive (fairly normal for a D&D clone),And outright stupid (Why do shields give no bonus at all?  Why can you only switch your melee skill between offensive and defensive outside of battle, why does changing it make no difference?  Why can I get 100%s to hit when 19-20/20 is always a crit fail? etc.),Random to an excessive level (Nothing you do means anything.  Your completely non melee focused mage can work better as a tank than your completely tank focused sword and board char.  Your spell which does 8-18 dmg (firebolt 2) actually rolls for between 3 and 27, before factoring in resists/weaknesses)On top of that, the AI cheats (They get 100%s to hit fairly regularly, they can parry a seemingly infinite amount of times, they parry your 95%s to hit about 95% of the time, they still maintain accuracy despite having every possible debuff put on them, they get access to things like potions in fights where it is explicitly stated no one has them, they succeed/fail skill checks in a completely disproportionate amount to thier displayed chances of success (etc)),The story is both unoriginal and bland,The world is completely nonsensical, you can walk across what is described as a "Vast empire" and back in less than a day,Apart from your PC, Naurim and the fat mage, all of the voice actors are phoning it in, especially Neera (or whatever she is called),The game is ugly as all hell, yet still has horrendous loadtimes and FPS drops (I am on a 4GHz 3770, a GTX680, 16 GIGs of DDR3, and a high speed SSD, yet it still drops to below 10 frames per second at times, seemingly randomly),The UI is♥♥♥♥♥♥(IE every spell has 4 levels, each needs to be put onto your hotbar at a set level).The progression is♥♥♥♥♥♥(no matter how difficult the fight is, you get 23 or 45 exp),Probably more, but this game is so painful to play through.  I wish my kindly friend hadnt bought the humble bundle for me, as then I would have bought it myself and could have just never played this game, but since someone bought it for me I HAVE to finish it so as to not waste thier money.Heres hoping it stops being♥♥♥♥♥♥at some point... Here is hoping it isnt 40 hours in...*Edit, I didnt quite force myself to 40 hours, close enough though, and I did give up in the end.  It never got good.  Its entirely possible the story gets good later on (though from comments I have seen it doesnt, BG2 supposedly has a good story if still unoriginal, and it having a good story is always mentioned as a positive comparison to BG 1), but if the gameplay is tantamount to pulling your own teeth out through your♥♥♥♥♥♥ why would you even bother getting that far?

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												Saying that this is an easy game is simply a load of arrogance. This is an easy game to get into but a hard game to master. Unlike many games of this genre, Blackguards is very unforgiving and will teach you a solid lesson for every mistake you do. Every action, moves and attacks you do should not be taken lightly. Even if the odds appear in your favour, not using cover, trying to get an attack on every turn and forgetting to equip valuable potions and such will quickly turn your battle sour. While a bit frustrating at times, I rather find this game a lot of fun. For the few hours that I've played, the storyline isn't bad and the characters are interesting. This basically a straight to the point, no BS RPG. There's no running around a village 2 hours just for the scenery. You get somewhere, talk to the npcs, get quests and you're in battle. The difficult battles are what keeps you hooked and satisfying. This is probably more of a 90s generation type of game.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												As of this writing I just simply can't recommend this game.ProsIt's not broken.It's very pretty, for the most part.ConsThe combat is not only nothing new, it's also incredibly boring. There's just a lack of depth here that can't hold up to even very old series like HoMM. On the surface it looks like there could be a lot of depth, but that's just because of the huge radial window of spells and abilities that will never be used. So it falls short as a strategy game.The writing is mediocre, not bad, but it's by no means compelling, original, or gripping. So it falls short of standards set by many previous RPGs.And that's really all I can offer about this game, I'm completely underwhelmed and can't recommend it at any price. Not because it's bad, but because it's just tedious and leaves me saying "meh". At the very least if it was a lot of fun and buggy, I could say, "Maybe if they fix it." But I don't think there's a fix to the problems here, without just making a completely different game.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												I really wanted this game to be fun.  Only 6 hours in doesn't make me an expert by any means, but 6 hours of frustration and boredom is enough for me.  The towm screens are all static,  with certain activities highlighted.  You can shop which doesn't take long as everything costs allot of coins and what the player gets on drops is insignificant.  Weapons drop and they are all inappropriate for the "basic" games preset skills.  For example, your warrior is proficient in single handed axes and the only bladed weapons that drop, initially, are swords.  So, in order to even hope to survive any of the battles you have to pump AP ( which are earned by combat and quests) into a weapon that you have found, rather than saving them for other talents.  Armor is virtually non existant as drops so you have no defense really.There is virtually no game here other than scrounging for gear and combat.  Your path is pretty much preset with no real exploration and each location is either a static town or a combat grid.  The other really stupid mechanic is your starting companions.   You get a dwarf warrior that is pretty good and a mage that is as useful as a box of combs for a bald man.  Now if you choose a mage as your class, the party has great ranged dps ability and very weak melee.  If you chosse a warrior its the reverse and you are in even worse shape as the preset companion mage is useless.  When looking at the mages's stats, you wil see he has the best "ranged weapon" skills of the three.  He also has the most Astral Points ( mana ) of the three.  Yet when equipped with a ranged weapon like a bow he misses every time.  His casting skills are not bad but the only really good spell is an AoE fire attack that does little or no damage and uses up all his mana in 3 turns.  Oh, your mana regens at the alarming rate of 1 to 2 points every 5 turns.  You are long dead by then as a mage can't wear armor, has little or no melee skills and now cant use magic.Casting is a thrill, the effects are nice especially the failures which occur more than 50% of the time and the melee companion will miss 80% of the time on the only attack that does decent damage and the attack that has a high chance of hitting does insigificant damage.Now I know that any starting party is releatively weak and there is an expected number of failures in any combat until the combat system is learned.  However, the punishment vs reward system in this game crucifies a new party.  The typical battle has the odds at 3 or 4 enemies to 1, so you have 3 party members that miss and fizzle spells most of the time with no armor and medocre weapons against 6 or more enemies that miss maybe 1 in 10 times.  Your mana is used up pretty quick and the regen might let you cast one 10 pt heal just before the 3 enemies around you hit for 10 pts of damage each.There was one battle in a cave of sorts, the 30 odd enemies were seperated from the party by twisting tunnels, but you can see them, so you know what is up a ahead.  After killing the 1st batch of enemies, about 10, I got to sit there mindlessly pressing the space bar until our mana regenerated enough to heal.  Yes heal pots, well they are  very dear, almost never drop and best saved for combat.   After healing the party I sat there pressing space bar for another 40 turns to regen enough mana to move forward and take on the next batch of enemies.  Needless to say that aside from the very deep skill system this game is visually boring and the combat is more so.  Quite a few words come to mind for this game:  Dark, Dismal, Uninspirering, Frustrating, Boring.  It seems that the publisher is punishing the player for being stupid enough to actually give them money for the priviledge of being bored!Blackguards is the sort of game that if you had a choice of getting a root canal or playing the game, you'd rush to your dentist with a smile on your face rather than load this game up!I may get back into it, but there is no desire to spend many hours in this mess as there are other more rewarding games out there.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												I thought it would be fun. It kind of is, but it's incredibly frustrating. Poor detection on clicking enemies and random luck screws you over worse than it does in XCOM. It's really inconsistant in its mechanics. You'd think it would be simple, that highest initiative goes first. But it doesn't. It seems like it only improves chances of going earlier in the turn order. Because I'll restart a level and a different character gets the first move. You'd think this would make things interesting but it just makes it incredibly difficult to learn from your mistakes when it constantly changes. Wounds just break immersion so much it's baffling that they put them in. Your characters get "wounds" that carry over from one fight to the next, which cripples them somewhat and you have to see a healer constantly if you didn't invest heavily in some kind of "do-it-yourself" wound healing. Really kills the immersion for me at least to leave a dungeon, go get healed and come back after every room. Some maps are just really unreasonable and you have to try over and over again to even almost win. I mean, it speaks volumes when the first option in the esc menu is "Try Again". I mean, I'm trying to be fair. The game is fun and the concept is great. Overall it's an okay game but if it weren't for the overwhelming swarm of tiny annoyances, it would have been amazing. All in all, it's far from a waste of money, but I honestly wish I had bought something else.

I tired with 4 different setup and every time(sometimes sooner then others) ran into a just stupidly setup battle where I would have selected a much different skill set then I had.I did end up not playing this game much but unless it takes off(always a possibility) it seems that you are just meandering through life without much direction other then random people giving you quests that I mean go to X and have a battle...no real interesting battles other then some I get to run through enemies with everyone killing me in a time limit or press a button causing some other random thing to happen that I feel was just put there to make the battle go on longer rather then for flavor.I am sure there are plenty of people who like this game but I just don't see why I would play this when there are so many better games out there even in this genre then this.

There are virtually no strategy options on the battlefield. Attack or cast spell. If you are a fighter you stuck with the first option, and hope for some decent damage. Most damage I did was around 9. Enemies constantly do damage over 10+. And spellcasters fizzle their spells 50% of the time. Combine this with the fact that you can't even cast spell out of combat (eg: no healing). And you get this complicated luck based game, with 0 fun factor.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												I bought this game having read a lot of the reviews. I was expecting it to be primarily centered around hex-grid combat. I knew this and dived in - I love games like HoMM and Kings Bounty. Other reviews have mentioned that the game is essentially battle to battle, with a few static village screens thrown in to try and create a background. Even so, I was expecting so much more. Everything in the game seems to have been implemented with the minimum amount of thought. There are relatively few upgradable skills and I found it fairly easy to just divide skill groups between party members and max them out fairly early in the game. Other reviewers have mentioned difficulty spikes in certain battles and this is occassionally true - some of the early battles are harder than the 'legendary' arena battles you have to overcome later on.Actually, one of the main sticking points for me was the distinct lack of equipment - or at least variety of equipment. If the game is going to be based entirely around battles, surely you should feel like winning is going to bring some great bounty, but in the end all you get is a pair of boots and 5 coins, or whatever. There aren't even any item conditions to mix things up (rusty swards, superior buckler, etc). The amount of XP you get after a battle seems to bear very little resemblence to its difficulty either. All of this leaves the game without any reason for you to be excited or want to carry on into the next battle (apart from the inherent addictiveness of turn-based RPG combat). You feel like maybe you should be progressing the story, but I also found the story boring for the most part, apart from a few of the cut-scene events. I recently bought the Baldurs Gate 2:EE and played for a few hours, the contrast in characterisation is ludicrous - straight away I was enjoying the quips and comments from party members - while the characters in Blackguards just aren't really memorable, I found myself interested at the beginning, but raply lost interest, either through poor writing or due to the incredibly slow pace of storytelling.Overall, I felt there weren't really any redeeming features for Blackguards - sure its graphically competent (although by no means pretty), sure the combat and strategy is acceptable (but by no means exciting or ground breaking in any way), sure the character concepts are interesting, but they just don't go anywhere. It's all a bit of a muddle really.

content:
Posted: April 19
												Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!This is a RPG(RNG) Turn based strategy game.Interface/Menu/SettingsThere is a difficulty level settings available.You are able to toggle the tutorial.There is a master volume slidebar available and it is also % based.There is a music volume slidebar available and it is also % based.There is a effect volume slidebar available and it is also % based.There is a voice volume slidebar available and it is also % based.There are some different resolution sizes available.About the game.Before you are able to play your game, they will ask you if you do wish to be a Mage, Hunter or a warrior. Each class has their own advantage and disadvantage. This game is borderline... Well let's say uncreative. You click on a map location and that level will start. You are either fighting against an enemy or you are in a town. Once in a town you are able to buy/sell items at a shop, Rest to recover the stats, Talk to some people or even doing quest activities. Whenever you are fighting against an enemy the combat rules are pretty simple (It's like Heroes of might and magic). The battlefield is on a Grid and each unit take turns for their action. The character speed is known as "initiative" and the higher number, the faster a character is able to perform again in a battle. Sadly enough the game suffers from "Random number generator" in fights (Such as X-Com) which means, Even if you have a 95% attack chance against an enemy. Well jokes on you, The 95% is not really 95% as you are still missing pretty often. Your character is able to level up and they are able to learn new spells, talents and other things. They can be equipped with items to make them stronger in battles.Subtitles are voiced over. You are able to skip and fastforward it.Great Graphics.Turn based Combat.Decent story.Random number generated % based in battles.Character has some customiziation.There is a rules control overview.Alot of ingame tips/explainations.It has dialogues and cutscenes.Other things.The random number generator in turn based games is simply NOT WORKING and will always ruin the game. Xcom is a good example (MY OPINION) as the enemy always have a higher hit chance than you will ever get.So in short words. "Combat mechanic is unfair towards the player as it is happening too often"-------------------I Give this game a 5/10

content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												Blackguards is a Turn-based, Tactical RPG, where you have the freedom to customize your character to your own playstyle.  You can roll a Hunter, Warrior, or Mage, and cross train each if you choose. You will lead up to five characters whom you save or recruit on your travels to help you in your quest. Blackguards has a dark story, which may not be suitable for the very young gamer, but teenage gamers have seen a lot worse on television. Visually speaking, Blackguards looks beautiful, it is well designed, intricate and detailed. There are over 100 different scenes, each as detailed well designed as the last. While I am not a huge fan of turn-based play, this was a very fun game I could come back to again.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												I really wanted to like this game.  I am a big fan of D&D and have played more RPGs than I can count.  I am also a huge fan on XCOM and that style of strategy so this looked like a match made in game heaven.Alas it was not to be though.  Here is the good the bad and the ugly.Good:- Graphics are wonderful.- Voice acting is top-notch.- There "appears" to be a lot of character customizations.Bad:- Storyline beats you up in the second chapter and you lose your "investment" arbitrarily.  Sad really.- There really is a lack of "strategy" as you are at the whim of roll of the dice.  Not XCOM calibre, not even close.- $39.99?  I got is pre-release cheap.  Save your money it isn't worth that much.Ugly:- XCOM style strategy doesn't play as such.  Random roll really makes this a flawed game.  You can employ the exact same strategy move for move and breeze through a level, and other times get decimated.- There is no place to "grind" it out to build up your characters if you are so willing to do so.  Early in the game you will find yourself redoing levels because you got a bad roll and you haven't enough Ducats (money) to do what you need.- Some levels (first one) become closed the moment you go to another map.  There is no turning back until later.  A big map, but very linear and very unforgiving.You have to REALLY love D&D style play to get into this game.  It will take a while to get used to, and even longer to become skilled at this game.  It feels more like work and less like fun.I would not buy this game again.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												I would first like to pre-face this review by saying that I bought this Deluxe version and Blackguards 2 as part of the Daedalic bundle for £9.99, making each game in effect worth £4.99 to me. Based on this price I think Blackguards is definitely worth it. The full price of £29.99 is however WAY off the mark for the amount of game you get (hint: not much) Despite me finishing the game in 40 hours, it is a very combat focused where pretty much every event you’ll encounter will be a fight. Whilst this is fun to begin with, as a lot of battle maps are quite interesting, after 20 odd hours it just got tiresome. After every cut scene, conversation, exploration, etc I knew I would be fighting something. So you can imagine my utter delight when after defeating the final boss, the final cut-scene was just that a cut-scene!Outside of combat there is unfortunately very little to the game, hence I only recommend it at a steep discount. There is no exploration to speak off, the town screens are static and the story kind of gets lots amongst 180 fight scenes you’ll have to slog through. I also have a few gripes about the story, but these could just be personal preferences. For example, I don’t see how this is a “dark” story as it seems very much like any other RPG where you-are-our-only-hope-to-save-the-world story (spoiler: you save it). Also this games is called Blackguards and makes the point of your character being an outlaw. I was picturing more of a vagabond, a mercenary on the run, or some petty thief down and on his luck. What I wasn’t expecting however was for my character to be buddies with a PRINCES whilst chilling at a home of a COUNT in the first “memory” cutscene. Less of a BlackGuard, more of a Brodude! Also in this game you have no meaningful choice – it really just railroads you along the main story-line with some side-quests where you have a choice between killing guy A or guy B... with no impact on main story-line. A lot of negative reviews about this game are regarding the dodgy RNG, and whilst I have encountered some odd miss on a 95% chance, I have never experienced a 3 in a row miss. If you read the manual and understand how the rules work. The % you see isn’t the % to inflict damage, but rather to do an action, then the enemy gets a couple of saving rolls – parry / dodge. So you might have successfully rolled an action, but then the enemy might have rolled a saving throw and so all you see is your guy missing or spell fizzing out.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												I have not been so bored with a game in a very long time. Blackguards is a hex turn based rpg type game, with much less of the traditional rpg feel and much more of the board game elements. As a genre, it’s not my cup of tea but I can see why people enjoy the thoughtful strategy of it.Playing Blackguards felt sort of like playing a chess match over and over again with the outcome being nearly entirely based on luck. Perhaps it boils down to the visuals not being all that visceral, but even things like positioning relative to the enemy seems to have no effect on combat outcomes. In the hour and a halfish I played I did little more than click on enemies and wait to either win or have to reload. It was as if the game was trying to distance itself from me.Definitely not a recommendation on any of my lists; if I wanted a strategic RPG I’d reinstall Neverwinter Nights, if I wanted a board game I’d find a free online chess game.

												I wasn't sure what to review this game, but I thought a thumbs down would get the attention this comment merits as an OG gamer.  The biggest problem is that the harder settings make experience points go down and the mission harder...  breaking the standard expectation of harder missions and more experience that I wanted.  I don't want to go through on uber hard mode and end up with a nerfed character.  I suppose the other problem, and if you're thinking balancing trouble is the deal with the criticism, I know, I've thought of that, the problem is that you're pigeon holed into one kind of min/max or maybe two if you want to beat the game on hard.  This, to me, is not acceptable, lol.But, also, not that the difficulty setting thing means that, when you finally have to switch back to normal to kill the gators with your incorrectly min/maxed character build, you might have to make the disgusting decision to set it to easy...  which I know a lot of gamers like me just cannot fathom, lol.I suppose this brings me to another failure of modern gaming...  it's not like and can grind out another level in the middle of the story, which I would love to do rather than abandon my character... but why nerf my powers when I have it on hard, really...

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												A good turn-based RPG game. Graphics, sound, music and story are good. This plays similarly to X-Com combined with Original Sin (and is about as difficult as X-Com, with a mercilous RNG).  Lots of puzzle maps to figure out, and battle maps are very unique, and beautiful. There are a few things to look out for: it's totally possible to build your character in a way that will make it difficult, if not impossible to finish the game. Each character needs to focus on their strengths and ignore superfluous stats/abilities. The kicker is the stats on your characters, and the gear do not make it abundantly clear how you should build characters, what stats do, how much better gear Y is than gear X, etc. I suppose if you are familiar with the system this game is based on, it all makes sense, but if not, you will be confused and probably have to rely on guides and forums.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												First of all I want to say that I dont regret buying the game (discount) . 8 / 10Pros:- challenging- good variety of battles (win conditions, interactive objects, environment, enemies)- multiple ways to win battles depending on your party- amusing dialogue- not a single crash the whole time I played and no other bugs- good lengthMinor Cons:- awkward character development / training and AP gain curve (the currency you improve your charaters with)- small selection of armor (lets just say I didnt equip my 2 casters with new clothing until the last chapter)- not many weapons either (many special spears, only 1 or 2  improved versions of other weapontypes)Tipps & Tricks (light spoiler warning): - do not rely heavily on the Niam character- make sure your fighters are good with secondary blunt/slash weapon set (for skeletons and crystals)- make use of the ability to delay your actions with a character by using the space-key (sometimes being the first to move is critical, but other times you want your enemies to move first, so you can move then and hit them- dramatically increase your chances to hit enemies via wounding them, poisons, knock them down / incapacitate them, attack them with a weak character first so they lose their parade- have a caster who can cast axxeleratus level 3- poison your weapons before entering a hard battle (you dont want to waste a turn to poison your weapons in battle)- use savegames to try out different spells if you have a lot of saved up AP, some are turds but others can really shine / decide a battle (the beserk one can be very good, lightning cloud too)- get your casters best possible manaregen via gear / talents, maybe archery as a secondary profession

												Not good at reviews so I'll keep this breif.  The randomness of this game is just too high.  I had to restart fight after fight and the increadibly long load times are very annoying. content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												I really enjoyed this game!There are a lot of missed opportunities, but I got a nice introduction to the Dark Eye universe.I got it for $5.5 and played for ~30 hours (and to be fair I didn't look for a super long challenge, I wanted a game I could finish in less than a week, so I played in easy mode).The biggest frustration I've had, came from the loading screens. Simply put, any change in location (Map, Street, Battlefield) will have to go through a loading screen. It gets old very quickly.The character customisation is not necessarily the strongest point of this game, with only one character entirely customisable (the main character), and a few different companions pre-defined, there won't be enough room to craft a custom team.That being said, I understand that it is better suited for someone new to the genre. Personally I didn't mind it too much.I enjoyed the introduction to the Dark Eye's universe and while I would probably not play through this game a second time, I got a fair share of entertainment for a very low cost and I am considering getting into the tabletop version.

												Maybe this game will get better, but I think eight hours is enough to get a feel for a game.So far this game is frustrating in the extreme. The developers got more things wrong than they got right. First of all, the game is extremely unbalanced. This wouldn't be a problem if the game wasn't also extremely tough. I'm sure some people will say that they found the game to be too easy, but that would only serve to prove my point, the game is very unbalanced. If you pick the wrong attributes to improve (and how would you know which ones are best), you can get stuck.The interface is also very clumsy. It appears that the developers have abandoned the game to move on to Blackguards 2. Overall the game is a tough slog, all frustration and no fun.I've formally been a real fan of Daedalic, I've bought a lot of their games. But lately most of their games have been really poor.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												7.5/10Blackguard is a very fun turn-based strategy game. You will come to love most of the characters. The dialogues are simply amazing. Your party members are exactly what you expect your most extreme type of role-playing friends to be during a sesstion of a tabletop game like DnD."I AM A MAGICIAN OF LOVE. I WILL SEDUCE EVERYONE!" and then you get into battle because he fails all of his seduction.Everyone takes it to the extreme. One is hella dumb, funny and racist toward the elves. Another is just always sarcastic and mean most of the time.That covers most of the story telling. Let's get into the gameplay.THEDARNTHINGWILLTRY TO BREAK YOU.The hex-based map is great.The game using the "automated diceroll" system as if you were playing an actual table top is great.Problem though is that the other side cheats way too often for you to really enjoy the combat.Somes of them are insanely easy.And the next one is just demanding you to either get the spell to work on a 50% rate at the start of the turn with the follow up attack from your friends hitting everything on the first turn or you might as well retry the battle.And to make it worse. Everything, except for some of the weak fodders, are either as strong as you or much stronger than you. It's funny the first few time you see a lizardman sniping your team with a javelin better than your archer can shoot someone with his bow but after about 2 to 3 hits, it stops being funny because they deal much more damage than you do and even has additional effects until you manage to get to a certain point where you can finally learn your cheap spamming moves too just to destroy everything.And "HARD" mode isn't even hard. It's just frustrating and cheating. Usually, in a strategy game, repeating the same failed strategy oftens lead to the same fail result. However, in Blackguards, repeating the same strategy is what you do until you finally roll enough damage and hit rate to actually carry out that strategy, and that the environment isn't messing with you. RNG governs everything. Mobs are predictable but overstat as heck that they will deal your critical-like damage on a normal hit so you just have to retry over and over until the 35% hit rate on them actually miss instead of hitting 3 times in a row while your 90-95% are still missing over and over, or dealing minimal damage when it actually hits, leaving the mobs with 1 hp.Because this game offers no between-combat regen so sometime, delaying a battle to 60 turns + is necessary although you can end it in 7. It wasn't challenging. It was just the game forcing me to repeat the "Whole map kite" for the next 10 minutes just to full heal the whole team. At normal or so, this isn't always necessary. I can try with 75% health and mana on the next map. On hard? You better be full or you might as well restart the whole battle chain.But that's really the annoying part and it can easily be somewhat remedied by just setting the mode to "Normal" unless you're ready to go through pointless self-torture that makes you want to ragequit because of a single crit or a slip on an overstat mob forcing an instaretry. Other than that, I see nothing wrong with this game. People often makes fun of the voice acting but it's only horrible on the trailer. The in-game voice acting is so much better and really fit the situation when the characters are trying to be mean or sarcasting, which isn't really something you can see on the trailer.I also recommend getting the big pack. The artbook is simply amazing.

												Let me just start by saying that this game is really great but the devs DON'T deserve any bit of your money!Pros:    -Story was really good    -Loved the gameplay(turn based combat and how cities were handled)    -Lots of sidequests    -Really nice char development "tree"Cons:    -There are known bugged achievements(0.2% players have this) that noone can seem to get and also there are some achivs that some ppl get and other can't get even tho they did the same things that ppl who got em did..    -Forums are full of achiv problems and noone has heard anything from the developers for a long time(for at least 6 months if not more)    -The world map is huge wich is really great BUT this game takes place on only like 30% of the map the other 70% might be used in the sequel so that kinda sucked cos I was really looking foward to playing even more of the game but then I just went to the last chapter    -The main hero has 4 male and female char models, they could have made it a lil bit more customisableConclusion:A great game sadly ruined by sh*t developers who dont care. content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Great game - FUN. I recommend this game if you like turn-based tactical RPG's. Overall the game is a fun experience. The biggest aspect of this game is gameplay and story. Other strengths such as atmosphere and tone create a nice world. Great soundtrack as well. Couple things to point out. The world map movement is point and click/adventure, which I did not expect to enjoy so much at first. This creates a little slower pacing then I am used to in other RPG's. Just kick back and relax during world map movement and you'll learn to enjoy it. Customization can be a "gift or a curse," depending on your personality. Personally, the party customization screens were cumbersome and confusing for the first 5-8 hours. If you get overwhelemed at charcter customization screen, I recommend going with the default builds, or research other builds online for direction. Try not to waste allocating points until you decide on a main build. By the end of Chapter 1 you can handle all of the customization options though. If you love stats and numbers, you will no doubt enjoy the customization. Sometimes battles take party-management prep work before you engage. Overall the game is a good experience and I recommend it if you enjoy turn-based RPG's. Great story involvment. The game has a slower pacing, but this is not a bad thing. Just relax and enjoy the world, story, and gameplay!

content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												I too was excited about this game. It had a great intro video, and looked crisp. I have enjoyed rpg's since I tried Might & Magic 7. That game had a pretty long learning curve with no proper introduction and my younger self had no idea of the concept of doing quests for xp. But slowly I got stronger and stronger, and I learned my way trough the game.Every time I encounter games without tutorials or hints to character building, I think of myself learning to play M&M7, thinking I just need to invest a few hours and things will clear up.So me and a friend bought Blackguards, and played it both. He is older than me and I got a lot of grief from him, when I complained about the learning curve and difficulty. He said I am from a time when games are easy and I am a spoiled gamer.That seems to be the issue here. People throw grief at the people not willing to spend 13 replays of a fight. Probably because they did 13 replays and want the rest of us to suffer the same. I play games to have fun, and Blackguards gives me no pleasure.Am I a spoiled gamer? Maybe I am! Maybe I just dont want to sit and redo the same battle 13 times in a row. That gives me no pleasure! It does trigger a lot of screaming at the computer, cursing and pulling out hair. Maybe I am a spoiled gamer, but I would much rather chop off my arms than play any more than 8 hours of Blackguards.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												I really tried to like this game, in spite of reading very mixed reviews. Alas, I ended up quite frustrated with a few aspects that are quite game (and immersion) breaking:1. losing vital companions at crucial times makes party build options very limited. Essentially, once you figure out what will happen to X, you need to rethink your entire strategy for party build. This sometimes means restarting from scratch, or a very earlier save, as party build is very important in some of the encounters (especially the main ones)2. lack of clothing for non-metal wearing characters - while there are several pretty good sets of armour for warriors, the (complete) lack of mage oriented outfits is a bit mind baffling. I could not fathom that no mage outfits EVER dropped, although you battle many mages wearing unique outfits. And none can be bought. As a consequence, you mage characters have to either wear horrible looking leather armour, or spend a lot of time buffing/running/dying. This is also important for...3. almost 100% spell failure when wearing metal armour. I can accept offensive spells (cast outward) failing, but having a healing/self-buff spell have a <25% of success is nonsense. So playing as a battle mage/arcane warrior/cleric type role is pretty much out of the question4. tedious battles - which can go on for a long time, with a lot of time sitting, and staring at the screen while seemingly endless hordes of critters/monsters/lice/etc. go thought their turns. Even tentacles get their own turns, and usually have a higher initiative than your party...5. endgame decision disasters - going back to #1 - at the end game you find out that you are 'supposed to' have made certain vital conversation decisions with one companion, otherwise they will be lost, which as mentioned before, can be a disaster for the party.So, if you want to play this:a) read the guides and build a cooky cutter type that the developers had in mind, andb) follow a pro-forma discussion template to placate one party member, or lose them at a crucial stage (or build with their loss in mind)c) have a good book/magazine handy to read during battles, as you otherwise stare at the screen waiting endlesslyPity, had potential

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												I never really liked the whole "Yes/No" recommentation. A game shouldn't be decided if it is loved or hated solely based on other's experiences but rather on if it is appealing to you. With that said I gave it a Yes since even though it does has it flaws, I personally enjoyed it. Now to the nitty gritty part.What this game is (if you couldn't tell already) is a turn based DnD style type of game and it is heavily based on DnD mechanics. For those that don't know DnD, Here is a quick breakdown on how combat works: Roll for initiative (i.e. RNGesus happens at the beginning of each battle to determine who goes first), move characters around the map and you can do an action like attack, cast a spell, drink a potion or place a trap. Or you can just wait until your next turn. This process continues until every character has made a move/action. Then it is back to the top and you keep taking turns and making actions until either you or the enemy is dead.Now, keep in mind that this game is RNGesus based and that even though you have 90% chance to hit that doesn't mean you'll hit..just like DnD. To keep this short...also my spelling is bad...Pros: Interesting characters, combat is intuitive and changes per environment (i.e. environment interaction), very challenging scenarios (for those that like to get kicked around). Cons: Very challenging scenarios (for those that want to get spoon fed victory), Character customization is limited (you can create a rouge/mage or a hunter warrior but you can't create something like a palidin where you hit people in the faces with maces and then cast cure. Reason being is that wearing heavy "Metallic" armor takes away your ability to cast spells and regen mana. This is a con for me because I wanted to roll a palibro). Keep in mind if you do a split class like rouge/mage you will have more skills/abilities however you won't be as strong as a pure rouge or a pure mage.

Posted: December 31, 2014
												So I have only played this game for a few hours, but I think what I have learned already will not change throughout the course of the game.Blackguards is a hard, challenging game, it is most certainly fun and the voice actors REALLY make this game a story to be part of, I simply love them. Now, don't get me wrong here, I'm all for % chances to hit, finding tactical ways to defeat the enemy and such, however I really resent the constant <70% chance to hit, and even at 70-90% I've had several times alredy where I do this action 3-4 times and each hit has missed (or failed)(not including piercing to skeletons etc.)Therefor this game is very inconsistent in how any battle will turn out even by using the same movements and actions each time, and this kind of (almost) luck based combat makes Blackguards very hard to want to play again.HOWEVER, I would recommend this game to anyone with the inclusion of this shortcoming.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												I was really excited to play this hoping it'd be XCOM in a fantasy world.  While the combat and graphics are similar, this game just lacks a lot of the depth of XCOM.  There's almost no point to the skill trees because each character will just use the same attack skills for the whole game, most skills are passives anyway, and the others are so situational it's not worth it.  There's really no role-playing choices outside of your character "build" which is pretty shallow and one decision at the end.  The few characters that you get to play with have some personality which is cool but there's too few of them and one of them is taken away almost immediately.  The combat is pretty simplified with basic line of sight rules and dice rolls which almost never go in your favor if 60% or less.  Also, as a completionist, it was really annoying that some of the quests / achievements are bugged.  The only reason I recommend this is if you are like me and itching for a Tactical Turn Based Strategy RPG-lite game this will hold you over but don't expect to get blown away.

Posted: December 24, 2014
												Finished this game about 2 weeks ago.  Wish I had reviewed it sooner when it was fresh in my mind but here it goes.The difficulty is very high and there is a ton of content to explore over 5 chapters.Can't stress this enough.  If you are easily frustrated you may not enjoy this game.But it sure does feel good when Naurim wins the battle with only a few points of health left, or when you manage to outrun that damn poison mist :)Story is good, I got really into it from the beginning.  You are trying to investgate the murder of the princess and its possible you are the killer.  As you play more of the story is revealed.Some good walkthroughs can be found online if you feel the game is too hard, but basically whatever character type you go for you need to invest in one weapon skill to at least 14-16 to avoid missing most of the time.  Also its a good idea to save your experience points until you absolutely need to spend it, and its a good idea to plan ahead what kind of skills and spells you want to invest in as experience points are limited and there is no going back once you purchase a skill.Don't be afraid to turn the game to easy in order to enjoy the game :)  I did in some parts and its a great RPG experience.
