content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												This is a turn based tactics game where you control (after about 30 hours gameplay) up to 5 heroes who walk between nodes on a world map in a very linear way and follow a more or less entertaining story (At least I found some of the dialogue mildly enjoyable). Some nodes are cities where you may learn skills, buy equipment, and get/perform quests, other nodes are quest nodes that may sometimes be skipped. Most of the time is however spent in  hexagon based maps fighting various bad guys. The game has a lot of skills and stats that you may experiment with, but mostly it makes little difference what you chose to skill up (For spells any nuke will do, some early bosses are weak to fire, but it makes little difference for most enemies, a healing spell is pretty much required, you will alternate between those two and auto attacks for the whole game), and as most stats and skills are needed in the end anyway the customization adds little depth to a shallow game. The major problem with Blackguards is that fights are mostly based on luck. Want to attack someone? Well, usually you have a 90% chance to hit (not bad, but that's as good as it gets unless someone is knocked down), but if you use a more powerful attack it might drop down to 85%, 70%, or 60% (based on dodge stat vs dexterity I think), further reduced with wounds that are randomly obtained when taking damage (I think your to hit chance can potentially go all the way down to 30%). If you manage to hit at all the damage dealt is then further randomed in a fairly large spread, and rarely it will crit for double damage. The damage is fairly high, so 3-4 good attacks is enough to drop most enemies and heroes.This means that missing more than a few attacks will result in one of your heroes getting knocked unconscious, and the enemies snowball from there.It's typically the enemies who get the good dodge stats, so while your heroes will mostly take full damage from anything that attacks them late game, your heroes will miss, miss, miss,miss, and miss some more as you watch them slowly die in frustration. The game's "difficulty" slowly ramps up as you play. Every encounter is level (in)appropriate, so every fight is a challenge. Since spell damage is fixed your magic users slowly get weaker after their 2 main spells hit level 3. While this makes sense in a way you will never get to be satisfied with how much stronger your heroes have gotten. Enemies have about the same stats and skills and do about as much damage as the heroes do, so fights vary little in practise between various encounters.The game could still be a mildly enjoyable grind with the above mentioned issues, but clearly the devs were obsessed with making the game into a never ending series of encounters by a power tripping DM trying to make your party lose.I got through several unfair fights like Running past all the enemies who get to hit you for free for 6 turns to get to the girl before she's killed, shoot a giant tree with 150 hp to death with arrows that each do 1 dmg because it 2 shots everything in melee range, run through a basement filled with traps to get to the guy you need to kill before he gets away, kill the necromancer who's surrounded by unkillalbe skeletons that block your spells and arrows, and many many more. The straw that broke the camel's back for me was the fight against the tiger lilly where one of your heroes is turned against you, you have to run up to a plant that always has a 60% hit chance, is immune to magic damage, every turn one of your heroes is knocked down, and 5-6 tentacles you're not supposed to kill get to attack your heroes freely while blocking off healing spells you might want to cast on the hero being bullied.I understand that something like this was necessary to make the game interesting, as the fights by themselves clearly aren't. With a different combat system these fights might have been fun, but in Blackguards you will just keep doing the right thing again and again untill it finally works and you get to go on. So, TL;DR: Turn based fights heavily based on luck, little customization in practise despite the wealth of options available, you get weaker as you keep on playing, and gimmicky fights where the devs metaphorically throw your miss chance and weakness in your face again and again by setting up scenarios that force you into doing stupid things over and over untill the RNG gods decide that you may finally pass. If it sounds like your cup of tea then you will probably enjoy Blackguards, but I did not.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												It should be noted that I picked up this game in a sale at a discounted price, my opinion is based on me paying about £18 for it rather than the full price. I think it is likely that my opinion on this game would change if I had forked out £30 for it.I knew about Daedlic's point and click games like Deponia so I was interested to see what their take on a RPG would be like. As it is something that I almost expect in a RPG nowdays it is important to state that this game is very linear. If you are expecting something like Dragon Age you are going to be very disapointed (to be fair expecting all RPGs to be like Dragon Age will invaribly lead to disappointment). Also I think the game description is a bit misleading, you and your companions do have a slight criminal air about yourselves but at the end of the day it is standard save the world type stuff, nothing too ground breaking.The game has three main views, the first is the world overview you use for travelling around. This is basically a map type view with marker locations for villages, towns, places of interest etc... To move around you click on where you want to go and jump to that location - so no player controlled wilderness exploration or anything like that. The next view is the "town view". This is pretty much a static view where you can click on characters to buy goods or obtain/advance quests. The final view is the battle view, this is a map split up into small hexagons where the player controlled combat takes place. These battle maps range in size, though none are particularly huge. They consist of different environments and obstacles that sometimes require a change in tactics for some scenarios. Combat is turn based attack and move type stuff with close combat with swords, axes, maces etc..., ranged with bows and crossbows and ranged with magic. The combat can get a bit repetitious but there is enough in there that it does not feel too much a grind.You get to pick one of three classes for your main character, a mage, a rogue/archer type or a fighter. On levelling up you pick attributes and combat skills and there is the freedom to create hybrid classes by giving your archer some mage abilities for example. I did find though that each class tends to have one particularly powerful skill or skill combo that you will just tend to repeat in combat.The game itself has a lot of good and bad points, it is quite a mixed bag but there is probably going to be something in there that does end up annoying you, it certainly is not perfect. How much that thing annoys you is probably the defining factor in whether you will ultimately enjoy the game or not. For me it was with the combat, there are some monsters which are only vunerable to one type of damage. However, ahead of the battle you do not necessarily know what type of monster you will be fighting so in my case I frequently had everyone inflicting either piercing or magic damage. That was my best set up given my characters, weapons and prefered skills. However, in some fights monsters will be invulnerable to piercing so you have to quit the game reload and re-equip characters with maces so you can inflict bashing damage. Nothing game breaking but it did really get annoying, you learn pretty early on to have back up weapons handy and make sure your party is at least a bit flexible. You can look on that as somewhat of a positive as my party was really not set up for those particular battles so it did add an extra challenge, making what should have been an easy fight a bit more difficult. I think one other problem that needs highlighting is the party make up. You have a limited number of companions that you can recruit, essentially there is one party for the game. You do not get to deicde if you would rather have a mage or a fighter in your party you get what your are given. I do not want to spoil anything but at some point in the game something happens that means that really to fill a specific gap in your party your main character needs to be a specific class. Luckily I chose this class anyway so it was not a problem in my play through. If I had selected a different class it may have negatively effected my opinion of the game.On the positive side I liked the story (the ending is a bit meh but nothing too objectionable) and found the characters interesting with some nice back story and different personalities. By the end I found myself invested in the story and felt fairly satisfied with the experience on completion. You do get some "choices with consequences moments" that give you a sense of control over how the story plays out. My play through took me 26 hours and I pretty much did everything quest wise in the game.I would recommend this game but I did pay about £18 for it. if I had paid the full retail price I would probably not recommend it as I think at that price some of the problems I have glossed over would have seemed a lot more annoying. My advice is to pick this up if you see it discounted as on the whole it is a relatively enjoyable experience. However, at full price there a lot better RPGs out there and I would be a lot less forgiving of the game's flaws.

												First of all I want to say that I dont regret buying the game (discount) . 8 / 10Pros:- challenging- good variety of battles (win conditions, interactive objects, environment, enemies)- multiple ways to win battles depending on your party- amusing dialogue- not a single crash the whole time I played and no other bugs- good lengthMinor Cons:- awkward character development / training and AP gain curve (the currency you improve your charaters with)- small selection of armor (lets just say I didnt equip my 2 casters with new clothing until the last chapter)- not many weapons either (many special spears, only 1 or 2  improved versions of other weapontypes)Tipps & Tricks (light spoiler warning): - do not rely heavily on the Niam character- make sure your fighters are good with secondary blunt/slash weapon set (for skeletons and crystals)- make use of the ability to delay your actions with a character by using the space-key (sometimes being the first to move is critical, but other times you want your enemies to move first, so you can move then and hit them- dramatically increase your chances to hit enemies via wounding them, poisons, knock them down / incapacitate them, attack them with a weak character first so they lose their parade- have a caster who can cast axxeleratus level 3- poison your weapons before entering a hard battle (you dont want to waste a turn to poison your weapons in battle)- use savegames to try out different spells if you have a lot of saved up AP, some are turds but others can really shine / decide a battle (the beserk one can be very good, lightning cloud too)- get your casters best possible manaregen via gear / talents, maybe archery as a secondary profession

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												Maybe this game will get better, but I think eight hours is enough to get a feel for a game.So far this game is frustrating in the extreme. The developers got more things wrong than they got right. First of all, the game is extremely unbalanced. This wouldn't be a problem if the game wasn't also extremely tough. I'm sure some people will say that they found the game to be too easy, but that would only serve to prove my point, the game is very unbalanced. If you pick the wrong attributes to improve (and how would you know which ones are best), you can get stuck.The interface is also very clumsy. It appears that the developers have abandoned the game to move on to Blackguards 2. Overall the game is a tough slog, all frustration and no fun.I've formally been a real fan of Daedalic, I've bought a lot of their games. But lately most of their games have been really poor.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												This game as a lot of potential the gameplay is engaging and the game offer a good challenge which isn't something that can be said from most RPG. I would recommend this game if you have a lot of free time because the battle (which is 95% of the game) are super long. You'll spend a lot of time waiting for your turn. If you are used to turn base table top game like DND heres some insight. Most of the  fighting involves around 15-20 mobs each time each critters moves around... one at a time and if you use the environnement most of the time you will block some path and they will just move around back and forth.. Its a major inconvenient ... the development team had really nice ideas of dynamic and unique fights that are really awesome, but most of the time even nice creative challenge will bore you because of the heavy and painful waiting turn... if only mobs could play all at once it would have been easier to bear. +great gameplay +animation are great +variety of spell and special action are nice +action centered game (not much time wasted on story) + innovative and creative fights + engaging strategy must be used to win + difficulty is good + good AI------ WAITING TIME for turn IS AWFUL and ruins the game

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												A good turn-based RPG game. Graphics, sound, music and story are good. This plays similarly to X-Com combined with Original Sin (and is about as difficult as X-Com, with a mercilous RNG).  Lots of puzzle maps to figure out, and battle maps are very unique, and beautiful. There are a few things to look out for: it's totally possible to build your character in a way that will make it difficult, if not impossible to finish the game. Each character needs to focus on their strengths and ignore superfluous stats/abilities. The kicker is the stats on your characters, and the gear do not make it abundantly clear how you should build characters, what stats do, how much better gear Y is than gear X, etc. I suppose if you are familiar with the system this game is based on, it all makes sense, but if not, you will be confused and probably have to rely on guides and forums.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
												I got this game during the humble bundle that was put up a few months ago, so I'm writing this review accordingly. In other words, if I had bought this game at the full price tag of $39.99, I'd probably be more inclined to hit "Not Recommended". But on sale, I think it's a good game that will definitely keep you playing for a couple of hours at a time if you don't have high standards of character. That being said, you will probably not be interested enough to keep playing this on a binge where you spend hours on end.The tactics style gameplay is pretty neato. That's... about all I can say about that part of the game. It doesn't really add anything to it or really borrow from some more advanced takes on it like XCOM: You've got area-of-effect attacks, you've to melee attacks, you've got ranged attacks. Don't expect to have any innovative takes on cover-combat, field of vision, and so on. The characters are decent. Not really involved enough that I'd say I particularly cared about any of them one way or another, but not bland enough that I wasn't at least interested in seeing where they fit in the story. The character you kind of play as doesn't seem to really have a major stance on anything minus how you decide to direct his dialogue, but it's one of those games where you're kind of your own guy and you kind of aren't. There's a lot of good side quests here and there that you are definitely going to want to do to keep yourself armed and leveled for the main questline.As for the main questline itself, there's really nothing that much to it. The game tries to differentiate itself from other RPG-style adventure games by having the cast of characters be completely unlikely heroes. You, the main character, find yourself traveling with two fellows (a stereotypical and somewhat superstitious dwarf and a casanova mage) who collectively break out of a prison. From there, your party's membership includes a drug-addict elf whose pretty good with a bow (I think she's an elf at least. She's got the ears), a tribal dude who was ready to kick your♥♥♥♥♥before, and a childhood friend who ended up becoming an (alleged) nymphomaniac witch. This seems like an interesting premise on the surface, but the game doesn't really apply itself that well. We don't really get much in on the character's pasts, and the interactions with the main character and the story are very limited. For a game that could've very well built onto a unique premise worthy enough of it being a constantly talked about title, the developers didn't really do much to apply themselves here, and I'm afraid that might still be the case for the sequel, Blackguards 2 as well (I haven't played it yet, so I won't judge).So basically, this game is good if it's on a really, really good sale and you're already into fantasy and tactical games, but aren't looking for anything too innovative on either ends.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Blackguards is without a doubt a fun game for the old-school turn-based RPG-combat interested. It feels like a solid title through and through and it has hours of fun and enjoyment in it where you will be redoing battles over and over until you find the right strategy for them and beat them easily. This is definitely a challenging game with a lot of good sides to it, but it has one major flaw, and that is that it is far from complete and full of game-ending bugs. Expect to go somewhere and not being able to play if you make that choice because the game will crash if you make that certain turn, if you were lucky you had savegames prior to that choice, if not - then you have to start all over again.By game-breaking bugs I mean that when you reach a certain location, the game will just crash every single time you go there. Reloading the game won't help, it will continuously crash and if you had an old savegame you can get around it, otherwise you are screwed until they either fix it, or you move on to another game, alternatively give this game another try and remember what choice you made that led to the crashing.Unfortunately this is a dealbreaker for me, and while I did have a lot of fun, I didn't get to experience the game as I played it, and I refuse to go back to change how I played just because the game is unfinished. Supposedly it's going to be done this autumn, but I doubt there will be much more development on this title, they've been releasing a DLC for it already, and announced a sequel, which is underway. It's a pity that a title that has such great core mechanics get ruined in the details, but such is the way right now. It is quite possible that you do not run into these bugs, and have an excellent experience, but keep in mind, you might end up like me.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												Before playing this game I spend some time with Blackguards2, and ultimately decided to wasn't worth my time.  I fired up Blackguards 1 to see if the original got it any better.  Surprisingly, the first game has a better pace to it, things move along a bit faster and the story gets way.  The protagonists seems more interesting, at least to me, and my crew is certainly an improvement.Ultimately, the gameplay is still just so slow.  The combat and movement crawls like a snail.  Other titles like Banner Saga have succeeded quite well with turn-based combat. Pros144hz supportDecent graphics, art tends to look reasonably good, it will immerse you.It’s better than Blackguards2ConsEven though the game is turn based it needs to allow the user to speed things up a bit.  It takes far too long time to accomplish anything in the gameNo camera rotating?  Some objects are placed behind others with an obscured view.  It's not an isometric game so this is seemingly pointless limitation. Combat doesn't seem to have a lot of strategy to it.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												I put 84 hours into it and quit with the end in sight.  I love turn based combat, and that kept me going in the linear game.  Combat became more about figuring out the trick to the map, rather than strategic play.  It sadly be came tedious.You only get a clean slate on your own character, and because the way the trainers are laid out you can’t develop your character the way you want, his all ties into the game being very linear.You can’t rotate the camera expect on one axis, which makes some fights awkward.Shield only helps per parry you get, so shields are not that great.Never once saw the point in disarming traps, but spotting them was very important.NPC you build into your party come and go, to me when I specialize a party it is crippling to lose one of its team members.I wanted to love it.  It is a good looking game.  I like the character development, except the trainer availability.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												Very enjoyable turn-based strategy game.  Easy to pickup, and a fun cast of characters that make your party. The core storyline is linear, but the battles are incredibly fun.  There is a lot of challenging battles, and plenty of easy battlse without a sweat.  It keeps the game tight toward the battle, because the overmap screen really gives you the chioce of what quests to pickup and what items to purchase, but there is not any unnecessary travel.  Essentially, you fast travel from location to location, and many times entering a battle at the various desitinations. There a few main enemies that show up multiple times, and adds to the drama.  However, the story is enjoyable, the battles at the last stage leading to the ultimate battle are quite good, however, the ending is a bit of let down.  However, that doesn't take away from everything they did to make this game awesome. If you like controlling your party for turn based D&D battles, you are going to love this game. :)

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												The ap and loot system feels more like living real life as a poor person oppressed by over priced rent, wishing he could buy steak at the grocery store only able to eventually afford the spam.. But only after he spends a few more days cleaning urinals. The limited amount of story line options in general make this a lack luster experience for a RPG, as its pretty much linear. For a tablet game, playing this while traveling on a plane, would be a decent experience, for a pc game it serves to make me want to go back outside and spend time in the real world despite trying to escape from it for a moment. I do continue to play it, and yell words I dont want my mother to hear when I miss 95% chance to hits over and over while the archers on the enemy side hit with 5% chances. Reminds me of my childhood when I played ninja gaiden and swore the game cheated hahah.All that said, once you get across the border, things get a little more interesting and slightly more free. IF you can find this game on a deep sale, and love this sorta play style youll find it is an easy game to fill the void between what ever else you are doing with your life.

Posted: March 10, 2015
												I bought this game with a bundle of a lot of games by the same company, and didn't think much of it. I had seen the positive review by TotalBiscuit, but I was not sure I would like the genre.However, the game surprised me positively. The combat mechanics are well designed and implemented, and it makes the game fun and additive to play. Thanks to this good design, the game doesn't feel repetitive (even though most battles are very similar). It does also help that the battlegrounds are often different and sometimes with additional challenges.The lack of possibility for level-grinding can make the game sometimes spike in difficult (at one point I was forced to lower the difficulty setting in order to get past one point, as there was no way to level-grind my characters), but for the vast majority of the game the problems arising from this have been largely avoided. (There are many similar tactical games that have no level-grinding where it results in the game being exceedingly difficult, but this game successfully avoids it for the most part.)

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												Very enjoyable turn-based strategy game.  Easy to pickup, and a fun cast of characters that make your party. The core storyline is linear, but the battles are incredibly fun.  There is a lot of challenging battles, and plenty of easy battlse without a sweat.  It keeps the game tight toward the battle, because the overmap screen really gives you the chioce of what quests to pickup and what items to purchase, but there is not any unnecessary travel.  Essentially, you fast travel from location to location, and many times entering a battle at the various desitinations. There a few main enemies that show up multiple times, and adds to the drama.  However, the story is enjoyable, the battles at the last stage leading to the ultimate battle are quite good, however, the ending is a bit of let down.  However, that doesn't take away from everything they did to make this game awesome. If you like controlling your party for turn based D&D battles, you are going to love this game. :)

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												Pros:*Interesting system mechanics, with a LOT of depth to advancement.Cons:*Tutorial and Tips are useless.  I had been playing for over 2 hours (8+ combat missions) before I got a couple of the tips on how to do basic things.*Horrible camera system.  Unable to rotate the camera, forcing you to revert to top down view in many areas just to be able to see the hex map behind objects/allies/enemies.*No resource regeneration out of combat.  You can camp to restore Health and Astral points, which isn't bad, but when you hit one of the first major fight areas, you are prevented from camping.  You are forced to use town healers to restore HP out of combat, even if you have 2 mages with healing in your party.  No Astral Point (mana) regeneration outside of combat, even with talents that grant passive Astral Regen per turn, forcing you to use your very expensive Astral Potions to be able to actually use a mage character.*Treating injuries with bandages has a chance to fail (very high chance) outside of combat, and almost useless to try in combat (6% chance of success at first rank).*You are forced to buy belts to be able to carry many items into combat with you, but you are encumbered in combat by ALL the equipment in your bags, even you quest items and camping resources.*Almost no income, with horribly high priced item.  At one point, you are given a large amount of money and told to go to the armorer to get equiped to help defend a town.  The armorer has 1 type of armor, 2 sets of it, and you are given enough to buy 1 piece of equipment.  Not a set, 1 piece.  You have to choose between upgrading a single piece of heavy armor, or to buy Astral and Health potions.*Horrible UI.  Almost no explanations as to what means what, or as to how anything is calculated.  When comparing armor pieces, it does not compare piece to piece, only how it will change your whole, and armor/encumbrance always shows a penalty, even if it is an upgrade.*Horrible combat encounter design.  In many of the fights, all of the mobs will sit back throwing poisoned javelines at you, each of which hits your heavily armored character for 15-30% of his total HP, and also poisons him.  Was forced to use the fighter as a tank, both of my mages as pure healers, while slowly grinding down the mobs hp with my archer (arrows cost a lot, and have weight.  I overmaxed my encumbrance just from provisions, which you need to camp, and arrows alone).*Buff, healing and utility spells have default fail chance, which until you pick of a very very expensive talent, are almost impossible to cast (22% fail chance to heal an ally, 68% chance to fail to dispel a poison with a spell that only dispels poisons, 48% chance to fail to cast a "wall" spell, etc).  Combined with no innate astral regen, very low astral point pool and high astral point cost to cast makes playing a mage character feel like your being penalized for playing the game.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												Turn based combat system? Yes please!One thing I appreciate about the game is that so far I haven't encountered any battles that felt repetitive. The maps, the environments, interactive elements on the maps (starting fires ftw!), and the variety of opponents have kept it fresh so far. Of course I need to state that I'm only on Chapter 2 at this point, so maybe that changes. Some battles have been easy enough, others have been challenging. There's been a few battles that I've had to retry but it's been a fun challenge, not a drain on my enjoyment of the game.So far, I'm loving this game and have been looking forward to playing it as time permits. I started over 6 hours into the game to switch from a basic character to an expert (custom) character. Having become more familiar with the game, I wanted to be able to customize my character more. I'm 20+ hours into this game and I'm still enjoying it which is a positive sign!

number of helpful: 7 of 17 people (41%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Blackguard is difficult. Blackguard is long. Blackguard is fun. The game forces you to utilize your envirounment on the maps of the different battles you will fight. The Mano a mano approach often leads to defeat or severe injurie. There's a lot of thinking, planning and retrying involved (when a strategy doesn't pan out), especially since you can only save before and after a battle, not during it. It's great though, makes the feeling of accomplishment that much stronger once you beat a battle while achieving all optional goals.The length of the game is very refreshing. 40 hours can very well be exceeded, depending on how often you fail ;) All said and donde, Blackguard is a real treat for all fans of tactical round based gaming. The story is kind of nice, but the gameplay is what kept me glued to this game for hours since I started.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												Pretty good SRPG, decent graphics,gameplay and leveling mechanics in terms of many choices to level up in and really create characters you want for your tactics.Some of the fights, or rather mechanics in the games are kind of broken. You can miss like 10-15 times on a row, even with maxed skills and thus lose fights on it, and other times you might hit and crit on bosses constantly and wipe them extremly fast... A quick examples are bosses that has 40% dodge on any attacks you do. Now imagien that they also poison you, and spawning mobs that are basically impossible to kill. Now, you can lose this fight, like I did 10+ times because you keep missing everytime. And yes, then another time, you might hit basically every swing and boss is down before you know it. Thats not balanced, its just random and in a SRPG based on tactics luck should never play a big part into it. I can understand some luck mechanics for the rpg-elements, but 40% miss on a boss that hit hard back? and he is a tank? Come on...I would give this game maybe a 7.5 or 8.0 of 10. When this game is at its best its actually really good, but when its at its worst its horrible. Probably need better beta test for the sequal in terms of balancing out battles, be more open about what to level up in, lots of trial and errors if you dont know what your supposed to level up or not. Also, the story and sidequest need to be better... basically as it is now, side-quest are kind of neccessary to finish for that vital AP which you level up in. So its not even a choice to do them or not.I finished the game in 40 hours on normal difficulty, so this is a pretty lenghty game I guess 35 to 45+ hours.Would I buy the sequal? Probably, yes, especially when its on some kind of a cheap discount, because I love srpg's and wanna support them (Final Fantasy Tactics need a sequal...) - but if the sequal for Blackguards, which is in development at this moment, get good reviews from the critics, I would probably buy it at launch. As I said this game could be great, it isnt however atm in this state in terms of balancing and storywise.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												I want to start off by saying that despite its many apparent flaws there is something that I find deeply compelling about this game.  The battle system is pretty good, you have quite a few options during combat and the interactive battlefields add a layer of fun and somewhat fresh gameplay.  My primary gripe with Blackguards is the difficulty.  To say that Blackguards is a challenging game is an understatement, but I feel that the way that Blackguards challenges you is a bit contrived and ultimately kind of cheap.  I've played difficult games in which I've lost or barely won a battle and have walked away thinking "wow that was a good fight".  In Black Guards if I lose I usually feel like I've been robbed.  You constantly miss spells and attacks and the enemy constantly connects whether you're fighting a semi-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ goblin, a backstabbing rogue or a giant tree.  And the dire situations that you are placed in again and again suggest to me that you're not so much a group of badasses so much as you are really gullible and kind of incompetent.    The main character feels really generic.  Pretty much everyone or everything that you encounter seems better suited for combat than the protaganist.  And so far I don't feel like the four playable characters that I have encountered live up to the name Blackguards.  They actually seem like relatively nice guys.  When I saw the name Blackguards I got excited because I had assumed that I would be taking on the roles of the Lannisters from GOT.  Instead it feels more like I've signed on with the Partridge family.  I've only  played a few hours so far and I'm not giving up on the game entirely just yet, but that's mostly because of the price tag.  This is not a 40 dollar game and I would not recommend that anyone pay that much to play this.  I work as a merchant sailor and I am literally stuck on a boat for the next month so I will be playing on.  If I get to a point in the gameplay in which I feel that my assesment was premature or unfair I will return to humbly apologize and I sincerely hope that, that happens.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												Calling this a tactical RPG is insult to all the real Tactics games that came before it.  The combat is from Heroes of Might and Magic.  Flat hex map walk towards each other and swing, over and over.  90% of the skills are useless (spend points on being able to see the hit chance of the guy I'm swinging at anyway, or spend points on +1 to hit), and the 3d20 skill system may be novel for the RPG this is based on but here it is just opaque and weird.   Going straight from battle to battle is actually a good thing, so don't fault it for not being the JRPG it is not.  But boring battles and boring equipment and boring skills in a Tactics game is a bad thing.  I'm going to go play Disgaea to wash out my brain.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												This is possibly the ugliest modern indie game I have had the displeasure of playing in a very long time. Everything from the sound mix to the graphics, down to the skid-mark brown art style. The only reconciliation is that I purchased when it was packaged with other junk and highly discounted. I highly recommend you do some research and watch some videos before buying this. If it wasn't so expensive I'd give this as a gift to people I don't like. It's so bad it makes me want to punch puppies and burn kittens. I mean it is just utterly atrocious. To put all that into context, it should be noted that I enjoy games like NEOScavenger. So yeah, don't buy this game unless your'e a masochist. The only darkness and gritiness here is the quality of development. I'm fairly certain they just dragged their taint accross the keyboard a few times and shipped it as a game. (╯°□°）╯︵ ┻━┻

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												Calling this a tactical RPG is insult to all the real Tactics games that came before it.  The combat is from Heroes of Might and Magic.  Flat hex map walk towards each other and swing, over and over.  90% of the skills are useless (spend points on being able to see the hit chance of the guy I'm swinging at anyway, or spend points on +1 to hit), and the 3d20 skill system may be novel for the RPG this is based on but here it is just opaque and weird.   Going straight from battle to battle is actually a good thing, so don't fault it for not being the JRPG it is not.  But boring battles and boring equipment and boring skills in a Tactics game is a bad thing.  I'm going to go play Disgaea to wash out my brain.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												I want to start off by saying that despite its many apparent flaws there is something that I find deeply compelling about this game.  The battle system is pretty good, you have quite a few options during combat and the interactive battlefields add a layer of fun and somewhat fresh gameplay.  My primary gripe with Blackguards is the difficulty.  To say that Blackguards is a challenging game is an understatement, but I feel that the way that Blackguards challenges you is a bit contrived and ultimately kind of cheap.  I've played difficult games in which I've lost or barely won a battle and have walked away thinking "wow that was a good fight".  In Black Guards if I lose I usually feel like I've been robbed.  You constantly miss spells and attacks and the enemy constantly connects whether you're fighting a semi-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ goblin, a backstabbing rogue or a giant tree.  And the dire situations that you are placed in again and again suggest to me that you're not so much a group of badasses so much as you are really gullible and kind of incompetent.    The main character feels really generic.  Pretty much everyone or everything that you encounter seems better suited for combat than the protaganist.  And so far I don't feel like the four playable characters that I have encountered live up to the name Blackguards.  They actually seem like relatively nice guys.  When I saw the name Blackguards I got excited because I had assumed that I would be taking on the roles of the Lannisters from GOT.  Instead it feels more like I've signed on with the Partridge family.  I've only  played a few hours so far and I'm not giving up on the game entirely just yet, but that's mostly because of the price tag.  This is not a 40 dollar game and I would not recommend that anyone pay that much to play this.  I work as a merchant sailor and I am literally stuck on a boat for the next month so I will be playing on.  If I get to a point in the gameplay in which I feel that my assesment was premature or unfair I will return to humbly apologize and I sincerely hope that, that happens.

												Fascinating turn-based RPG. I love the story so far, enriched by these interesting characters. If you're into the Dark Eye universe, this is a must-buy, for everyone else: If you enjoy challenging battles that involve the environment, you will find yourself at home. Don't expect anything groundbreaking tho - fights can drag on for a while and there is no way to quicksave during a battle, which can get frustrating if you can't figure out a certain tactic - especially on the hardest difficulty.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												A non-biased quick look @ the game:


YouTube™ Video: ➜ A Quick Look @ 'Blackguards' (GeForce GT 640) 

			Views: 22		

			You can get the game here: http://store.steampowered.com/app/249650 A non-biased quick look @ 'Blackguards' - What happens when the only hope of a threatened world lies not with heroes in shining...		

What happens when the only hope of a threatened world lies not with heroes in shining armor, but in the hands of a band of misfits and criminals? Blackguards, a new turn-based strategy RPG, explores this very question. You will discover over 180 unique hex-based battlegrounds within a dark and mature story of crime, drugs, and murder. Play as a warrior, mage or hunter and customize your character's skills as you see fit. The challenging campaign delivers a story of doubt, treason and loss. You decide the course of the story at key turning points and determine its outcome. - Recommended!

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												i regret buying the game at 50% off . I enjoyed the first chapter then it got a bit tedious , it seemed a game designed to make sure you had no fun. I love turn based tactical games and i dont think i've ever played one i didnt enjoy before.character develpoment and advancemet is dreadful , worst of any RPG or CRPG i've ever played , It's so boring and mundane. There's an illusion of freedom but really you just stick to a few skills and spells that are clearly miles better , if you dont you end up with useless underpowered skills and characters.I think i am still using the same 1 skill with my melee and archer characters 10 hours into the game and the same 2 spells on my casters. There's just not enough variety to the game. In another 10 hours i probably be using the same 2 skills. Thats not enough depth for a tactical game or an RPG.As an RPG it is without doubt poor but i expected that and assumed the tactical combat would make up for it , it didnt , the combat was worse than i expected and that is the reason i eventually got bored of clicking the same 2 buttons and stopped playing

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												Highly recommended for fans of turn-based fantasy and role-playing games in general.Pros: The adventure system is a welcome relief from wandering around huge towns of useless NPCs. It's similar to point-and-click adventures of old. Let's you get to the story and/or combat quickly.Cool level-up system. Characters really start to feel powerful at later levels.Attractive graphics and runs smoothly.Neat battle set-ups. Battles have traps, special objectives, secrets, and ambushes. There are a good number of straight up fights, but the set piece battles really spice things up.Interesting (but not completely original) story with an compelling (but really not original) cast. It keeps you interested enough to follow along rather than just clicking through the dialogs, and the cut-scenes are simple but well done.Cons: I strongly recommend starting on "Easy" difficultly. This really feels like it should be the default and is best for first-time players. The mechanics of the game are a little obscure, and having one play-through under your belt is best. Easy offers a good challenge without being frustrating, and gives you freedom to explore the game.Again, obscure mechanics and no way to respec makes the game progression rather unforgiving.Sparse loot. Don't get me wrong, I think it is a nice chance of pace to have magic items actually be rare and not drop 11 times each battle, but it feels like the game is really stingy with the rewards. It does make the few items you get feel more special but, unfortunately, they're not even that much better than the standard ones you can buy.The characters you get aren't very customizable in their roles. But they do what they do well. Low replayability. You could replay the game on a harder difficulty, but why? It's a long game and nothing is really randomized. It's not really much of a con though since the game is so long with lots of optional quests.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
												Blackguards is a turn-based strategy game with strong RPG elements, rather like XCOM but with a much greater variety of character customization. (Though it has a reasonable story, you might be disappointed if you're looking for an RPG. It isn't open world, there aren't many meaningful story choices for you to make, and there isn't much customization available for your character's appearance.)The campaign is reasonably long, though the game doesn't feel repetitive thanks to reasonably varied fight scenarios and win-conditions. Early problems with bugged quests and translation issues from the original German seem mostly resolved at this point (I only noticed some spelling errors in the English version and had no problems with bugged quests.)Common complaints about the game focus on numerous loading screens and an unintuitive UI. I found the UI fairly easy to pick up myself, only issuing incorrect commands once or twice. Though there are a lot of loading screens between scenarios, each one lasted only 1-3 seconds for me so they didn't detract from my experience. People playing on systems using HDDs rather than SSDs may find the loading screens take longer and so are more annoying, though.I was worried by the relatively low Metacritic score for this game, but I'm glad I wasn't deterred. If you like single-player, turn-based strategy games that put you in control of a small group of specialized combatants, you'll probably like this.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												In a nut-shell, you'' definetely like Blackguards if you are into turn-based, hex-based linear tactical RPGs. For one, i do!The combat is nicely done and obviously the strong point of the game - it works, and keeps you challenged (at least, up to now).The graphics are nice, but a little too cartoon-ish for my taste (and for the atmosphere the game tries to create).The story is good enough to carry you from chapter to chapter, although it's a little obvious in its twists.There are obviously a few cons as well:- The biggest minus for me it's the inventory, and the way it works. You don't get a clear comparison between your equipped item and another one, in your pack or at a vendor - this alone makes choosing weapons a nuisance at later stages. The inventory also becomes cluttered extremely easy. - Also a minus is the auto saving system. The game makes it that, quite a few times, you have to fight battle after battle, without possibility of resting&healing. And the autosave saves as you enter a new battle. This means that, if you don't take extra care, you'll end up (it happened to me once) in a position i hate most in RPGs - making some bad decisions in a 3rd-in-a-row battle, i had no chance of winning the 4th. And the autosave was only for the 4th. So i had to restart not only the 3 battles before, but the whole branch of the chapter (a lot of dialogue and cinematics included) - and i hate remaking choices i already made, listening to the same lines over and over again etc. They should have made an auto save for each battle, and an autosave for entering a chain of events/battles - this way, you can restart the fights without restarting the story itself.Anyway, all in all, is a nice game (and i bought it during a sale) - so i give it 7.5/10.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Blackguards is great. Based on The Dark Eye setting and tabletop roleplaying game rules this game really captures those rules and lets them shine in a way previous real-time titles have not. The turn based nature of the combat system in the game really lets you see the benifit of the various different builds of characters where in a realtime combat game such as Drakensang based off of the same rule set does not.The plot is engaging, lengthy, and at times really does feel like a transcript of a tabletop campaign, which is great for someone who maybe used to tabletop and just doesnt have the time to, or doesnt get the opportunity to as often as they would like.All things said, I paid full price for the game, and don't think I spent even a penny more than the game was worth.

												I played till the end and it wasn't a bad trip, but there are some points that annoyed me.Broken achievements the most.I'm a achievement hunter and this games is so full of bugs concerning achievements it made me crazy. (20% !!)You just can't get them.Some achievement don't even make sense!! Why would I upgrade every spell to 10?! Why not 8 where you get to the next level of the spell?! Getting all spells up to 10 is a HUGE waste of EP!?Same with teaching a character all weapon types. Why would I do that?! That's just stupid!Why would I upgrade character specifics that are only good for a mage or a warrior?Second, is there really much of alterning the storyline? Because they tried to act like it but it seems to me that is rubbish.Fighting system was fun and okay, but it is true that there should have been a little bit more variety of enemies and also goals. The story... well, could have been better. A bit confusing and in the end I don't really know what we needed that big word we searched so long for... what ever.I bought the game cheap and I would do it again, but don't buy it for the regular price, it isn't that good.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2016
												This game has kept me interested for hours and hours of play.  The different scenarios forcing you to use different stragies, defeating you over and over, then finding a different strategy to kick it in the dirt is so satisfying.  The game allows you to build characters in any which way, whether you wanna shoot at the baddies from afar with bows and crossbows, or be a complete juggernaut and get your hands dirty with beefy armor and an axe.  Some features might cause the game to be a little too easy after a while, such as massive gold accumulation making cheap healing outside of combat very convenient.  Even so, this game is a great one to check out and play around with.

												Great graphics, good dialogue.  Decent story.  Great skill selection.  Two things ruin it for me: 1. Not able to customise keys. (I have a disability and use a trackball which has no wheelso there is no way for me to change the camera angle.  Minor issue.)2. Difficulty. content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												Just so much failure in this game. I really wanted to like it, but it just does so many things just wrong. Everything is ridiculously expensive, there is zero immersion. For example my guys all have crappy torches, and we have had crappy torches for well over an hour, killing guys with axes and swords. When we defeat said guys, you'd think we get a sword right? NOP! Still stuck with the crappy torches! And still can't afford 1 crappy hand axe, which the game seems to value at 13 gold! These developers are clueless at both medieval history and game balance (a hand axe would NEVER cost anywhere that much) !  Oh, and then the game wants to kill gigantic troll with your crap weapons! It's like the game is trolling you! I didn't even mention that almost everything to do in this game can just fail as it does nothing and waste your turn. It seems the way the developers want you to  get through this game is to save scum your way through, just hope you hit the all the monsters all the time and load if you don't! How fun!  This game is just a package of false promises that ends in dashed hopes and shame; just stay away.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2016
												Great tactical RPG.  The sequel is better in some ways, but they're both great, so I recommend you start here.  There are a few ugly little graphical issues here & there, but they're not common, so it's not a big deal.  I love the relatively low-magic fantasy setting & the fact that just casting a spell successfully, not to mention hitting the target, is genuinely difficult at first.  The ending is the weakest part, unfortunately.  One issue I have before that is the way the game handles damage types.  It seems a bit odd & nonsensical to me.  For instance, if you get an enchanted mace that does fire damage, (& don't expect to find any such wonders easily,) it does pure fire damage & no physical damage, & this is just one example.  Skeletons are completely immune to piercing damage, etc., etc.. Still a good game, though.  Battles are pretty difficult at times.  A lot of people seem to think this game is too hard, but I disagree.  I enjoy the challenge, & I hope you do too.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 13, 2016
												I've been playing the game for around 4 hours at this point and I'll be honest...  I don't get the bad rep this game is getting...  The characters (so far) are well voiced, the story, although fairly generic, is decent enough and the combat system is decent.I will admit, I bought the game as a part of this weekends sale, so got both Blackguards 1 & 2 along with a bunch of other games for about £12.  I've been tempted by both of these for some time now, but was put off by the reviews and the price.  So far, I have found these to be unfounded.I dove straight in on character creation rather than have the system do half the work for you and I am learning it as I go.  There's a lot to choose from so I just went with basics at least to start with.  It looks diverse enough to branch out later, which is always nice.Sure, there is a large element of RNG, but look at XCOM...  That game has continually devastated its players by repeated 95%+ shots missing at the, single, most crucial shot of the game.  I can't count how many times in that I have missed that said shot and the mission suddenly went to hell.  This is no different, though I have yet to encounter anything so drastic, but it's still early days.I can certainly see the game getting repetitive after a time, but there seems to be a lot more variation than XCOM in terms of attacks you can do, especially when you take in to account the spells.I would say that this game is definitely recommended to fans of TBS games and also to those of strategic fantasy games.  I would also definitely say that this game 'should' be recommended.To set 'not recommended' as others have because it's niche is just a tad overkill tbh.  If they aren't interested in a game just because it's a TBS or fantasy, then why are they looking at it in the first place?  It's a moot point.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												First of all this game does not deserve the mixed reviews it has received.  I've been a fan of CRPGs since the days of Might and Magic.  Maybe it's the nostalgia of the Dark Eye ruleset that reminds me of games like Star Trail, which even with its flaws I love. I cannot understand some of the complaints I've heard here. I find the battle difficulty perfect. I know this may turn some people off, but I love it. I typically play all of my RPGs on the hardest settings. I play this on normal. There is an easy mode if you need. It's understandable. That said everytime I'm frustrated I put it down, come back to it later, and succeed.  I will say that I restarted once because given the difficulty I was unhappy with how I had planned out my characters. Let me also say that I am happy there was not a "respec" option.Pros:Feels like a classic CRPGSuperb characters and voice actingGreat truly tactical combat systemSuprisingly mature storyline and writingLengthy - some might see this as a flaw, I love itCons:Limited character creation/customization optionsUninteresting and simple models/textures for armor/charactersA few bugs, some graphical, at least one gameplayNote: For those complaining about the RNG, please remember that the mother of all RPGs D&D is a dice game. Get over it.TLDR:Great game worth the 4$ or whatever it is in the store right now. I would have bought it for much more. I can't wait to start the sequel.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
												Fun game overall, pleasant enough to play - and quite longer than I originally expected - but didn't like it enough to throw myself onto the second installment. I might wait for it to be on sale. For the time invested, the ending felt rushed and not all that satisfactory, but overall game still gets the thumbs up. I remember when this initially came out awhile back that people were going on about the darkness of the anti-heroes, the crudeness of the dialogue, almost juvenile humor, etc. Maybe years of playing the Witcher games have heightened (or is that lowered) my tolerance bar, but nothing in Blackguards even raised my eyebrow. In fact, rather than being the EDGY ANTI-HEROES that seem be everywhere these days, it was kind of relaxing to find out that my party were just a bunch of losers, with a lazy, whiny main character, a dwarf who is possibly nuts and most certainly an arsonist, a philandering wizard, and that's just to start with. Rather than choices that are downright eeeeeevil, you mainly get the choice between being a cold-hearted pragmatist or a bit more charitable, which works great. Voice acting was quite good for the price and the type of games, and the graphics, well, they are what they are, I don't mind (honorable mention goes to the fire effects which may be the prettiest I've seen in ANY game at ANY price tag.)I didn't find the combat to be as intense, strategic or engaging as Original Sin, but it was satisfying enough. The lauded interactive elements were for the most part useless when the surest, easiest strategy (on Normal, anyway) was to fall back, put my tanks in front of my glass cannons, hop the former up with all the buffs I could lay on, and let rip. But the game would fairly frequently throw a curve ball to shake things up; some fights have limited turns before you lose an optimal victory condition, others force you to move forward with ever-spawning enemies or poison gas. There was enough variety that it never got too repetitive or boring, though obviously some of the fights are going to feel annoying or unfair, or leave you way too open for the revenge of the RNG demon. Conclusion: I feel no rush to play this again, but I have no regrets buying it in the first place.

content:
Posted: January 3
												I have mixed feelings on this game. I got it on sale and would recommend it as such, but this game is not worth 40$. Nothing in this game is bad except for the UI, but nothing is good either. Nothing impressed me at all. The spell system having 3 stats associated to every spell just doesn't make sense. I need strength for magic? Wait what? Okay it would make sense if its a force push or something maybe that fits right? Well one of them creates and arcane wall, the other is a debuff. How is that associated to strength at all? Most irritating part is some fights are just not properly balanced. There is one fight I spent over an hour on, had the moves mapped to a science, and just needed the RNG to connect. If you let the guy hit you on the second turn and poison you, you simply cannot win. So one companion has to move the perfect amount of tiles away from the enemy so it will chase him, while the other moves away and shoots at the non poisoning opponent. Kiting of this level doesn't have a place in a game like this. When I have to take my tank and run him in circles to not die, I feel like the developers missed something...  And to put it in perspective, I have the best armor and stats possible at the current place for a tank, and he cannot tank nor do I even consider him "tanky". Your shield will add a lot to your parry, but you can only parry once per turn turn so what is the point? My mage honestly has just as good of a chance to survive as he does wearing cloth without a shield. I love games like this, and this one just doesn't shine enough for me to recommend it over what is out there. As I said I don't feel it is bad, but I am not finishing the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 9
												Update: Finished game, would hardly call unfair, most fights in the game took a max of 2-3 tries, plenty were 1shots. Did all sidequests I ran across before completion, not sure how close to 100% I was, but I'd guess I probably did a good 85-90% of the content on offer. It's just about learning the game to be honest, there's nothing super difficult here. I play a good variety of games and hardly am "an expert" at turn based tactics games for comparison to what you can expect. Fun game, a couple of times I found the combat very slow and wished I could skip through enemy turns when there were lots of enemies (last dungeon had a couple like this...)Pretty funny seeing all the people here whine about this game being unforgiving or super difficult... I am completely new to Dark Eye game systems and have just taken my time in looking at the character trees etc and sort of feeling my way into where I'm spending my AP. I would say that if difficult = not 1shotting every single battle, then the game is "difficult". But beyond that, it's not very difficult. Every single encounter has taken me no more than 2 tries barring the end encounter for Chapter 2 (louse queen as a 3rd battle in a row with no recovery time. I decided to power thru it vs trying to load an old save and set myself up for easier success over all 3 as a whole with the knowledge I'd gained... too lazy to do that). And I can even say that the first attempt is often experimentation or trial/error with the different maps, traps and interactables etc and perhaps new enemy types. It's fairly easy so far, although I will say that the difficulty is spiky; it runs the gamut from faceroll to mildy challenging (and some of the reviews I see whining about difficulty are from people that spent far less time than I, so I doubt it's where I am in the game) -- honestly if you are having trouble, maybe reevaluate your movement and positioning. I've found that there is a lot of advantage to be gained and strategy in positioning and more or less "gaming the map" to keep control and manage some of the risk/rng. This is a hex based game, and sometimes moving 2 hexes right or left can change a whole lot. To give an example -- I saw a "WTF is" by TotalBiscuit, where he played a fairly early map and thought it was frustrating and difficult... immediately started making major positioning oversights in the very first turn he had. The corridor is bottlenecked to 3 hexes wide and there are like 6 active crypt lice. Why would you not move 3 characters onto each of those hexes and wait for the lice to come to you? Then you are only fighting 3 at once you only have 3 characters of your choosing taking damage (far more control over damage intake). Following this, you have infinite recovery turns on the map to heal before moving forward and "activating" the next group. This is just a very basic example... and I don't really even dabble in strategy games all that much. I just don't see how this game is hard. It's fairly simple with a bit of trial and error involved. The RNG complaints are also pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t... there is even a "wounds" system to manage the RNG... which I discovered at my leisure after continually investigating the ruleset as I played. Have some patience... you definitely don't need to read character guides to suceed. I've learned after playing and reading around that the optimal route is playing a mage as the hero (there's 0 disadvantage since there are basically characters that can cast and characters that can't -- everything else can be developed as you see fit as the game goes on...), and I'm doing just fine.

Posted: February 8
												I want to like this game, I really do. But there are several critical issues that the game designers should have fixed before release or fixed in a patch.The most critical issue is there are points in the game that are dead ends. What I mean by this is there are situations that will force you to restart because you won’t be able to get around them. One example is a scenario where your players cant leave a series of encounters and if you can’t beat the one of those encounters the game is effectively over. Scratch 15 hours of play. I assume there are more to come.The game looks great and the system is deep enough to make it interesting. The issue is with the encounter design and the above is only one example (although be it the worst) so far in my playthrough.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 17
												Another example of a great (in places) game putting off players do to poor presentation of core game mechanics to player base / very poor ingame feedback. I don't know what the developers were aiming for with the way the final product turned out (it is NOT due to technical ineptitude or lack of creative ability - the game mechanics are consistent with its defined rule set, full of intelligent puzzles and reasonably bug free).The lack of transparency (markedly unsound - it badly hurts their sales numbers by quickly alienating the "shallower" player base. ) seems to be caused largely due to intended design. Maybe TDE (dark eye) game rules are were so second nature to the developers they coudn't see how difficult it will be for "foreigners" to make sense of their otherwise "working within parameters" product. It almost like the game is made by aliens strangers to earth based game interface progression in the last 20 years. Maybe this what a game made by programmers/designers that don't play computer games should be expected to turn out (speculation). cons-very limited ruleset/mecanics exposition and ingame feedback (steam guides mostly fixes this)-alien game interface: bits of relevant information are scattered all over the place (need to navigate 5-6 "screens" to gather basic info about a character - a feat the good modern games can achieve in 1-2 "screens" with overwelmingly superior amount of detail - wastes player time, hurts immersion)-stoneage like combat log functionality (mising a lot game critical events and the ones presented lack detail)  -rough spell/ weapon class balance-nearly impossible to read opponent's percentage based resists ( some even have vulnerabilities to certain damage types but it is extremely hard to tell due to the hidden resist stats , RNG damage component and poor combat log features)-liniar story, set drops(limited itemisation issues) and poor spell/abilities balance (few powerbuilds builds) leads to poor replayability value. (maybe the obfuscation was intended to mask/hide the poor balance to the players - or the poor balance is the result of the obfuscation making it hard for the devs to see the problems ?)pros-the community with a bit of help from developers managed to unwind most of the critical game mechanics (check out the game's player guides section)-the game is well oiled (very few bugs), the creative people did great - very high intelligent puzzle combat variation(enjoyable once you start grasping the game mechanics).   I still recommend this game despite its numerous flaws because it has the capability to enthral players for hours, but wait for significant special offer discounts .
